XML.Hansard-Body: The Legislative Assembly met at 9.30 am.
Mr Speaker (Hon. John Mickel, Logan) read prayers and took the chair.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Expenditure of the Office of the Speaker
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I lay upon the table of the House the Statement of public disclosure: Expenditure of the Office of the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly for the period 1 July 2009 to 31 December 2009.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Statement for public disclosure--Expenditure of the Office of the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly for the period 1 July 2009 to 31 December 2009.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Clerk presented the following paper petitions, lodged by the honourable members indicated--

Dr Robinson , from 100 petitioners, requesting the House to amend the appropriate Juvenile Justice and Police Powers legislation to ensure that police have the power to bring children back to their parents and that children are not permitted to roam the streets at will.
Mr Ryan , from 43 petitioners, requesting the House to ensure that Bribie Island is removed permanently from the list of potential Desalination Plant sites in Queensland.

Mr O’Brien , from 53 petitioners, requesting the House to respect the Aboriginal flag; legislate into the laws of Queensland the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples; return all the lands, territories and resources that have traditionally belonged to the Aboriginal Peoples except those which are otherwise compensated; and reject any and all amendments to the Queensland Constitution which do not uphold the rights of the Aboriginal Peoples and which have not received the prior, informed consent of the Aboriginal Peoples.
Petitions received.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts)
(9.32 am): It is very pleasing to see that Queensland is experiencing what appears to be a normal wet season with life giving rain being delivered to many parts of the state. Unfortunately, we cannot control Mother Nature and over the last two months some of this rain has caused flooding and disrupted many communities across Queensland. Sadly, several people have also lost their lives as a result of this flooding. As our thoughts are with the family and friends of those who have lost lives, I again remind all Queenslanders to take extreme caution around watercourses, particularly following torrential rain.

During the recent flooding events, our emergency response agencies, local governments and SES volunteers have again done an outstanding job responding to calls for assistance throughout Queensland and in providing a helping hand where required. The government has also actively been assessing the nature and extent of the disaster relief that needs to be provided. To date, the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services has activated natural disaster relief and recovery arrangements for 50 local government areas. In all but one area relief measures have only been activated to assist with the costs of counterdisaster operations and the restoration of essential public assets. Following an assessment by the Department of Communities, assistance under the disaster relief assistance scheme has been activated for people living within the Isaac Regional Council, particularly those in the Clairview and St Lawrence areas, experiencing personal hardship.

I am pleased to advise the House that while the recent flooding events have caused some significant damage across the state, most people who have been affected on this occasion have been able to personally cope with the damage and have had the capacity to meet their immediate needs. This ability to cope with the aftermath of natural disasters such as these flooding events demonstrates the continuing resilience of Queenslanders as well as the commitment of our emergency service workers to put in place strategies to help mitigate the challenges associated when events like flooding occur.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.35 am): Yesterday I was pleased to launch the Queensland Arts and Cultural Sector Plan 2010-2013 here at Parliament House. More than 1,400 people from across Queensland have contributed to this four-year industry development framework to build a strong and sustainable arts and cultural sector in Queensland. This sector plan promotes key values that are integral to a strong and vibrant arts and cultural sector such as shared leadership, industry partnerships, closer working relationships with our government partners and stronger national and global networks.

The plan’s goals and strategies focus on five key areas. They are: great arts and culture; engaged audiences and culturally active communities; a strong and diverse economy; creative spaces and places; and a commitment to ongoing learning. By focusing on these key areas we can create an arts and cultural sector where everyone can be involved in the arts as part of their daily lives, where our artists and producers are creating quality arts and cultural experiences and where we have the right facilities and spaces for a vibrant creative culture. The plan focuses on ways to stimulate creativity, entrepreneurship and the use of new media and technologies as ways to grow the sector’s contribution to the economy and to employment.

It is important for Queenslanders to recognise the contribution the arts community makes to all our lives--culturally, socially and economically. Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics identified in 2008 that 85 per cent of Australians aged 15 years and over attended cultural activities at least once a year. Statistics from 2006 indicate that 3.5 million Australians worked in the cultural sector and in 2006-07 this sector exported cultural goods valued at $534.1 million. Over the past 10 years, Queensland has greatly enhanced its place within the national cultural landscape with programs of international significance at the Gallery of Modern Art and the State Library building, and at the redeveloped Queensland Performing Arts Centre.

This is only part of the story. Longstanding Queensland favourites like the Woodford Folk Festival, the Gympie Music Muster and the Laura Dance Festival along with the growing national and international recognition for Queensland’s lively small to medium arts organisations attest to the remarkable creative energy of arts and culture here in our state. Best of all, we can look forward with confidence to the emergence of new creative projects and events to add to this record.

The Cairns Indigenous Arts Fair, staged for the first time last year, has brought new levels of interest and recognition to the quality and diversity of Queensland’s Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander arts and culture. That program arose out of the Arts and Cultural Sector Plan that preceded the one I launched yesterday. The opening of the new facility the Edge at the Cultural Centre later this week will also drive a whole new wave of creative output using digital technologies. We will stage the state’s first-ever design triennial, focusing on design thinking from the Asia-Pacific region.

The arts and cultural sector in Queensland is not only alive and well, it is making an extraordinary contribution to life in our state--to our prosperity, to our national and international reputation and to individual and community wellbeing. The Queensland Arts and Cultural Sector Plan for the next three years, which I launched yesterday, will provide the platform for the next stage of growth, will guide government decision making and investment in arts and culture and will provide for future success for our artists and cultural workers.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.38 am): Today we kick-start our campaign to further boost the literacy skills of Queensland students. Today we begin our efforts to recruit an army of volunteers to read with children in our schools. With our Queensland Ready Readers program we seek to raise an army of 3,000 volunteers to share the magic of reading with our students.

The Ready Readers program is part of our determination to give Queensland children a flying start in education. The Ready Readers program is based on national and international research that shows that well-trained and supported community volunteers can make a big difference to children’s learning. Reading fuels young imaginations and it can help a child’s listening and language skills. It can promote attention and curiosity and can put them on the right track for a great start to their education. The Ready Readers initiative is part of an $8.7 million four-year funding commitment that includes new funding for Volunteering Queensland to work across Queensland with businesses and community organisations. It also includes funding for a major social marketing campaign around the importance of reading which will also be launched today.

It will draw on the fantastic skills of people out there in our community. Many members will know people in their own electorates who are very keen to get involved in their local school communities but often do not know how to go about it. Volunteering Queensland--a great Queensland organisation that is very well versed in recruiting volunteers and training them and supporting them--will manage the registration of interested volunteers through its website. This website contains registration forms, information about training requirements and time lines for when the initiative will be launched in specific areas. All volunteers will be trained in the Support A Reader process and will be required to go through the standard checks for working with children, and they will read with students in our schools under the direction of classroom teachers. The first Ready Readers will be in our classrooms in Toowoomba, Townsville and Wide Bay by the start of second semester this year. The program will then be progressively rolled out so that all parts of the state will be covered by the beginning of school next year.

Today I have the pleasure of officially welcoming our first volunteer Ready Reader. Wyllene Banks is a former voluntary librarian and tuckshop helper and, most importantly, she is a passionate reader who will be a valuable asset to the program. Wyllene stars in our Ready Readers ads which aired on television last night in the three areas we are initially kicking off in. The ads promote reading awareness and will be aired state-wide and I hope that they encourage mums and dads and family members to take up the challenge to read to their children more often and more regularly.

The 2009 Australian Early Development Index shows that, nationally, approximately 70 per cent of children are regularly read to at home. This compared to 61 per cent of children in Queensland. Literacy starts at home. The ability for our teachers and our schools to build on a child’s literacy skills is enhanced when they come into our classrooms with some of the benefits of reading at home. So we need to ensure that parents understand what an important part of parenting this is and to make some priority for it, even if it is only a couple of minutes a day. I encourage all Queenslanders to consider becoming a Ready Reader. I urge them to log on to the Volunteering Queensland website to see what is involved. It is a fantastic opportunity for people to contribute to our children’s education, to be involved in their community and to support the good work that is being done by our teachers in schools right across Queensland.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (9.42 am): The Bligh government recognises that we have an ageing and growing population, and this means that we face huge challenges when it comes to delivering health care over the next 40 years. Australians are living longer. We now have the second longest life expectancy in the world. That means that a child born in 2010 can expect to live to 81 whereas a child born in 1965 will live, on average, to 71. Indeed, in 1910 the average male life expectancy was 59. But as we live longer our healthcare system will face greater challenges. According to the Commonwealth Treasury’s 2010 intergenerational report, the proportion of Australia’s population aged over 65 will almost double over the next 40 years and the population aged over 80 will quadruple.

Whilst our life expectancy is one of the longest in the world, we are facing a greater burden when it comes to chronic disease. We have the shortest elective surgery wait times in the nation and our ED wait times have improved from sixth to third, but we know we have to do better. That is why we committed to releasing monthly ED data and publish our quarterly public hospitals performance report, because unlike the National and Liberal Party we know that accountability breeds excellence. Indeed, there are many members of previous governments on the other side of this House elected before me who were part of that regime of nonaccountability, because we all know that their record is to put nothing on the record. The Bligh government recognises that whilst investment in our hospitals is crucial the fundamental priority--was that a comment from the guy who has never changed a nappy in his life and demonstrated that at parliament the other day?
Mr Hopper interjected.

Mr LUCAS: You clearly had not ever done it because you never knew about mothers taking male sons to bathrooms or toilets. You showed your ignorance. What do you think the rest of us do when we have daughters, pal!
Opposition members interjected.
Mr LUCAS: The Bligh government recognises that whilst investment--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr LUCAS: No, you never changed a nappy. You are such an unreconstructed neanderthal. You have never taken a child to a toilet or changed a nappy, clearly.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr LUCAS: I am not talking about you; I am talking about him.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Deputy Premier, address your comments through the chair and that way the comments will be less personal.
Mr LUCAS: Thank you, Mr Speaker. The Bligh--
Mr Seeney: And less rehearsed! Less rehearsed would be good!
Mr LUCAS: The Bligh government--
Mr Seeney: You’ve been practising that all night in the mirror!
Mr LUCAS: There is someone who cannot even change nappies for the other people on his own front bench!
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides!

Mr LUCAS: The Bligh government recognises that whilst investment in our hospitals is crucial the fundamental priority must be tackling chronic disease, and we recognise that prevention is the best cure. In 2008 we announced our Q2 strategy to make Queenslanders Australia’s healthiest people. The Queensland government currently invests more than $460 million in prevention in the Health portfolio alone. Not only do we have campaigns to encourage Queenslanders to give up smoking, drink more responsibly and find 30 minutes a day to exercise and get their two serves of fruit and five serves of vegies every day; we also have campaigns to tackle sexually transmitted diseases, encourage people to get vaccinated against vaccine-preventable diseases and monitor their blood pressure, just to name a few.

All this is promising news, but one of our most preventable chronic diseases--type 2 diabetes--is on the rise. The complications of type 2 diabetes include renal failure, cardiovascular disease and loss of lower limbs, not to mention a much poorer quality of life. Over 50 per cent of patients with type 2 diabetes will die prematurely of cardiovascular disease. Diabetes was the sixth leading cause of premature death and disability in Queensland in 2006. The Bligh government recognises that the increased rate of type 2 diabetes is one of the greatest challenges we face in health care. Diabetes currently costs the Queensland economy $500 million per year in hospital, medical, pharmaceutical, allied health and research costs. Over the next 30 years, according to the Commonwealth government intergenerational report, the cost of treating diabetes will rise 436 per cent from $1.6 billion to $8.6 billion. Diabetes related hospitalisations are expected to triple in Queensland to over 300,000 admissions each year by 2028. That is why the Premier and I are pleased to be hosting a diabetes round table next Tuesday to discuss the measures the Queensland government can take to strengthen our response to diabetes with some of Queensland’s leading diabetes clinicians and researchers in this field. The Bligh government is committed to tackling the onslaught of chronic disease. The Bligh government is planning for the future and looking ahead to the health challenges that we know are on the way.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (9.47 am): There is a proverb that says that if you are planning for a year sow rice; if you are planning for a decade plant trees; and if you are planning for a lifetime educate people, and that is just what we are doing. We are planning for the future by investing in some of Queensland’s brightest minds through programs like the Smart Futures PhD Scholarship. Today I can announce that 17 Queensland university students will each receive $24,000 over the next three years to support their research on a range of important areas, including how to better identify childhood anxiety, how to better treat health issues like motor neurone disease and prostate cancer, how to promote road safety and how to deal with climate change.

Last Friday I visited Bond University to see firsthand some of the research projects underway. This round is the first time the government has received applications from Bond for this program. To have four successful recipients out of four applications is a great result and a credit to the students and the academic staff at this university. There are other universities that are also benefiting from our investment in Queensland’s best and brightest. For example, Rachel McGeorge from Griffith University is working on developing more effective drugs to combat malaria, Libby Liggins of UQ is examining the impacts of climate change on key Great Barrier Reef species, Nathan Manthey from USQ in Toowoomba is investigating the use of biocomposites in industry, and Angela Watson of QUT is working on improving the collation of road trauma data to better inform road safety strategies. It is these types of research projects where world firsts are realised.

Since 2006 the government has awarded 80 Smart State and Smart Futures PhD scholarships valued at more than $1.6 million. This is an investment in brains. In the scientific breakthroughs of tomorrow, we are ensuring that Queensland builds a strong foundation of promising early stage researchers who will swell and nourish the ranks of our outstanding researchers into the future. The program is part of our $91 million Smart Futures Fund, which is an integral component of our long-term strategy to assist in the transformation of Queensland into a knowledge based economy and to diversify our traditional economic base. This is at the heart of our strategy to build a stronger Queensland economy powered by innovation and bright ideas for a brighter future.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (9.49 am): The Bligh government is committed to lifting standards in Queensland schools. We have a vision for education in Queensland to help all our children get the flying start that they deserve. We are working hand in hand with the federal government to roll out a range of initiatives designed to boost achievements in the classroom. We are covering different bases by focusing on students, parents, school leadership and teacher quality. We are helping students by mandating teaching times for literacy and numeracy and running summer school programs for students needing an extra helping hand. Turnaround teams and school audits are designed to identify and address whole-of-school issues to lift school performance.

We are also focused on parents as first teachers with our education campaign about the importance of reading to children and preparing them for school, as spoken about by the Premier this morning. When they get there, we know that they will have passionate, dedicated and confident teachers. We want to put more of these teachers in front of Queensland classes. That is why we are providing literacy and numeracy coaches, extra science teachers and extra professional development to give our teachers more support to build their confidence and knowledge in these critical subject areas. We have also introduced preregistration testing to ensure that teachers are graduating with the best possible training so that they have a sound knowledge of literacy, numeracy and science before they begin work.

We have a responsibility to examine any option that might help us get more great teachers into our classrooms and to support the teachers who are there. That is why we are looking at a program introduced by the Australian government and currently at work in Victoria called Teach for Australia. This program gives students practical experience in the classroom while they study for their teaching qualifications. These are highly skilled graduates in other professions, such as engineering or science, who have a passion for teaching. They face a strict set of criteria before being accepted. For example, in Victoria there were just 45 people selected out of 800 applicants. The successful applicants then undertake an intensive six-week training course before beginning their graduate diploma and entering the classroom. The students have a reduced teaching load and work closely with a mentor. This program is just one program that the government is considering and talking to parent and teacher groups about. We are keeping an open mind, and we will keep having an open mind, about anything that will help us give Queensland children a flying start.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (9.52 am): Today is Vindaloo Against Violence day. Vindaloo Against Violence is the creation of Mia Northrop, a Melbourne woman who is encouraging all Australians to take a stand against racial violence today by eating out at their local Indian restaurant. While Queensland has not seen the level of violence that has been witnessed in Victoria, we cannot afford to be complacent. Vindaloo Against Violence is the perfect chance for Queenslanders to show their support for the state’s 26,000-strong Indian community.

I am pleased to inform the House that the cafeteria at Parliament House will be serving Indian cuisine today. Dishes will include tandoori chicken, vegetable pakora and, of course, beef vindaloo. On ABC Radio this morning, Spencer Howson threw out a challenge to MPs who think they can stomach a hot vindaloo. Spencer nominated Vaughan Johnson, the member for Gregory, and I nominated Deputy Premier Paul Lucas. So the challenge is on. Perhaps the chef can come up with an extra hot vindaloo to test their mettle and, Mr Speaker, perhaps you can adjudicate.

I want to encourage as many Queenslanders as possible to enjoy their favourite curry at their local Indian restaurant today. I want to thank the Premier, Mr Speaker and the Leader of the House for supporting Vindaloo Against Violence. I am sure that all members, staff and visitors to the House will get behind this great initiative.

Queensland is home to more than 20,000 Indian students and the Bligh government values their contribution to the state’s cultural, social and economic life. We are getting on the front foot and supporting Queensland’s Indian community. Earlier this year I was pleased to announce the appointment of Umesh Chandra as liaison officer between the Queensland government and the state’s Indian community, and Umesh is here today up in the gallery. I look forward to sharing a curry with him at lunchtime today.

Last Friday, I also visited international students at Griffith University during O Week and I will be meeting students from QUT later day. In addition, this Sunday the Queensland Police Service will be conducting a free information seminar in Brisbane for Indian students, highlighting the range of state government support services that are available to them. The Bligh government is getting right behind Queensland’s Indian community and I want to encourage all members and all Queenslanders to Vindaloo Against Violence today.

Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (9.54 am): On 1 January this year we commenced the start of several changes to the laws regarding the recovery of outstanding monies from long-term fine defaulters. Last sitting week, I provided the House with an update on progress of the 12-month wheel-clamping trial. I can now provide an update on the two-year seizure-and-sale trial that commenced at the same time.

This two-year trial targets long-term fine defaulters who owe more than $1,000 and who refuse to accept responsibility for their unpaid fines. The initial phase of the trial is targeting those fine defaulters owing more than $5,000 who were not eligible for the vehicle immobilisation trial. The State Penalties Enforcement Registry team uses information gathered through initial investigations conducted for wheel clamping to identify fine defaulters with assets suitable for seizure and sale. These investigations involved the investigators identifying correct contact details, addresses and assets of these fine defaulters. The team then initiated telephone contact with fine defaulters and outlined the potential enforcement action.

As at 17 February 2010, 30 individual debtors with debts valued at $336,989 and 22 corporate debtors with debts valued at $223,316 have been identified as suitable candidates for seizure and sale. SPER officers are now starting to work their way through this list. SPER has sent property seizure warning notifications to four individual debtors with debts totalling $92,640 and one corporate debtor owing $17,587. It is pleasing to note that the corporate debtor, whose debt related to a conviction for having an unsafe workplace, finalised their outstanding debt of more than $17,000 after receiving the notice.

Also last week, seizure-and-sale warrants against two fine defaulters were issued to the Bailiffs Office of the Brisbane Magistrates Court. The two debtors have outstanding fines with a combined value of $19,524. If these debtors continue to refuse to meet their obligations and pay their overdue fines, the government will seize assets, including real property, which may include people’s homes. The Bligh government is serious about recovering monies from long-term fine defaulters and we will continue to use all measures available to get these people to pay their debts.

Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (9.57 am): I was referring before to the Deputy Premier’s sausages, not to the vindaloo. I absolutely endorse the campaign being run by the minister.

I am advised that a recent incident occurred at Mackay West State School involving an alleged breach of the Workplace Health and Safety Act in relation to the removal of asbestos-containing material. I have also been advised that an allegation of inappropriate procurement practices has been made against a QBuild staff member subsequent to the incident at the school. The member for Mackay has also conveyed his concern about this allegation directly to me. Like the member for Mackay, I take these allegations very seriously and, as these matters are considered operational, I have asked the director-general of the Department of Public Works to engage a wholly independent third party to investigate these allegations and review all the issues, including both the potential breaches of the Workplace Health and Safety Act 2005 and allegations of inappropriate procurement practices. The director-general has requested that this review be undertaken as a matter of urgency. However, I am advised that the timing of the findings will be dependent upon the review and assessment of all relevant information.

As the Minister for Public Works, I demand that QBuild maintains the highest possible standard in every instance where it is called to remove this substance in government buildings. As I have advised this House previously, I have personal experience in both handling this material and what it can do to people in terms of their health. I also expect departmental staff to uphold the strictest code of conduct when dealing with the public and contractors. Let me be absolutely clear about this: if a breach has occurred those responsible will be dealt with to the full extent possible by the Department of Public Works. Let me also reassure members of the House that the incident occurred during school holidays and at no stage were children, teachers or parents in possible harm’s way.

For the past 15 years the Department of Public Works has been charged with the removal and management in situ of asbestos-containing material in government buildings. During that time more than $130 million has been spent making schools, hospitals and office buildings safe for children, teachers, doctors and all government employees and visitors. This government is committed to the removal of asbestos throughout our schools. At all times we strive to deliver best practice in our asbestos removal work methods. I take very seriously any allegation and I assure the member for Mackay that I will follow up on his concerns. When it comes to the removal of asbestos material, I expect the independent investigation initiated by my department to be rigorous and thorough and that we all should expect nothing less.

Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability)
(10.00 am): During the past several months our government has detailed a strong, comprehensive package of measures to protect koalas and their habitat in South-East Queensland. I have released the first of its kind detailed koala habitat mapping for the region. Just this week I called for koala disease research tenders to share in $400,000 in state funding. Next week public comments close on new planning powers for councils. Another crucial component is funding to protect and expand habitat in South-East Queensland. Today I am pleased to launch a new program toward this goal.

To build on our koala habitat program today I can announce a $4 million package to rehabilitate and protect koala habitat in addition to our program of acquisitions. Today I am putting the call out to landholders in koala mapped areas who may wish to use their own block to establish special koala nature refuges under their ownership. The Koala Nature Refuge Program provides landholders with the opportunity to apply for financial assistance to revegetate, rehabilitate and manage koala habitat on their land in priority koala management areas.

Funding is conditional upon entering into a binding, perpetual nature refuge agreement to establish a nature refuge over all or part of their property. The new $4 million Koala Nature Refuge Program will recruit landholders with properties of key strategic value for koalas and help them, technically and financially, rehabilitate that land. It is expected that work will begin rehabilitating our first property in Redlands in coming weeks--a joint project at the Redland sewage treatment plant with council. I want to particularly thank Redlands mayor, Melva Hobson, for the support she and her council officers have shown in providing support for our program of habitat acquisition and rehabilitation.

As members are aware, the consultation on the koala planning laws closes on 28 February. The Department of Environment and Resource Management has received 52 submissions. I encourage all Queenslanders to have their say. Officers from the department are continuing to meet with officers from all SEQ councils, including Moreton Bay and Ipswich, to discuss the new instruments.
Koala protection is everyone’s responsibility. Landholders who work with us to establish a nature refuge will leave a lasting legacy for koalas by safeguarding habitat for future generations.

Hon. PG REEVES (Mansfield--ALP) (Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport)
(10.02 am): The Bligh government is committed to making Queenslanders Australia’s healthiest people. We know that a key to good health is being active. That is why we are proud to invest more funding in sport and recreation than any other state. We want to make sure this investment delivers real benefits for Queenslanders. Last year we undertook a review of sports funding programs to make sure that they effectively meet the needs of Queensland communities.

Today I am pleased to announce a new package of sport and recreation funding programs to deliver more than $138 million to help build new infrastructure and support initiatives that encourage Queenslanders to get involved in sport and recreation. What is more, these programs will create jobs for Queenslanders.

Under the new model, local sport and recreation organisations, councils and schools will be able to apply for funds under four different programs. The programs are aimed at increasing participation, recruiting more volunteers and encouraging disadvantaged communities to get involved in sport and recreation. The amount of funding that sporting clubs can apply for for minor capital works has more than doubled under this model and applications are open to more organisations than ever before.

Today’s announcement will also help deliver more than 500 jobs for Queenslanders over the next three years. This is a win-win for Queensland. The four new programs providing funding over three years include: a $38 million Local Sport and Recreation Jobs Plan to help employ local sport and recreation coordinators; a $51.5 million Sport and Recreation Infrastructure Program; a $27.6 million State Sport and Recreation Organisation Development Program; and an $18 million Active Inclusion Program. There will also be $3 million allocated for industry development.

The federal government’s 2009 Crawford report made the observation that children from middle-class backgrounds dominate club sport. We are determined to address access to sport and recreation so that no child misses out. Under the Active Inclusion Program we will be making funding available for local organisations to encourage disadvantaged groups to participate in sport and recreation.

Funding rounds are due to be released between March and April this year. Workshops will be held throughout the state over the coming months to explain the new programs to sport and recreation groups. I look forward to seeing local groups making the most of these new opportunities to help Queenslanders be active.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Indigenous Trainees and Apprentices, Road Construction
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. CA WALLACE (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads) (10.05 am): The Bligh government is all about jobs and growing strong local economies. We know that in uncertain economic times there are few things more important than jobs and job security. Our road building crews in Main Roads have their hard hats on at hundreds of road construction sites across our great state. While they are working in small towns and communities they are spending money at local shops and businesses, strengthening local economies.

Where does it all begin? In training and education. My department has opened up job opportunities for Indigenous trainees and apprentices in road construction right across our great state. Last year we provided training for around 70 Indigenous trainees in Cape York and Torres Strait. They have used these skills to work on infrastructure projects in their own communities, including sealing almost 40 kilometres of road.

Another initiative, our Education Towards Employment Scholarship Scheme, is helping young Indigenous students complete their year 12 schooling. We are giving them a better, brighter future. The scheme supports young Indigenous kids with leadership potential. It is also about creating role models for other kids. The students get a $5,000 scholarship, mentoring support and in some cases they can take part in work experience with linkages to apprenticeships, traineeships and cadetships. The scheme has been expanded. We are sponsoring 80 students this year. When we started in 1999 there were three student scholarships. Over that time, more than 420 students have successfully completed year 12. More than 2,300 Indigenous youth have applied for scholarships. That is a testament to the success of our program. In South-East Queensland we have got the Constructive Mob. It is about delivering better opportunities for Indigenous people and boosting their numbers in the construction industry. They have had the opportunity to complete a Certificate II in Civil Construction and at the same they have gained valuable hands-on experience on actual road construction sites.The Bligh government looks after all Queenslanders across our great state no matter where they live. We will continue to reach out to young Indigenous kids to give them the skills and education they need to get ahead in life.

Hon. D BOYLE (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships)
(10.07 am): The new Local Government Act 2009, which comes into effect on 1 July, requires councils across Queensland to develop a community plan as part of their overall planning process. This plan clearly sets out the aspirations and priorities of the community. These plans are hands-on, strategic frameworks underpinning the long-term sustainability of councils. They will play an important role in guiding and shaping land use plans, corporate plans and town plans.

Community plans reflect a community’s priorities in a whole range of areas, such as provision of services for seniors, planning for economic opportunities of the future and improved sporting and recreational facilities. Importantly, community plans are built on broad community consultation and engagement ensuring locals have input into their own future. Community plans are an opportunity for councils to think strategically about their entire region as well as ensuring communities with a special identity and special values are retained. Examples of such communities are places like Maleny, Port Douglas, Stanthorpe and Noosa. Having a community plan which demonstrates how the priorities of the residents of such areas are translated into an operational and works plan by the council will no doubt be welcomed by residents.

New Zealand first introduced community plans in 2002, so they have had time to review their implementation. At the end of January, at the invitation of the Local Government Association of Queensland, I travelled to New Zealand with members of LGAQ’s executive and my deputy director-general to see firsthand how community plans are working there. I met with the New Zealand Local Government Minister, Rodney Hide, representatives from the Department of Internal Affairs who are responsible for local government, as well as representatives from Wellington City Council, Masterton District Council and South Wairarapa District Council. Each of those stakeholders bought a different perspective to the community planning discussion--perspectives that reflected the different demographic, geographic, financial and social factors impacting on individual councils.

It is clear that there is no one-size-fits-all approach to community planning. This awareness will definitely guide our implementation of the community planning process here in Queensland. It is important that processes are flexible enough to be useful for the diversity of Queensland’s local councils, from the Diamantina Shire Council to the Bundaberg Regional Council, the Gold Coast City Council and all of the 73 local governments. The local government reform program is evidence of the Bligh government’s continuing commitment to local government and to building a strong Queensland for the future.

Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport) (10.10 am): This morning I rise to clarify some reports regarding the Gold Coast Rapid Transit project as outlined in today’s Gold Coast Bulletin . The Gold Coast Rapid Transit project is a unique nation-building project being delivered by the Queensland government in partnership with the Australian government and the Gold Coast City Council. All of the modelling suggests that without the Gold Coast Rapid Transit project there will be gridlock on the Gold Coast. Therefore, we are undertaking a project that will substantially increase the rate of public transport patronage in that growing part of South-East Queensland. Early works on the first stage of the Gold Coast Rapid Transit project have already started between Griffith University and Broadbeach, and that stage of the project will be operational by 2014. Planning is also underway for the next stage of the project between Griffith University and Helensvale.

Yesterday, on the recommendation of the local member, the Gold Coast City Council and the Gold Coast Rapid Transit team, I approved the H1 option linking Helensvale and Griffith University via the Harbour Town shopping centre. Contrary to reports in the Gold Coast Bulletin this morning, this announcement provides a greater level of certainty for residents. There is now one route to connect Helensvale and Griffith University, not the two that were previously being considered. During consultation in 2006-07, 83 per cent of people surveyed said that they preferred the Harbour Town route option. Early planning indicates that the subject of the news story in the Gold Coast Bulletin , Mr Gordon Taylor, will not be impacted upon by the proposed route.

The next step is for more consultation with residents, along with more detailed planning around engineering and property impacts. Hardship acquisitions will be available for those directly impacted by the route, which was first mooted some years ago. Construction on this stage of project is not expected to start until at least 2014 and residents will be consulted at every step of the way. The Bligh government remains passionately committed not just to building this stage of the Gold Coast Rapid Transit project but also to planning a sustainable public transport system for the Gold Coast’s future.

Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (10.13 am): During the last sitting I was pleased to advise the House that construction of the Airport Link, Northern Busway and airport roundabout upgrade projects were well underway. When complete, Australia’s largest infrastructure project will slash travel times for motorists and public transport patrons in a city currently experiencing some of the country’s worst peak-hour traffic. I am aware that Airport Link construction work is impacting residents near the nine major work sites from Bowen Hills through to Lutwyche, Windsor, Kedron, Clayfield and Toombul. In recent weeks, I have again met with affected residents and heard firsthand the toll this project is taking. I would like to inform residents and the House that the government will continue to take every mitigation measure possible.

The state government will continue to investigate any possible breaches of the independent Coordinator-General’s strict construction conditions, which include noise and light restrictions and spoil truck regulations. If breaches are detected, penalties will follow. I understand the Department of Environment and Resource Management is continuing to monitor project activities to ensure the Coordinator-General’s strict dust restriction conditions are being enforced. An investigation into an incident involving after-hours work at Wooloowin recently led to the Coordinator-General issuing a show-cause notice on 18 January. A warning has also been issued after complaints were received near the Toombul work site. In addition, the Department of Transport and Main Roads has undertaken safety checks on the many vehicles hauling spoil from project sites. This too will continue.

I take this opportunity to inform the residents of Lamington Avenue, Lutwyche, that Airport Link trucks will soon be using an alternative route to reduce noise and other impacts. However, not all impacts can be mitigated. Despite fitting 250 homes with mitigation devices such as air conditioning or double glazing, and the installation of noise walls and acoustic sheds, the state government has purchased or offered to purchase more than 12 extra properties whose owners are finding the impacts too difficult to endure. When complete, this project will slash travel times for the whole Brisbane community. Once again I would like to respectfully thank the residents of the inner north side and ask for their continued patience.

Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (10.16 am): The Office of Fair Trading has joined forces with a Cairns Indigenous consumer group to give remote Far North communities a dedicated person to turn to on consumer issues. The Office of Fair Trading will partner with the Indigenous Consumer Assistance Network, ICAN, and deploy specially trained officers to Yarrabah and Palm Island.

Remote Indigenous communities can often be the target of unscrupulous businesses, due to their isolation and lack of marketplace competitiveness. For example, just last week hundreds of Far North Queenslanders entered into costly and unfair contracts after a household goods rental firm doorknocked local homes. Consumers have extra rights when approached by door-to-door sellers and they also have other options to get household goods without incurring massive debts for years. However, those are the types of things that people might not always be aware of. In this recent case, ICAN was able to pass on information from the affected consumers. The Office of Fair Trading then investigated and got the firm to cancel all 800 of the rental contracts and pay back in excess of $13,000 it had obtained from the residents.

The Office of Fair Trading wants to prevent similar incidents happening in the first place, but recognises the Indigenous community did not traditionally lodge consumer complaints. We need to change this situation, which is why we are training seven ICAN staff in fair trading matters. They will work on the ground within the community and be armed with even more knowledge and skills to help protect the rights of residents and, where necessary, pass on information to the Office of Fair Trading for enforcement action.

The Office of Fair Trading has provided funding for ICAN services for two years as part of its 2009-10 Indigenous strategy. The strategy also includes an Indigenous consumer campaign called Know Your Rights, which will start in March with ads appearing on radio and print publications over the coming months.

The Bligh government is committed to protecting the rights of Indigenous peoples. All the opposition leader and the LNP are doing for Indigenous people is labelling them and their traditions as living fossils, as we will recall. If members want further evidence of that, they need look no further than yesterday’s debate on the preamble to the Constitution.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (10.18 am): I am pleased to announce a trial of new technology to assist the kangaroo industry in Queensland. Currently, kangaroo harvesters use a paper based trace-back system, but overseas markets, including the European Union, are demanding improved traceability. With this in mind, we will conduct field trials on two different identification tags to track kangaroos from the time they are harvested until they arrive at the processing factory. The first trial, supported by $61,000 in state government funding, will use a radio frequency identification device. This sort of technology is already used in Australia to identify casino gambling chips, but this will be the first time it is used for kangaroo and wild game harvesting.

The identification tag is fixed to the animal and records specific information about each kangaroo including time, date and GPS location of harvest. It also has the capability of collecting detail such as the sex and species of kangaroo. The two-month trial will begin in southern Queensland in March this year and will involve Ipswich based Game Meat Processing and a number of local kangaroo harvesters and field depots. DEEDI will supply an economist to look at the true economic advantages. Meantime, Safe Food Production Queensland will trial a tag that uses bar code technology already used in the red meat industry. The tag will capture the time and date from various stages throughout the supply chain.

We want to develop one cost-effective tag that will suit the requirements of all agencies and restore access to overseas markets. As well as improving traceabilities, the tag could potentially cut a lot of paperwork and improve harvesting practices. Industry stakeholders, including harvesters, processors and regulators, are supporting the trial because of the possibilities the tag offers for opening market access and lowering costs. The Bligh government is about supporting industry, protecting and creating jobs and building stronger rural and regional communities. A viable kangaroo industry will help us achieve that goal. I seek leave to table for the benefit of members an example of the radio frequency tag.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Photograph of a kangaroo tag control device.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.21 am): The Bligh government has a demonstrated track record of boosting the number of front-line officers in the Queensland Police Service. Since Labor came to power, the number of police officers in Queensland has skyrocketed by more than 50 per cent, from 6,800 in June 1998 to more than 10,400 today.

Reinforcing our commitment is our promise to employ a minimum of 600 additional front-line officers within the service during this term, and we are delivering on that promise. However, the government and the Police Service have also been able to boost front-line numbers through civilianisation. Employing civilian staff members to undertake tasks which do not require police powers means sworn police officers can be deployed back to the front line of policing. The Queensland Police Service currently employs 275 civilian communications room operators, 100 watch-house officers and 105 station client service officers across the state. That is 480 positions in total.

At one station I visited recently one trained client service officer staffing the front desk had resulted in 19 extra operational police shifts every 28 days. That is 228 shifts per year available for a uniformed officer to work in the community responding to calls and patrolling our streets--clear evidence that civilianisation is paying dividends for the Queensland Police Service and the community at large.

I am pleased to be able to announce today that the Queensland Police Service has identified a further 59 positions across the state where a civilian will be employed, allowing the sworn police officers to be redeployed to front-line services. These positions relate mainly to the functions of communications, watch-houses, station client services and prosecutions. Six of the positions are in the far northern region; five in the northern region; nine in the central region; four in metropolitan north; eight each in metropolitan south, north coast and south-eastern regions; five in the southern region; and four in the state operations command, with two positions still to be allocated.

Trained civilians, under the supervision of sworn police officers, provide a significant resource to policing in Queensland. I congratulate the Police Commissioner and his senior executive for identifying these additional positions for civilianisation as a part of their commitment to keeping Queensland safe.

Hon. KL STRUTHERS (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (10.23 am): The Bligh government is committed to increasing the participation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the Queensland democracy. Yesterday we witnessed the inclusion of the landmark preamble to the Queensland Constitution. Today I am pleased to announce the 2010 Young Indigenous Leaders Forum will be held in Brisbane from 30 May to 5 June, and that will incorporate an Indigenous Youth Parliament. I encourage all members to spot talent in their local area and encourage young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to take up this opportunity to be involved in the Indigenous Youth Parliament.

The Young Indigenous Leaders Forum will support and encourage the development of future Indigenous leaders. It is an important commitment that was made as part of the Premier’s Reconciliation Action Plan. Young participants will learn about the history of our parliament and gain an insight into democracy and the workings of the House. Participants will be taking over Parliament House for a few days. Forty seats will be earmarked for young Indigenous people passionate about making a difference. These young people are the decision makers of the future.

The forum is an important step towards reconciliation and it also supports the ambitions of the Bligh government’s Toward Q2 plan for a fairer Queensland. The inaugural 2009 Indigenous Youth Parliament was inspirational, and I look forward to meeting the 2010 participants. Past participants have said that the Indigenous Youth Parliament was very inspirational and motivating for them. They have been spreading the word around their communities that it is a chance to share stories from their community and learn how to lead. On the day it was held in this chamber I was certainly very moved. I encourage all members not only to spot talent in their local area but to come down and witness these young people in action.

Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport) (10.25 am): The go card is continuing its rollout across the South-East Queensland TransLink network. This week for the first time the go card is expected to be used to make more than two million trips across the TransLink network. Since 4 January, 150,000 go cards have been issued through more than 400 go card retailers across the south east as well, of course, by people ringing 131230 or buying a go card over the net. This is yet another important milestone for our go card, making it the most used smart card in Australia.

The go card is consistently surpassing expectations and forecasts. Since it was rolled out in 2008, more than 72 million trips have been made on a go card and more than $187 million has been loaded on to the smart cards. Today, over half of all public transport trips are taken using a go card and, with students returning to university campuses through this week, it is clear that the record number of customers touching on and off will continue to rise.

These are all encouraging signs because the go card is providing enormous time savings for commuters. If you catch a bus, as almost 400,000 people do each day, it takes three seconds to touch on and off with a go card as opposed to on average 11 seconds to board and pay the driver whilst fishing around for change. Go cards are also increasingly capturing vital information which gives TransLink accurate data on passenger movements which helps to better plan and improve the network. This is a much more cost-effective way to address crowding as TransLink is able to target hot spots down to an individual stop or station level.

It is early days, but this new level of data is already being used to begin improving bus services, such as the additional 20,000 seats a week back-to-uni package that began operating on Monday. Ultimately, a paperless public transport system will deliver information which will help maximise every public dollar and every dollar in fare spent by government and by commuters in the south east.
Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (10.27 am): I give notice that I shall move--

Urges the Premier as the incoming national President of the Australian Labor Party to oppose any move to cancel or postpone the annual State Conference of the Queensland Labor Party.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: School Group Tours; Visitors to Public Gallery
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Visiting Parliament House this morning will be students from Padua College in Kedron in the electorate of Stafford and students from Fairview Heights State School in the electorate of Toowoomba North. Attending seminars today will be Hillcrest College interns meeting with the University of Queensland, Griffith University and the Queensland University of Technology. To make sure that he is on his best behaviour today, the member for Morayfield’s mother and grandmother are in the public gallery.

Mr LANGBROEK (10.30 am): My first question without notice is to the Treasurer. Three days before the state election was called, credit rating agency Standard & Poor’s wrote with concerns about Treasury debt, asking, ‘How does the government plan to address the deteriorating operating position?’ What did the government tell the credit rating agency, and will the Treasurer reveal if and why the government raised privatisation options with the agency before telling Queenslanders?

Mr FRASER: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for the question. The reason the Leader of the Opposition is able to reference meetings that occurred with credit rating agencies is that I provided all of that information to him. The complete government record about the interaction with the credit rating agencies has been provided in full to the Leader of the Opposition under our nation-leading right to information laws. Nevertheless, even though we provided all of that information, he clearly has not read through it all, or if he has--in the world of the LNP conspiracy theory--he wants it to amount to something else. The reality is very clear. Let me go through it again.

This government, unlike any other government in the history of Queensland, published in full the details of the state’s finances before the calling of the last election, as we had committed to do--and as every future government of Queensland will be committed to do if the LNP decides to vote for the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill that sits on the Notice Paper right now. The question is: does the LNP offer support to pass that bill through this parliament and therefore commit itself to what we as a government did, despite the law not providing for it, in providing a full update of the state’s finances?

What did we say to the credit rating agencies, as we have said to them each and every time we have met with them? We go through in detail the state’s finances, and all of that information has been provided to the Leader of the Opposition. Yet again, despite the fact that we have handed it all over, what have opposition members done with it? Have they decided to use it to create one economic policy? Have they decided to look through it to come up with one idea?

What we said to them was that we were committed to making sure we charted a course for the future strength of the state’s finances, and the answer to your question in one word is ‘no’. The reality is that the Leader of the Opposition has been provided with the details of that meeting and therefore he has the evidence of why that is the case.

So the test is this: now that we have provided you with all of that information, now that we have done a great deal of the homework for you, now that we have put it all together, put a dog clip on it and mailed it to you, what are you going to do with it? Are you going to utilise it to come up with one idea or one policy, or are you going to stick to the same old policy that you have always pursued of talking about your wholesale privatisation agenda--it extends to schools, hospitals and far beyond what you have been prepared to admit in the public arena--as you scrunch yourself up into a little ball and pretend that you have no obligation to put forward policies of your own. Now that we have provided him with the homework, it is time for the Leader of the Opposition to do his own work. The reality is that the LNP has not produced one ounce of work and one policy that it would take Queensland forward with.
Mr LANGBROEK: Mate, you are the best actor but the worst ever Treasurer.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: I will wait for the House to come to order.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is to the Minister for Transport. The minister has revealed that she was unaware of the government’s plans to sell Queensland Rail until after those plans were revealed in the media. Will the minister advise when she was first told that her department was planning a Brisbane metropolitan congestion charge for motorists of 30c a kilometre--a congestion charge for motorists on top of registration increases and a new fuel tax?

Ms NOLAN: This government and my department have a comprehensive plan for South-East Queensland and in particular its transport future, and that plan involves these things: building better rail in the outer metropolitan areas of the city, like extending rail to the Gold Coast, down towards the member for Southport’s part of the world--
Mr Stevens interjected.

Ms NOLAN: Southport as well will benefit. The government’s plan involves extending rail to Richlands and it involves building better busways in the inner city, like the Eastern Busway and the Northern Busway, which are currently under construction. The government’s plan involves providing more trains, more buses and more ferries on that public transport network--like, for instance, the 20,000 extra seats that rolled out just this week, starting from Monday. This government’s plan is comprehensive and is being delivered right now.

Further, as has been said on the record before, this government does not plan to introduce a change in pricing such as a congestion charge. We have a comprehensive policy and we are building it and rolling it out right now. I am sure, for instance, that the Minister for Main Roads would be more than happy to tell the House about the comprehensive road elements of the transport plan. The real issue for this House is what the LNP would do. The LNP went to the last election with a nonsensical transport policy. First, the LNP proposed a railway line on the Sunshine Coast which did not join in to the broader network. There will be no--
Ms Simpson interjected.

Ms NOLAN: I just want to respond to the member for Maroochydore’s interjection: there will be no congestion charge. Instead, we have a comprehensive plan to build better public transport and better roads. That is in stark contrast to the LNP, which planned for an unfunded Petrie to Kippa-Ring railway line and a railway line on the Sunshine Coast which does not join up.
Mr WATT: My question is to the Premier. Could the Premier please update the House on her government’s latest initiatives to give kids a flying start to their reading?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for his question. I know how much he enjoys reading with his own son, George, and how much he understands that reading is a critical obligation of parenthood. We know that research shows that reading just one book a day--just one small children’s book a day--to a child can have a very positive impact on their literacy and on their development. We know that children’s brains develop very rapidly in their early years, so there are endless chances for them to learn new skills. It is those early years when we have to set the foundations.

Literacy and numeracy start at home. In our schools, we want to see the literacy and numeracy performance of our students boosted. That is why the Minister for Education, his department and the other sectors of schooling are all putting extra effort into literacy and numeracy initiatives, with extra resources into schools, particularly those that need it most.

But we also know that the efforts of our schools will be significantly improved if what happens for children before they come to school can have a focus on learning and on literacy. That is why the A flying start for Queensland children discussion paper which the minister and I launched starts with the basics, and it starts with a focus on the early years. We know from the first comprehensive national survey ever done of early childhood development in Australia, which was published near the end of last year, that around 70 per cent of Australian parents are regularly reading to their children at home. Unfortunately, for a range of reasons, that figure is somewhat lower in Queensland, with 61 per cent of parents on average reading to their children at home. We want to see that figure lifted. I want to see more Queensland parents than any other state reading to their children.

We also know that increasingly parents right across Australia are very busy. We know that there are more and more families in which both parents are in the workforce, either full time or part time, and that often makes the responsibilities of parenting a very big juggle for people. That is why we think it is time to be out there in the public arena promoting the importance of reading.

Mr Speaker, you will see this week the start of a major social marketing campaign on the importance of reading for parents. It will be accompanied in Townsville, in the central Fraser Coast area and Toowoomba with a campaign to kick-start our reading volunteer program in schools. Every single one of these initiatives links with the next--getting it right at home, then putting in kindies which meet up with the prep year, then having literacy and numeracy initiatives in our classrooms. It is a connected continuum. Every single part of it is important in terms of getting the results we want for our children. We want our children to have a flying start, and it is programs like this that will deliver it.

Ms SIMPSON: My question is to the Minister for Transport. I refer to Connecting SEQ 2031 and transport department planning documents which propose a 30c per kilometre Brisbane congestion tax. Why does the plan assume that in Brisbane by 2031 the number of car trips will decrease from 2.7 million trips a day to 2.4 million? What would cause such a decrease if Labor had not already secretly committed to imposing a congestion tax on motorists?

Ms NOLAN: It is governments that make decisions, it is members of the cabinet who set the direction, and this government will not introduce a congestion charge. What this government will do is build better public transport and a better road network in South-East Queensland and right across the state. That is what we are doing right now. There are workers right now who are building a better public transport network. Do you know why they are doing it, Mr Speaker? They are doing it because this government has decided that that is our priority and this government has funded that infrastructure which creates those jobs which makes for a better quality of life for these people who live in this state right now. That is the decision that this government has made.

Where would we be if the LNP had fallen over the line at the last election? I can tell you where we would be, Mr Speaker. There would be some sort of chaos about how exactly it is that you construct a railway line on the Sunshine Coast that does not join up with the broader network. We would have got past the election and all the people who live around Redcliffe would have realised that, when the member for Maroochydore went up there in the first week of the last election campaign and promised them that she would deliver the much vaunted Redcliffe railway line, she did not mean it. With an asterisk and in small print she meant, ‘Maybe only if things go okay with the global financial crisis’, ‘Subject to the global financial crisis.’ That is where we would be.

This government makes the decisions. Our decision is to build a better public transport network. We make tough economic decisions in order to keep doing that, and this stands in very stark contrast to those opposite whose only economic plan was to cut services and jobs, and whose transport plan in many respects did not even join up.

Mrs ATTWOOD: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier please detail to the House how the hard decisions taken by the government over the past year are helping to build a strong state for the future?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. I think it is important for us to acknowledge what has happened in the Queensland economy over the last 12 months. This time last year we faced the most dire of circumstances, along with the Australian economy and many jurisdictions around the world. Our government has put in place some tough decisions, and they are starting to repay benefits and dividends for the people of Queensland.

In just 12 months what we have experienced is now six months of consecutive job creation--more than 18,000 jobs created in the last six months. Employment figures are starting to turn around. We expected unemployment to peak this year at at least 6 per cent. It is now down to 5.8 per cent. As the Treasurer outlined yesterday, the gross state product for the September quarter saw growth of one per cent. Importantly, predictions from Access Economics are that the Queensland economy will grow at a rate of 2.7 per cent this financial year--faster than the national rate of one per cent.

Why is that working? It is working because we made the decision to keep building. What did that decision mean? It meant that we kept jobs and we kept skills in our economy. Those skills and those jobs are driving the beginnings of economic recovery. Some of the things we are building have been outlined this morning by the Minister for Transport. We are not only building big projects in the transport sector that are providing jobs when we need it most but also putting in place transport facilities in the south-east and in other parts of the state that will drive productivity in the economy this year, next year and the year after.

I note a number of questions this morning in relation to future transport planning. In relation to current thinking in the government around transport planning, let me say that the documents that are being referred to this morning are documents that have been developed by some people in the department of transport. Let us talk about what the government did with those documents. I required those documents to be brought to cabinet so that government could make a decision on them. You know what we decided? We decided not to adopt the recommendations. We said, ‘This is not good enough. We will not accept this advice. We do not support a congestion charge.’
Mr Springborg: But you said you weren’t going to kick Queenslanders when they were down with a fuel tax.
Mr Lucas: But you said you weren’t going to privatise. The hand is on the chin for effect.

Ms BLIGH: That chiselled, thinking look. Let me be absolutely clear and put it beyond any doubt: there will be no congestion charging by the state government for as long as this government is on this side of the House.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading. I refer to the minister’s responsibility to protect Queenslanders from Labor’s deadly Home Insulation Program. Will the minister tell the House how many shonky installers have been prosecuted, how many house fires have been linked to shonky installation and how many of the 1,000 Australian homes with deadly electrified roofs are in Queensland?

Mr LAWLOR: I thank the honourable member for the question. With regard to the reports that we see in the media, the Commonwealth Department of Environment, Water Heritage and the Arts is responsible for the administration of the homeowner and insulation protection program. It is part of its $4.5 billion package that aims to improve the energy efficiency of Australian homes, as we are aware. The situation is that on 19 February 2010--a few weeks ago--the federal government announced the closure of the home insulation and hot water rebate schemes. As part of the ongoing consumer protection role, the Queensland Office of Fair Trading receives and considers complaints against insulation installers. A memorandum of understanding between the Office of Fair Trading and the Commonwealth Department of Environment, Water Heritage and the Arts has been established to enable the Office of Fair Trading to provide details of complaints received against registered insulation installers to that department.

The Office of Fair Trading has finalised 208 complaints regarding insulation since January 2009. Those complaints received by the Office of Fair Trading cover a broad spectrum of consumer issues, as members would expect. They include simple requests for assistance to obtain refunds, repairs, replacement and warranty issues, complaints about installers including the workmanship involved with installation and approaches made by traders offering to install products. The cost has also been an issue. There have been allegations the installers were overcharging in order to collect a full rebate. There were also concerns raised about safety issues, in particular regarding downlights and foil insulation. They amounted to five complaints. Details of all complaints, including those five complaints, have been provided to the federal Department of the Environment, Water, Heritage and the Arts or referred to the appropriate regulatory agencies where they are involved.

Ms JARRATT: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Can the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health please advise the House of the need for strong policy development to tackle the serious challenges in health?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. I have indicated before that one of the great challenges we have in health is an ageing population and the ever-increasing expectations of that ageing population. For example, off the top of my head, in 1984-05 we did about 32,000 hip and knee replacements in Australia. About 12 years later we did 72,000. In that period I do not think anyone could suggest that people’s knees and hips got worse. The expectation of people for surgery and those sorts of things increases, as it necessarily will, over time because we want to provide better and better outcomes.

We heard the Premier this morning talk about a very exciting new initiative in education--that is, voluntary reading to children. What we say with that important initiative is that we want parents, grandparents and others to read to kids on a voluntary basis in our schools. We do not want them to take over the job of teachers or principals. They have a very important professional job to do. We want them to assist as volunteers.

One of the areas where we are committed to real action is the area of mental health. Mental illness or chronic ill-health is not the leading killer of people in Australia, but it is one of the leading areas when it comes to lost wages or lost time from work. We have a mental health plan. We take our mental health and wellbeing very seriously. We have invested in a 10-year plan. Since July 2007, $617.43 million has been invested in community mental health. We have funded 422 extra equivalent positions in nursing and allied health, 65 medical officers and 93 technical, operational and support staff.

But who could forget the last election and the wonderful volunteer policy of the opposition. It was that we will have volunteers in mental health dealing with mental health records. That was one of its purlers. That was up there in the pantheon of LNP policies with the railway line that did not connect into anything and the asterisk. We have the member for Caloundra and his absolute purler--mental health records, the most sensitive things we can have, being maintained by volunteers.

One of the things about volunteering is that you have to opt in. The opposition does not know much about opting in but it knows a hell of a lot about opting out. We have the Leader of the Opposition, who is no doubt the weakest Leader of the Opposition in the time that I have been here, opting out of a reshuffle that he promised to do. He has opted out of taking action against the member for Moggill, the member for Noosa and--who was the other one in it--the member for Mermaid Beach, the little water, the little mermaid water. But he took action against the member for Burnett and the member for Beaudesert. He opted out of any policy platform despite the fact that he said it. He opted out of a reshuffle despite the fact that he said that he would do it before Christmas. Worst of all, he opted out of any role for liberalism in the parliamentary Liberal Party in this state. There is no liberalism, there is no freedom of thought in his party and no policy either.
Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to--
Mr Lucas interjected.
Mr McArdle interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Caloundra and the Deputy Premier. Now we will hear from the member for Clayfield.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Treasurer. I refer to the Australia-wide mass sacking of insulation workers by the Labor Party. Treasurer, exactly how many Queenslanders were sacked or are about to be sacked by Labor, and what is the tally for jobs lost in Queensland as a result of the cancellation of the scheme?

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow Treasurer for his question and for his feigned concern for the interests of working people in Queensland. The reality is that given the decisions that have been made by the Commonwealth there are obviously ramifications that will occur in that industry. The federal government has been clear about the fact, for instance, that it will provide $10 million in support to those workers as any decent Labor government would do. Secondly, it has also indicated, through its employment participation minister, that it will be fast-tracking support to affected workers not only in Queensland but right around Australia. That is the responsible course of action for a Labor government to undertake when a decision such as this arises. It is a response that has been pursued by the federal Labor government at a national level.

However, to walk into this chamber and to feign concern for the interests of workers shows the rank hypocrisy of the LNP. What we see, of course, in the last couple of weeks, just as the shadow Treasurer now seeks to cuddle up to the cause of workers’ rights, is the Leader of the Opposition federally seeking to recuddle up to the concept of Work Choices. The reality is this. What we see from the Liberals federally and what we see from the LNP at a state level is an absolute commitment to the same old failed policies of the past.

So the real question for the shadow Treasurer is this: where does he stand on bringing back Work Choices?
