Where does the shadow Treasurer stand on bringing back the worst parts of Work Choices--the single biggest attack on the interests and the rights of working people around Queensland and indeed around the nation? When he comes in here and sets out his policy position on what he believes in terms of bringing back Work Choices and opposes those most heinous parts of Work Choices which have been put back on the agenda by Tony Abbott as opposition leader, then he has every right to feign concern for the interests of the workers of Queensland. He has no right to feign concern for the interests of working people, just as all other members of the LNP in this chamber do not, until he states his position on bringing back Work Choices.

What are we doing? We are making sure that we have an industrial relations system that supports workers. What are we doing? We are providing support, like our $101 million commitment to the Skilling Queenslanders for Work initiative, to get people in work and keep people in work. Our new $10 million JobsAssist program has helped nearly 1,000 businesses in this state to help people stay in work. What is this government committed to doing? Making the tough choices to fund employment programs, to put forward industry development programs, to run schemes that support new and emerging industries. We have the courage to make the decisions, to make the choices and to support working people in this state. I just say to the workers of Queensland: watch what these folk are up to and ask them where they stand on bringing back Work Choices.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides will come to order.

Mr MOORHEAD: My question is also to the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development. Can the Treasurer update the House on the government’s employment programs which are assisting Queenslanders get back into the workforce?

Mr FRASER:
I thank the member for Waterford for his question and for his interest in the Skilling Queenslanders for Work initiative--our $101 million commitment that we maintain to help Queenslanders break into the workforce. I know that it is program that he has a strong personal interest in in his local area. He puts the time and effort into making sure that those Queenslanders who need the assistance of government can get access to that assistance.

Right now a number of success stories are being featured on regional television through the Win network--success stories from our Get Set for Work program, like Emiliese Anderson, who has broken into the labour market in Cairns for the first time with the assistance of the Queensland government’s employment programs. I refer to success stories like Clinton ‘Cuz’ Woodbridge from Goondiwindi who has got his dream job--‘Cuz’ has got his dream job--as a police liaison officer with support and assistance in the literacy program that has helped him secure employment and helped him chart a course for not only himself but indeed his future family.

Those are the success stories that we are interested in as we make the tough decisions to keep funding the employment programs that support Queenslanders who need it. But of course what I remain committed to is finding out the alternatives being offered by the opposition. So imagine my anticipation when I came across an article in that journal of record the Northern Downs News in the last couple of days titled ‘Shadow treasurer casts light on future’. The anticipation built but quickly deflated. I read the first paragraph, which starts with--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Politicians were thick--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: and perhaps they should have stopped there--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: on the floor at Dalby Golf Club, when Ray Hopper MP hosted Shadow Treasurer Tim Nicholls MP and--
Senator Barnaby Joyce--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: at not a policy forum but I go on to read--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: at a social evening on Tuesday.
XML.Hansard-Body: I know the shadow Treasurer has been struggling with the company he has had to keep in here in the last couple of weeks, but even I was pretty surprised that he would choose to haul around on the northern downs with the member for Condamine and Senator Barnaby Joyce just waiting for a tidbit of wisdom or a tidbit of policy to drop off the table from Senator Joyce about what it might take to run the economy of Queensland in the future.

But my anticipation was well placed, because he did propose an idea. The shadow Treasurer has come up with an idea: he thinks the state of Queensland needs to establish a ‘sovereign well fund’. I am prepared to give him the benefit of the doubt that he actually meant ‘sovereign wealth fund’, but the big news flash is this: in 1991 this parliament authorised the creation of QIC, a sovereign wealth fund, which you can find on the internet in reports on sovereign wealth funds. Or if you do not want to read those, you can even go to--would you believe?--sovereign funds central and find QIC listed. The reality is that they need to come up with a policy, because this article does not quite cut the mustard.

Mr SEENEY: My question without notice is to the Treasurer and Minister for Employment. When the Premier announced her election commitment of 200,000 solar hot-water systems, she promised it would create 500 jobs. Can the Treasurer advise how many jobs have been lost and what is the government’s response for the tradesmen and contractors who have lost work because of the collapse of this failed election promise?

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow minister for his question and for his concern in ensuring that this government continues to support programs that not only support industries of the future like solar hot water and LNG but do so in a way that creates skills for the future workers of Queensland. Our commitment to running these programs remains unchanged. However, the reality--as the Minister for Energy has been clear, as the Premier has been clear and indeed as all members of the cabinet have been clear--is that the changes that were decided upon by the federal government last Friday do present challenges for us and the institution of our program. We are presently dealing with those issues.

The reality is that this government remains committed to its election commitment on delivering a Solar Hot Water Program, and we remain committed to delivering a Solar Hot Water Program because not only is it good for developing a new industry and not only is it good for creating jobs of the future but also it is providing a tangible benefit to those people who get the benefit of this program, not only in terms of their carbon footprint but most importantly in making sure that their energy bills are reduced. That is why we remain utterly committed to ensuring that we deliver a program that supports the solar hot-water industry in this state. What we want to see is this industry grow into the future.

What we have not seen from the opposition is any identification that it would fund this program or indeed any other program, because it remains committed to the old days. When it was last in government, what did it do in terms of employment programs? We all remember that former minister for employment Santo Santoro abolished the department of employment. So committed to job creation is it that its record is that it abolished the employment department. So committed is it to job creation in this state, as all members on this side of the House know, that the current status of the jobs target the LNP has in this state is zero--right there beside how many policies it has put forward, and that is zero. Until those opposite come in here and disown the old policies of job cuts, as they remained committed to in the weekend’s press, until they come in here and put forward a proposition about what they would do and until they come in here and put forward a positive plan for what choices they would make--the decisions they would make--then their feigned concern in here is seen through by every member of this chamber and those watching from outside.

While they are sitting down doing nothing and creating no policies, their do-nothing plan condemns this state to an extra $25 billion of debt. Until they can confront the reality of making choices, making decisions and putting forward policies, then the idea that these are the people to chart a course for the future of Queensland to concentrate on providing job opportunities is one that is seen through by everyone in this chamber and everyone outside.

Ms STONE: My question is to the Minister for Main Roads. With millions of motorists driving on South-East Queensland motorways every day, can the minister please advise the House what steps are being taken to help keep our state-of-the-art motorways clean and tidy?

Mr WALLACE: I thank the honourable member for Springwood for her question. She is a regular user of our motorways, as is the member for Albert. I constantly get comments from motorists about the rubbish on our motorways. I wish I had better news, but, unfortunately, motorists are continuing to dump rubbish on our motorways. We embarked on a major clean-up campaign across our motorways in South-East Queensland earlier this year. We put on extra crews after the peak Christmas holiday period, one of the busiest times on our roads. They have picked up everything from fast-food wrappings to glass, plastic bottles and car parts--even furniture and old fridges. We have had a number of work crews, made up of people doing community service to pay off their fines, out there cleaning up debris and removing rubbish from our motorways.

It costs around $1 million a year to keep our motorways in tiptop shape, but every dollar spent removing rubbish from our motorways is a dollar that is not being spent on our roads and road safety. Motorists in Brisbane threw away more than 2,000 cubic metres of garbage onto our motorways last year. That is almost enough to fill an Olympic sized swimming pool. It is just not good enough. Around 1,500 cubic metres of mess was removed from the M1 alone last year. More than $1.6 million was spent on rubbish removal in the Main Roads north coast region last financial year. Of that, around $600,000 was spent on cleaning up the National Highway and more than $1 million on other state controlled roads in the region. More than $820,000 was spent last financial year removing rubbish and debris along the M1 between the member’s electorate of Springwood and Tugun on the Gold Coast.

Our road crews continually clean up South-East Queensland motorways so that all road users can travel on our roads safely. But today I urge motorists who throw caution to the wind, and everything else out the window, to think twice before littering our motorways. It is an offence by law and it is an offence to the majority of responsible motorists who also travel on our state’s roads and who do the right thing. Not only that, the money spent on clean-up costs--money that could be better spent upgrading our existing roads and networks and improving safety for Queenslanders--is wasted. If you are using our motorways, please ensure that you keep your rubbish inside the car. That way, we can have better roads.

Mr HOBBS: My question is to the Minister for Local Government. I refer to the statement today from the CEO of the Sunshine Coast Regional Council that hundreds of council jobs must go due to Labor’s forced amalgamations. What is the government doing to help those Sunshine Coast workers to support their families?

Ms BOYLE: I thank the member for the question. It is a question that I am very pleased to answer, because thank heavens for the Bligh government and the deal struck with the unions, with the LGAQ and with the LGMA to protect local government jobs during the transition to amalgamations. We did not know at the time that that deal was struck that we were shortly to face the global financial crisis, with the huge pressure that has come to bear on employment in communities around Queensland.

That local government jobs are protected through to March 2011 is undoubtedly providing some considerable comfort to all of those families who might otherwise fear that they would be on the unemployment market and competing for too short a supply of jobs in our current economy. Nonetheless, I understand that the CEO has said that, with the amalgamation on the Sunshine Coast, it has become apparent, in particular in middle management, that there are too many workers and that after the period whereby they were forced through the arrangements made by our Bligh government to keep employees there will be a review, as I understand it at the 2011-12 budget, of the job needs for the Sunshine Coast council. I respect that that is the CEO’s opinion. He is an excellent CEO. I also respect that he is giving his community fair warning of the circumstances that will arrive some 15 months from now. So the Bligh government has provided that comfort to workers in the local government field.

Let us talk a little bit more about the Sunshine Coast council. Yesterday, I was pleased to see the mayor of the Sunshine Coast, Bob Abbot, along with many other mayors from around Queensland who are on the executive of the LGAQ, who came to meet with the Premier and me. Other councils that were represented at the meeting included the Bundaberg Regional Council--and I pay my regards to Mayor Lorraine Pyefinch--and other councillors who attended included Les Tyrell. There is no doubt that those mayors and their councils have stepped up to the challenge of amalgamation. And how! They have kept the jobs running. They have tackled it, even if it was not their personal view that the amalgamation should occur, absolutely strategically. They are saving money through the amalgamations and are honestly reflecting that while at the same time talking to our government about the challenges ahead. Yesterday at that meeting a new beginning in the partnership was struck with Bob Abbot and the Sunshine Coast council and the other councils represented on the executive and the LGAQ.

Mr RYAN: Mr Speaker, I firstly join with you in welcoming members of my family to the chamber today. I am sure they will tell you that I am always on my best behaviour. My question is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. Could the minister advise of the number of jobs generated by the Capital Works Program since the election and what the effect of a capital works freeze would be?

Mr SCHWARTEN: I thank the honourable member for his question and acknowledge to his mother and grandmother what a fine member of parliament he is and how a true Labor person in this place is concerned about jobs. We know on this side of the House that the best thing a Labor government can do is provide security for families by employment. That is the cornerstone of a Labor government and it separates us greatly from those who sit opposite. If you go back in history--back to 1929--what did the tories do when they got elected?
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SCHWARTEN: They can try to dismiss this. They stopped every capital works project in Queensland. What happened when the Borbidge government got elected? Things got a bit tough. There was a capital works freeze, $500 million, people out of work and high unemployment in Queensland. That is their way and that distinguishes us from them. Leopards do not change their spots and tories do not change their ways.

The reality is this: since we have come to government, if you go around to any of the electorates--for example, if you go to Cairns--you will hear the members representing the electorates in the Cairns area talking about the hospital there and the jobs that has created. You will hear them talk about the number of people in the other industries that are supported, such as at Lotus Glen that is up the road and all the subcontractors from Cairns who are up there. If you go to Townsville you will hear the members representing electorates in the Townsville area talk about what is happening at the hospital and the thousands of jobs that have been created. If you go to Mackay you will hear the member for Mackay talking about it. If you go to Rockhampton, you will hear the member representing that area talking about it and you will hear the member for Keppel talking about it as well. If you go to Maroochydore, what do you hear? Nothing. You would swear that there is nothing happening there. There is a $92 million government office building being built there, creating 640 jobs. Do we ever hear the member representing that area promoting it? Never, ever. If you come to Brisbane and talk to the member who asked the question--
Mr Wendt: Gatton.

Mr SCHWARTEN:
I was just about to get to Gatton. I am glad the honourable member is enthusiastic. Last week he came out there. Where is the ‘Lightning from Lockyer’? There he is. What is he worried about? Is he worried about jobs? No, he is worried about what we should call the Gatton prison.
Mr Rickuss: I’m worried about the community services in my area. That’s what I’m worried about.

Mr SCHWARTEN: He is not worried about the 3,000-odd jobs that are out there. He is not worried about the jobs that are created. He says there are no jobs. He did not want the prison in the first place and now all he is worried about is what we are going to call it.
Mr Rickuss: What about the railway workshops in Ipswich and Rockhampton?

Mr SCHWARTEN: Six hundred jobs. I was there last week. What can he do? The poor unfortunate man. It has finally overtaken him. Finally, the disease has got to him. He is just sitting there muttering his own irrelevance. The reality is this: this government cares about jobs, not job freezes.
Mr Seeney: I just love those billboards in Rockhampton.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I do, too. They get me a vote every day.

Mr STEVENS: My question is to the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading. in a phone hook-up on 29 April 2009, officials from the Queensland Office of Fair Trading were warned about the federal government’s insulation scheme and the likelihood of unregistered operators and shonky operators leading to a forecast 10 per cent failure rate in the program. I ask: why did the minister not take any action on this warning to protect the lives of three young Queensland workers that could have been saved if he had launched immediate action?

Mr LAWLOR: I thank the member again for his question. I can only go through the information. I am unaware of the phone call that the member refers to. I can only go through the information that I have already provided, and that is basically that this is a federal government scheme. It was abolished as of 19 February, but it will be replaced by a new household Renewal Energy Bonus Scheme under which households will receive a $1,000 rebate. As part of the ongoing consumer protection role, the Queensland Office of Fair Trading receives and considers complaints against insulation installers. A memorandum of understanding exists between the Office of Fair Trading and the Commonwealth department to provide details of complaints received against the registered installers to that department. It is a federal government scheme.

The Office of Fair Trading has finalised 208 complaints regarding insulation since January 2009. Those complaints received by the Office of Fair Trading related to a multitude of issues, simple requests for assistance for refunds, complaints about installers’ workmanship, costs, allegations that installers were overcharging and also issues relating to safety. Details of those complaints are provided to the federal department. It is a federal government scheme.

The scheme commenced on 1 July 2009. The Office of Fair Trading has received 208 complaints since 1 January. Six months before the scheme came into being, 27 complaints were received regarding insulation. In the 7 months since the scheme commenced, there were 181 complaints regarding insulation. Of those insulation complaints, since 1 January--that is, before the scheme started--17 indicated some type of safety concern and of those six did not actually identify a safety matter. Six complaints, which consisted of consumer perception that the product or its installation may have been unsafe, were not correct. Five complaints actually indicated a safety concern. All five that indicated an actual safety concern were referred specifically to the federal department. One of those complaints involved a consumer who alleged that they had been electrocuted as a result of the insulation. That consumer had already lodged a complaint with the relevant Queensland government agency, the Department of Justice and Attorney-General.

The unfortunate deaths of Queensland insulation installers by electrocution are matters being investigated by the Electrical Safety Office and Workplace Health and Safety in the Department of Justice and Attorney-General.

Ms CROFT: My question is to the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading. Will the minister please tell the House how important the international market briefings held this week in Cairns and on the Gold Coast are for tourism?

Mr LAWLOR: I thank the member for the question. On Monday and Tuesday this week Tourism Queensland regional directors who look after Queensland’s key international markets, including Japan, the UK, New Zealand, North America, Europe, China, the Middle East, India and South-East Asia, travelled to Cairns and the Gold Coast from around the world to update the local tourism industries on the latest trends and issues affecting their markets.

From all reports, international travel in Queensland is looking up for 2010. The briefings give Tropical North Queensland and Gold Coast tourism operators market intelligence on Queensland’s key international tourism markets in 2010 straight from the horse’s mouth, effectively. There is a big year ahead of us, coming out of the global financial crisis and on the back of positive aviation news for Cairns and the Gold Coast in recent months. Feedback from our international markets is that things are looking positive for 2010, with a gradual return of consumer confidence. Earlier this month AirAsia X increased daily services between Kuala Lumpur and the Gold Coast. In addition, Tourism Queensland launched a $400,000 international tourism marketing campaign in early February encouraging Kiwis to cross the ditch. As part of the campaign this week, Tourism Queensland’s New Zealand office has been hosting some of New Zealand’s top radio presenters on the Gold Coast showing them the sights, sounds and exciting holiday experiences.

In the year to September 2009 the Gold Coast received 794,000 international visitors who spent more than a billion dollars on their trips. Tropical North Queensland received 667,000 international visitors who spent $919 million on their trips. Tourism is a major driver for the Tropical North and the Gold Coast economies. It is most important, now more than ever, that our industry works together.

These market briefings are an important tool in enabling our operators to meet Tourism Queensland’s international regional directors and help them gain vital market intelligence. I would like to know what sort of intelligence there is in the LNP. They still have no policy on tourism. The only policy they have is to cut $12 million from the QIIS program and cut 12,000 jobs, which would have an adverse effect on various areas of the economy, including tourism.

Mr FOLEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Education. In light of the recent tragic events and other instances of children bringing knives to schools, what system has the minister put in place to ensure that students will remain in a safe environment whilst at school?

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for this very important question. It is a very serious issue, and the challenges around it are shared equally by all three school sectors--that is, ensuring that we have the safest possible environment for our young children to be learning in a positive, creative and stimulating educational situation.

The systems apply differently in the three school sectors. We in the state school sector, Education Queensland, have a very rigorous state-wide behaviour management policy that applies in each school. It is in the hands of the principal and the staff to ensure it is rigorously and thoroughly implemented. It is complemented by a code of good behaviour that is developed at the school level in consultation with the school P&C and the broader school community and, indeed, within state education. I requested late last year, in the fourth quarter, that the behaviour management plans be updated and reviewed. That is in the process of being concluded across the 1,245 state schools, to ensure they adopt high community expectations about appropriate behaviour in schools.

Make no mistake: this government--and I am sure all members here join with me--will not tolerate violence and inappropriate behaviour not only in state schools but in all schools. We will take all steps across the three school sectors to ensure that message is carried strongly to all students and to the broader community. As we know, there are some parents who do not respect high standards of behaviour in their interaction with schools and with teachers.

So important is this issue that we have set up, as was announced by the Premier and me yesterday, a very significant initiative--that is, an alliance across the three school sectors against student school violence. That alliance has the most senior people from the three sectors working together with senior representatives of all the key stakeholders, accessing Queensland Police, Child Safety and Communities. The key purpose of this is to identify where each school sector is carrying out world’s best practice and is implementing or has in practice right now good policies around violence in schools, bullying and cyberbullying. I look forward to a good report from this alliance.

Mr WETTENHALL: My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland. Could the minister please update the House on plans to update our knowledge of the state’s recreational fishing industry?

Mr MULHERIN: I thank the honourable member for the question. The honourable member knows the value of the recreational and commercial fishing sectors to the tourism industry, particularly in Cairns, which is a great mecca for people who gather there for both their recreational pursuits and the fine food that the commercial fishermen catch.

With more than 700,000 people pursuing recreational fishing each year, we need new information about participation and what the catch is. To help determine the true worth of recreational fishing, more than 4,000 recreational fishers will take part in a telephone survey later this year. The survey will target a cross-section of Queenslanders for a period of 12 months. The last state-wide survey was conducted in 2004-05. What we need now is a more up-to-date picture so that we can be more informed in our policy areas.

In the previous survey, 3,000 people participated using logbooks, but we will make it easier by using a telephone survey. We are investing over $500,000 in this survey. What the survey in 2004-05 showed was that there was a decline in recreational fishing, but this was a trend worldwide. What we do know is that since that period the environment in Queensland has changed dramatically. The population has grown by over 500,000 people since 2005, technology has produced better fishing methods and significant development has occurred in the coastal areas from the New South Wales border right up to Cairns.

The state-wide survey in 2010-11 will focus on participation rates, where people fish and what people catch. In addition to that, we will finetune the data by conducting surveys at boat ramps which will provide finer detail. There is a definite advantage in carrying out the research in this way. The telephone interviewers will contact the participants on a regular basis, recording all their fishing activity. This same method of survey is internationally recognised. The jurisdictions of Tasmania, South Australia and the Northern Territory are participating in a similar approach.

For the first time, we have actually put a dollar value on the recreational sector. For 2009 we believe that the recreational sector was worth about $350 million to $420 million a year to the Queensland economy. That supports thousands of jobs across Queensland. We want to promote recreational fishing, protect jobs and ensure that recreational fishing is sustainable.

Mrs STUCKEY: My question is to the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading. In light of the minister’s statement that he was unaware of the phone hook-up of 29 April 2009 warning of an anticipated 10 per cent failure in the home insulation scheme rate, will the minister undertake to report to this House within 24 hours the action taken by his department to protect Queensland workers’ and householders’ lives?
Mr SPEAKER: Minister, you have one minute.
Mr LAWLOR: I am happy to report back to the House.
Mr SPEAKER: The time for questions has expired.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Notice of Motion; Australian Labor Party State Conference
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: The Leader of the Opposition has today given notice of a motion that is, in my view, unorthodox. It is unorthodox because it seeks to have the House express an opinion on a matter relating to the Premier, not in her capacity as a minister or member, but as president of a political party. I have considered whether a motion on such a subject is permissible or out of order.

I note that questions to a minister about personal matters or about matters pertaining to their capacity as a member of a party are generally out of order, because they do not relate to the public affairs for which the minister is officially connected or to any matter of administration for which the minister is responsible. A notice of motion, on the other hand, is merely an incomplete motion, a proposal.

It is for the House to determine whether it will agree to the proposition. As long as the motion, if agreed to, would not offend the law and the notice is internally logical, coherent, and contains only facts necessary and able to be authenticated, it should not be interfered with. Therefore, the matter will be left to the House.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Further Answer to Question; Traffic Management
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (11.31 am), by leave: I rise to make some further comments in relation to a document that was mentioned during question time. The document is called Connecting SEQ 2031. The existence of this document is well known. In fact, I think it was referred to in the editorial of the Courier-Mail this week. This is the planning document that the state government is working on with local councils in South-East Queensland to develop a better integrated transport plan for the south-east corner. As one would expect in the development of such a plan, a broad range of options are being canvassed by all involved. Also as one would expect, every possible issue is being explored and advice is being provided to government. This project has been led by the state government in partnership with the Council of Mayors. It was first put to the Council of Mayors in May 2008 and the Council of Mayors agreed that each affected council would second a council officer to the project. The project team represents good practice in terms of planning between state and council officers.
Let me address a couple of things about the document. Firstly, is this a secret document? I note that the document that the member for Maroochydore referred to--
Mr Fraser: I note she didn’t table it.
Ms BLIGH: I note it has not been tabled and I seek leave to do so now.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Regional Coordination Committee, document titled ‘Vision for Transport in South East Queensland, Connecting SEQ 2031--‘An Integrated Regional Transport Plan for SEQ’, 3 December 2009.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Ms BLIGH:
This document was the subject of a presentation at the regional coordinating committee at which mayors Councillor Campbell Newman, John Brent, Paul Pisasale, Allan Sutherland and Bob Abbot were all present. A very open conversation was had. Does it represent government policy? I would draw the attention of members to a number of features of the document. What does it say at the bottom of just about every page? It is little wonder this document was not tabled, because it says ‘draft, not government policy’. Another page refers to ‘hypothetical strategy options’.

I can confirm for the House that cabinet has considered a preliminary draft of the document. Cabinet has ruled out and rejected any cordon charging, cordon tolling or congestion charging. I expect that cabinet will consider a number of versions of this document before it is finalised for a lengthy process of public consultation. I thank the Minister for Transport for the work that she is doing and for bringing this document to cabinet. This is part of the normal process of planning. We simply cannot get the planning for South-East Queensland transport right unless we work with the councils of South-East Queensland. We will do that in partnership because, unlike those opposite, this government will build the infrastructure needed today and tomorrow.

Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.35 am): Today I rise to speak to the growing concern of violence in our schools. This is something that the LNP takes extremely serious and, as I have said previously, it is something that we believe should be addressed in a bipartisan way. Yesterday in this House, the Premier stood up to grandstand on the issue of school violence, but instead of taking action she chose to do nothing. Last week, I offered to work with the government on ways in which we can reduce violence in our schools. Sadly, that offer was turned down. Yesterday we saw nothing more than another exercise in spin.

In 2006, the Youth Violence Task Force was set up to address very similar issues as to those to be addressed by the Queensland Schools Alliance Against Violence announced by the Premier yesterday. I ask the Premier: what has happened to the Youth Violence Task Force and what has happened to the 16 recommendations it handed down in 2007 to tackle youth violence? In the 52nd sitting of parliament I introduced into this House a private member’s bill to limit the supply of alcohol to minors. Even though the Youth Violence Task Force supported the purpose of my bill, the government voted it down only to come back into the House a year later and introduce it as its own bill.

That is why today, as part of a plan to address violence in our schools, I table a copy of a consultation draft of a bill to amend the Criminal Code to introduce a series of offences relating to acts of violence on school grounds. The draft bill also seeks comment on a new offence that would seek to prevent violent fight clubs being conducted on school grounds. According to police statistics, there were 2,498 assaults reported on educational facilities between 2006 and 2009. Educational facilities had some of the highest recorded number of assaults in any institutional setting.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Criminal Code (Protecting School Students and Members of Staff from Assaults) Amendment Bill 2010, consultation draft.
XML.Hansard-Body: As I have said, this bill seeks to address this violent trend by affording legislative protection to students and teachers from persons who assault and intimidate others whilst on school grounds. People who enter school grounds and assault others must be held responsible for their actions. Victims of such violence should also have the full protection of the law. Let us put aside politics for the sake of our children’s safety.

Mr SHINE (Toowoomba North--ALP) (11.37 am): Over a number of years I have had the terrific experience of working with a great bunch of women, the Toowoomba Maternity Coalition, in their quest for a birthing centre at the Toowoomba Hospital. This was an important election commitment for Toowoomba. It is great news that the $1 million redevelopment of the Toowoomba Hospital’s new birthing centre is in full swing with the appointment of a successful tenderer.

The redevelopment will see two new birthing suites constructed in the Toowoomba Hospital, adjacent to the maternity ward in an area occupied by the old decommissioned obstetric theatre. The $1 million redevelopment will provide a new birthing experience for the expectant mothers of Toowoomba and the Darling Downs. The new Toowoomba birthing centre will give low-risk pregnant women significantly enhanced birthing choices, including giving women the opportunity to give birth in a family homelike environment with midwife support and access to specialised care if required.

The state government is now working closely with the Toowoomba Maternity Coalition in the development of the new birthing centre. The Maternity Coalition does a tremendous job in working to enhance birthing choices for women locally. I am really pleased that it has continued to provide input into the development and design of the centre. This includes being involved as part of the birthing centre working group and steering committee, with both playing an integral role in the development of the new birthing centre. This consultation will help to further ensure that the design of the centre meets the needs of expectant mothers and the specialised midwifery nurses who will care for them.

Over the past 12 months the Toowoomba Hospital has seen an increase of six per cent in the birthrate, which is consistent with what has been happening in Toowoomba over previous years. There is a strong midwifery model of care in place. Those highly trained midwives will ensure that local women have the birthing experience they choose, all the while knowing that the support, care and advice they need is right there.

Ms SIMPSON (Maroochydore--LNP) (11.39 am): This Labor government has betrayed Queenslanders on a petrol tax. It has betrayed Queenslanders on privatisation. And who would ever believe those opposite about a congestion tax? They promised that they would not bring in a petrol tax. They promised that they would not sell Queensland Rail and privatise state assets. And they lied. They misled the people of Queensland.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order!
Member for Maroochydore, resume your seat. Your language is unparliamentary and I ask you to withdraw.

Ms SIMPSON: I withdraw. The only thing Queenslanders can trust Labor on is that if they vote for Labor it is going to cost them dearly. I was going to table this document--it has been tabled--that shows that a congestion charge is in the government’s plans. What we see from the government is that it says one thing and does another.

The government’s transport planning documents as part of Connecting SEQ 2031 show two things: a congestion charge and delayed public transport infrastructure. Queensland motorists are already paying the highest costs of any motorists in Australia. Commuters in SEQ are also suffering from a government that has plans but no action. In 2016 the rail network in the middle of Brisbane is due to hit gridlock. Like a scene from the movie Groundhog Day , Labor keeps reannouncing feasibility plans, with no action--14 April 2005, 26 August 2007, 7 October 2008, 12 May 2009 and 19 November 2009. In the next few weeks we will see another announcement about a feasibility study and yet another expensive PR campaign. Labor has the PR; it just does not follow up with action.

We have seen delays on the Eastern Busway, the South East Busway and the rail line to Elanora, and CAMCOS is a project that this government has pushed out now to beyond 2031, according to this document. The government is failing to deliver on public transport infrastructure but it is putting the costs up. It says one thing and does another. Queenslanders can expect a congestion charge and more taxes under this government.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP) (11.41 am): Each year the Queensland government provides funding through the Multicultural Assistance Program for community groups to host events and run projects that strengthen multiculturalism, foster harmonious community relations and participation and build community capacity, including improved access to services in Queensland. In 2009-10, funding of $700,000 was allocated for this purpose. This was the most competitive round in history, with over 200 applications received--our highest number of applications in 10 years. The total amount of funding requested far exceeded what was available. Considering the amount of cross-cultural benefit that this funding produces within the community, it is certainly money well spent.

The minister has approved funding for 98 events and projects in 2010 which is also the highest number of applications funded in the last 10 years. The assessment process was rigorous, and this has helped to ensure a wide spread of high-quality events to be implemented right across the state. I am very excited by the diversity of events and projects that are being funded this year, and I look forward to attending many of them.

We have just witnessed the vibrant celebrations for the Chinese New Year and the Vietnamese New Year. In March, Queenslanders will have the opportunity to join in the Fraser Coast Cultural Festival, the Multicultural Carina Festival and the Central Queensland Multicultural Festival and to celebrate Telugu New Year, Nowrooz--the Persian New Year--and Harmony Day events. Many community projects have also been funded to increase the capacity of Queenslanders from culturally diverse backgrounds to access services they need. I encourage members of parliament to actively participate in these events which are such an important way of recognising and celebrating our cultural diversity.

As the Parliamentary Secretary for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs, I would like to commend the hard work of a small team of people in MAQ responsible for administering the grants program. They have a diverse range of duties which take them across all areas of government, ensuring that multicultural harmony is always on top of the agenda.

Mr McARDLE (Caloundra--LNP) (11.43 am): The Productivity Commission’s Report on government services 2010 , recently released, showed some concerning statistics in relation to people suffering from a mental illness and how their needs are being met in Queensland. The report highlighted that Queensland continued to have the lowest level of recurrent spending on mental health and services of any Australian state.

Mental health funding at the discretion of the Queensland state government was $143 per person in 2007-08 compared to an average of $164 in the other states. Alarmingly, the number of available hospital beds per 100,000 residents for those with a mental illness has fallen in Queensland for the fifth consecutive year, from 36.8 in 2003-04 to 33.3 in 2007-08, whilst the national average is 41.2. One in every six patients discharged from a psychiatric hospital bed is readmitted within 28 days--a rate higher than any other state--and only 44 per cent of mental health patients in 2007-08 received a community follow-up within seven days of discharge, compared to over 50 per cent a year earlier.

Of most concern is the total lack of dedicated hospital beds for those with a mental illness. I fear that the lack of beds may be leading to patients being discharged earlier than appropriate, because the report reveals that almost one in every six patients discharged from a hospital is readmitted within 28 days--a rate higher than any other state. The report did highlight that funding in Queensland for community mental health services has increased, yet only 44 per cent of mental health patients in 2007-08 received a community follow-up within seven days of discharge, compared to over 50 per cent a year earlier.

Clearly the mental health system and the way we treat people who suffer from mental illness is in significant difficulty. It will take a system that deals with prevention, early intervention and treatment, tackling issues including substance abuse, domestic violence and social isolation to build a structure that will provide adequate care, protection and recovery models for the future.

Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (11.45 am): Last Saturday the local business community embraced the need for a clean environment when the Redcliffe City Chamber of Commerce hosted me and the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning, Stirling Hinchliffe, to launch the Business Clean Up Australia in Redcliffe. The event was held at Redefined Cafe, and owner Rod Kemp welcomed us and we joined his normal Saturday lunch patrons and passers-by.

President of the chamber, Irena Morgan from MW, addressed the crowd with the support of chamber secretary Deb Grealey from Beads by the Beach. It was heartening to see that the business community, who are seen as role models in the community, are keen to lead the charge in cleaning up the Redcliffe CBD and shopping precinct. This show of business support will encourage other people who may not normally take the time out to clean up their corner of our precious natural environment to give a couple of hours on Clean Up Australia Day.

This clean-up will not only make the Redcliffe CBD a cleaner and more pleasant environment in which to shop and eat but also ensure that less rubbish will go into our stormwater system and that fewer cigarette butts and less plastic will find their way into the stomachs of sea birds and turtles. This demonstrates the symbiotic nature of acting to increase environmental outcomes and running a successful business, particularly in Redcliffe--where we are surrounded by Moreton Bay and Hays Inlet--because we are working to develop our fledgling tourism industry.

The launch of Business Clean Up Australia in the Redcliffe CBD demonstrated the Bligh government’s strong focus on achieving our targets of protecting our environment and growing a strong economy. Reaching our targets is what good government is all about, and this Labor government is about good government.

Dr FLEGG (Moggill--LNP) (11.47 am): On 1 September last year I asked the Minister for Education and Training to detail the number of weapon incidents that occurred in Queensland schools. The answer to question on notice No. 1054 in essence says, ‘This isn’t the department’s problem. It’s a problem for individual schools and the police,’ and no details were provided. Similarly, in answer to question on notice No. 1334, no details of the number of lockdowns were provided.

Last year the LNP opposition was trying to urge the government to take the growing concern around weapons seriously, only to find that the government was so disinterested that it could not or would not even tell parliament the extent of the problem. How can you define the extent of a problem or assess whether measures to contain it are effective if you cannot even provide an answer to a question in parliament about the number of serious incidents? Deputy Premier Lucas said this morning that ‘accountability breeds excellence’. That has been missed by the education minister.

When suddenly, through tragic circumstances, media attention is focused on the issue, the government in fact is able to provide the figures to the Courier-Mail --the figures that it would not provide to parliament. Apart from the obvious disregard for parliamentary accountability, this tragically demonstrates again that on matters of grave importance to Queensland parents the government only acts when it comes to dealing with media fallout. The LNP believes that the government should be proactive in dealing with these worsening trends before they end in tragedy.

Yesterday I placed on notice a question in relation to another serious problem in our schools--the number of drug incidents. Drug incidents are linked to violence in our schools. The problem is serious in our schools. Is the government waiting for this problem to hit the papers, too, before it does anything? Any reasonable person would expect that the government would be closely tracking this problem and will be prepared to answer a reasonable question from the opposition. We shall see in 29 days.

Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (11.49 am): Twelve months ago, I was part of the Bligh Labor team that went to the Queensland electorate promising jobs, not job cuts, and an $18 billion infrastructure program that would protect 127,000 Queensland jobs. In Logan, the state government’s commitment to job creation can be seen in major projects like the Pacific Motorway upgrade at the Loganlea Road interchange, a project creating 1,400 jobs and improving traffic flow for 140,000 motorists.

But there are also local projects that are giving young people from Logan and Beenleigh an opportunity to get ready for work and get a job. The state government’s Skilling Queenslanders for Work program has given thousands of Queenslanders a chance to enter the workforce. In our area, organisations such as BoysTown and the Beenleigh PCYC have delivered practical local projects that provide real employment outcomes. One of these projects is the fantastic partnership between BoysTown and the Waterford Demons Rugby League Football Club. The Waterford Rugby League Football Club project provided a construction work placement program for eight young local people looking to get a start in construction and landscaping.

As well as making sure these eight young Logan people are job ready, the project delivered important upgrades for the Demons’ home ground at Noffke Park. During the 16-week project, the eight participants installed approximately 130 metres of fencing posts and rails between the two main fields, constructed concrete pads and erected two player dugouts, constructed concrete pathway and disability access and approximately 130 metres of footpath to the clubhouse, constructed approximately 60 metres of retaining walls, constructed a wood bin enclosure and painted a new mural on the club’s facilities.

The project was delivered with the support of the Logan City Council, which contributed the material costs for the project, and the owners of the sporting fields. At the project graduation on 22 January, the success of these job programs could be seen when half of the participants were too busy working to attend the graduation. The Bligh government’s commitment to jobs, not job cuts, continues to give young people in Logan the opportunity to have a job, a career and the dignity of work.

Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP) (11.51 am): I rise to speak on behalf of the public transport users in my electorate of Buderim. They would like to be able to take advantage of the government’s wonderful go card system and make their travel cheaper and easier. Unfortunately, unless they are able to purchase and top up their go cards online, they are out of luck. In its wisdom, the government has failed to provide a single retail outlet for go cards in the entire Buderim electorate--not one. The minister and her bureaucrats may not have been to Buderim recently. If they looked at our electorate, they would discover that there are plenty of potential retail outlets that could handle the go cards. They would also discover that there is a significant population of older residents, many of whom do not use computers but do use buses. In fact, these residents would like more buses so they can get out and about, particularly if they no longer drive a vehicle.

To give you an example, I have an elderly constituent who was thrilled last year when TransLink extended the local bus route so she can now use it. In the past, it was too far for her to walk to a bus stop. She has been a regular bus user ever since and it has made a big difference to her life, but she cannot buy a go card to use this bus--not without catching a bus to the customer service centre in Maroochydore. They offer a limited service there. You can buy a $20 go card, provided you have cash and do not want to use EFTPOS or credit. Yes, people without computers can buy go cards over the phone or send in a form, but older people in particular often do not like to buy over the phone. They like to do it in person, and that is their right.

When it comes to services like public transport, we should ensure that everyone has equal access. We should not be discriminating in favour of those who are used to technology and feel comfortable using it. Older people, like my constituent, want to stay independent and in their own homes. To do that, we need to make sure they have access to good public transport options. The bureaucrats who designed the go card system should come down from their city offices and look at how the system really works for the people who use it. Go cards should be widely available through retail outlets that are convenient to the people who want to buy them. It is time the minister and her department took action to make it happen.

Mr RYAN (Morayfield--ALP) (11.53 am): I rise to give my support to recent positive news that this state Labor government will introduce new conservation measures to protect koalas in priority koala bushland habitats. Koala populations in South-East Queensland, and particularly in the Morayfield state electorate, have been declining for a number of years and these progressive announcements will mean that this vulnerable species will be further protected. The new package of measures will protect priority koala habitat, rehabilitate habitat impacted by development and create new habitat for future koala populations.

The conservation measures include: a ban on all habitat-clearing development in priority areas until new planning instruments are finalised; an initial amount of $15 million for buying new habitat and rehabilitating existing habitat; compulsory acquisition powers for koala habitat outside the urban footprint; new planning laws for councils to minimise koala impacts when assessing development applications in key koala areas; new controls for councils to ban dogs in new developments in koala habitat; and new planning laws to allow land swaps in and outside the urban footprint for strategic koala habitat corridors. I also note that this state government is making $400,000 in state funding available to researchers to study chlamydia and other serious koala diseases. It is hoped that this funded research will help find ways to reduce the impact of disease on koala populations in Queensland.

I would like to take this opportunity to recognise the hard work of the Moreton Bay Koala Rescue group. I commend the group’s volunteers for their selfless and dedicated service to the protection and care of koalas in the Morayfield state electorate. When it comes to the protection of koala populations, governments can do something or nothing. In this instance, this state Labor government is doing something. In this instance, this state Labor government is working hard to provide the greatest protection of koalas ever seen in South-East Queensland. It is this Labor government which is leading policy development on environmental protection in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Criminal Code (Serious Assaults on Police and Particular Other Persons) Amendment Bill
XML.LegAssembly: Criminal Code (Serious Assaults on Police & Part. Other Persons) A’ment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr SPRINGBORG (Southern Downs--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition)
(11.55 am): I present a bill for an act to amend the Criminal Code to provide for minimum sentencing for serious assaults on police officers and particular other persons. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Criminal Code (Serious Assaults on Police and Particular Other Persons) Amendment Bill.
Tabled paper: Criminal Code (Serious Assaults on Police and Particular Other Persons) Amendment Bill, explanatory notes.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr SPRINGBORG (Southern Downs--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition)
(11.56 am): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Today I introduce a bill into parliament that seeks to provide further protection to our state’s police and a bill that will hold violent thugs who seriously assault police accountable for their actions. When it comes to violent assaults against our state’s police and emergency services workers, the time for making excuses for criminals must stop and the laws need to be strengthened to ensure that real deterrence is implemented.

The bill I present seeks to establish a minimum sentence range for offenders found guilty of seriously assaulting police, ambulance and fire officers where the assault involves biting, spitting or throwing bodily fluid or faeces at an officer in the course of their duties. In the case of assaults against police, this type of serious assault is much more than just resisting arrest. The types of serious assault I have outlined involve some form of decision to act out the assault and can have serious physical and emotional effects on the victim. The agony and anguish that a police officer or emergency services worker must go through waiting months for results of testing to find out if they have been exposed to a communicable disease is a harrowing experience. This ongoing suffering is not just isolated to the officer but also involves his or her family.

In 2007 there were 429 offenders convicted of serious assaults against police officers. This bill seeks to introduce a minimum sentencing range for serious assaults on police where the assault involves biting, spitting or throwing bodily fluid or faeces. In view of the time, I seek leave for the remainder of my speech to be incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Between December 2008 and June 2009 police officers made 155 WorkCover claims for assaults against them and in almost half those cases (72) the officer was exposed to blood or bodily fluid.

The Bill makes it clear that the minimum sentence that a court may impose on an offender who is guilty of a serious assault under a new part 2B, that defines certain types of serious assaults, is 3 months imprisonment. Offenders convicted for a serious assault on a police officer or emergency services worker, where the assault involves actual biting, spitting on, throwing bodily fluid or faeces at an officer fall within the new sentencing provisions contained in 2C. The new part 340(2D) makes it clear that the minimum 3 month term may not be suspended.
Assaults against our emergency services workers are as equally deplorable and this is why the LNP has sought to include them in this legislation.

Figures indicate in the financial year 2007-2008, 38 assault incidents were reported by QAS officers, 1 of which was reported to the Queensland Police Service (QPS) and 1 incident resulted in a paramedic being unable to commence their next shift.
In the financial year 2008-2009, 107 assault incidents were reported by QAS officers, 11 of which were reported to QPS and 7 resulted in a paramedic being unable to commence their next shift.

In the financial year 2009-2010 (YTD as of 19.8.09) 21 assault incidents were reported by QAS officers, 5 of which were reported to the QPS and none have resulted in a paramedic being unable to commence their next shift.

Any assault against a police officer or emergency services officers is one too many and we on this side of the House are determined to ensure that the penalty reflects the seriousness of the crime when it comes to these vicious attacks. If we do not respect and move to protect those at the front line who are there just to protect us, what hope is there?
The Bill allows a court to take into account exceptional circumstances where the offender is a child as to whether the minimum 3 months imprisonment is to be imposed.
I commend the Bill to the House.
XML.Hansard-Body: Debate, on motion of Mr Hinchliffe, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Queensland Institute of Medical Research Centre
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms GRACE (Brisbane Central--ALP) (11.58 am): Well, if you were Chuck Feeney of Atlantic Philanthropies and you wanted to invest in world-class scientific and medical research, where would you go? Brisbane, Queensland, is the answer. It was wonderful to be with Premier Anna Bligh as the first sod was turned on a new addition to Queensland’s medical research and development capabilities. This is particularly exciting as work has begun during February, which is Ovarian Cancer Awareness Month, and I am today joining the Teal Team by wearing this teal ribbon.

The $179 million Queensland Institute of Medical Research Centre at Herston in Brisbane will create about 360 jobs during construction, will be home to 20 new research laboratories and will be staffed by 400 scientists and students. This facility will be completed by 2012 and has been funded by the state and federal governments and by Atlantic Philanthropies. The centre will increase the capability of QIMR to further its research in areas such as tropical diseases, vaccine development, cancer and genetics, which is excellent news for women suffering ovarian cancer during this special month.

Equally exciting will be the introduction of a Mental Health Research Division, with brain neuroimaging facilities which will enable QIMR to improve research of serious mental illnesses such as schizophrenia. Added to this will be an expansion in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health, with room for 20 extra scientists researching cancer, asthma, rheumatic heart disease, dementia and maternal and child health. An education centre, which is part of the project, features a state-of-the-art high school research laboratory for teacher and student workshops.

The state government over the last decade has transformed Queensland’s scientific community from 8,500 scientists to 18,100 scientists during this period--the biggest increase of any Australian state. New scientific infrastructure like this will continue to make Queensland a world-class player in the vital areas of scientific and medical research, and I ask: what can be better than that? Lives will be saved and cures will be found because of QIMR’s world-class research. I am proud to have them in my electorate.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP) (12.00 pm): I would like to take this opportunity to raise a matter that for some reason the Minister for Health is either unable or unwilling to answer. Based on the performance of the Minister for Health, I suspect it is the latter. With respect to the delayed Sunshine Coast University Hospital, on 20 August 2009 I asked the minister by question on notice--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: With reference to the Sunshine Coast University Hospital ... planning (project) board--
Have any members of the board been sacked, made redundant, transferred or ‘re-orientated’ since the announcement that the SCUH would be delayed by up to two years and, if so, who and why?
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The minister wrote back as follows--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That team, like any public service unit, experiences personnel changes from time to time.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: On 8 October 2009 I asked the minister another question on notice--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: With reference to the Sunshine Coast University Hospital project/planning board and the Minister’s previous answer to my Question on Notice ... who is currently on the board ...
I refer the Member to my answer to Question on Notice ... in which I provided a response to these issues.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: No, he did not. So on 24 November 2009 I asked the minister again--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: When is the Sunshine Coast University Hospital project team being re-convened?
As I have advised the member in more than one answer to his Questions on Notice in recent weeks, the project team continues its work to deliver the $1.57 billion Sunshine Coast University Hospital.
XML.Hansard-Body: The question remains unanswered. Having given up on the minister’s ability to answer quite a simple question, I headed to the government website--Sunshine Coast University Hospital ‘Getting Involved’. Apparently as well as the project team there is a stakeholder advisory group involving members of the community. There are no other details and--a recurring theme for this--no names of the stakeholder group. What is interesting is the ‘Getting Involved’ information for members of the public, if they do want to get involved: ‘Further information about how you can get involved will be available soon.’ This is from the government website about the Sunshine Coast University Hospital. It was last updated on 31 March 2008. Two years ago the minister and his own department’s website says that, if the Sunshine Coast community wants to get involved, wait two years. It is not acceptable.

Ms O’NEILL (Kallangur--ALP) (12.02 pm): It is Australian Organ Donor Awareness week. Many times my heart has been warmed by stories of the wonderful difference organ and tissue donation has made to the life of the grateful recipients and their families: freedom from dialysis, sight returned, a strong heart, the chance to breathe freely again. Unfortunately, the more sombre question of being a donor is less often discussed or the subject of media coverage. Of course, a loved one’s illness, accident or death is a fearful, heart-rending time. It is a time of clinging to hope and supporting loved ones and making decisions about treatment. We are stressed, emotional and grief stricken. It is not the time to be discussing organ or tissue donation. But for many of us it is the only time we are asked to discuss it, and we are required to make rapid decisions.

It is a great pity when there is only a one per cent chance that a person will be able to be a donor for that chance to pass by because families do not know the wishes of the deceased, because people have not told their family of their wishes or they are not on the donor register. I have long been a fan of opt-out legislation, or presumed consent, as a means of increasing the number of people on the donor register. Some research states that presumed consent can improve the chance of a donor being available by as much as 25 per cent. Other research says that it is the availability of facilities and community education that makes the biggest difference.

I am aware that it may be a difficult social decision, but perhaps presumed consent could ensure that more conversations take place and lead to a much needed increase in available donors. I urge all Queenslanders to join the other 912,000 of us and sign on to the donor register; promote organ and tissue donation and the selflessness of such a decision to friends and workmates; talk to your families; and make sure they know your wishes. In the face of terrible loss, the knowledge that other critically ill Queenslanders and their families will be given a new lease of life may give much needed comfort.
Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (12.03 pm), by leave, without notice: I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That general business order of the day No. 2 be discharged from the Notice Paper .
XML.Hansard-Body: Last year I introduced a private member’s bill to amend Queensland planning laws by creating a new simple law to regulate community hospices in Queensland. Since then I have had discussions with Minister Hinchliffe and our Premier. As a result, the government has now created a new simple law to regulate community hospices in Queensland. I thank the Premier and Minister Hinchliffe for listening to my request to change the law and for changing the law in Queensland. I will now not need to proceed with debate on my private member’s bill. I table for the benefit of all members a copy of the government’s new planning provision, ‘Regulating community hospices in Queensland’.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Document, undated, regarding community residence.
XML.Hansard-Body: On behalf of the many Queenslanders suffering a terminal illness who would like to die in their own community and not in a hospital or nursing home, I thank the government for making that wish more possible. We on the Sunshine Coast look forward to the opening in the near future of the very first Australian community hospice house, which is locally known as Katie Rose Cottage.
Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (12.05 pm), by leave: I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be withdrawn.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.

Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (12.06 pm), by leave: A new state government planning code has paved the way for a much needed palliative care development on the Sunshine Coast. Following the introduction of the code, the Sunshine Coast Regional Council unanimously agreed to endorse a local planning instrument to reduce red tape for a proposed community residence development.

Katie Rose Cottage, in the hinterland community of Doonan, west of Noosa, is now, I understand, ready to open and help terminally ill Sunshine Coast people to die with dignity. The small facility is the realisation of a dream for palliative care nurses Terry Clarke-Burrows and Sue Story, who spent the last two years working to make the cottage a reality.

This valuable service equally would not have been possible without the member for Nicklin. It was the member for Nicklin who first brought Katie Rose Cottage to the state government’s attention with a private member’s bill to amend the Integrated Planning Act on 28 October. The member for Nicklin pushed for change at state and local level, and it is largely due to his efforts that Katie Rose Cottage can now open its doors.

The Bligh government recognises that there is a need for more similar facilities. On 18 December the state government finalised changes to the planning laws to allow councils to amend planning schemes and permit residential homes to become palliative care hospices, with up to six guest rooms in each house. I would like to congratulate the Sunshine Coast Regional Council for being the first local government in Queensland to implement this policy, and provide additional dignity and comfort to terminally ill community members when they need it most. I hope their decision encourages other councils to provide similar much needed care facilities for terminally ill patients and their families within their local planning schemes. I would again like to commend Mrs Clarke-Burrows, Mrs Story and the member for Nicklin for their dedication and hard work.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 9 February (see p. 53), on motion of Mr Wilson--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Dr FLEGG (Moggill--LNP) (12.08 pm): I am pleased to make a contribution to the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010. There are three main areas covered under this bill. I will address these three areas in order. The first area of this bill is that, following on from early legislation that published certain notices that were issued to child-care operators on a website, we are now in this bill requiring child-care operators to keep a logbook available to parents and prospective parents that details any notices, variations to their licence, suspensions et cetera.

The main difference that this bill has to the existing arrangements is that minor notices or notices pertaining to minor breaches will also be included in the logbook. The LNP and I, as shadow minister, have consistently supported parents’ right to information. Even where this has been a difficult issue, such as the My School website, we have taken the attitude that the overriding right of parents to have access to information about where their children are cared for or where they are educated should be the guiding principle.

In the case of the My School website, that was a difficult decision for us because that information is prone to misuse. We see with the creation of league tables that conclusions are erroneously drawn that because a school’s overall performance on a league table exceeds another school’s then the school higher in the league table is providing a better outcome for individual students. That is a false conclusion that cannot be drawn. The LNP has had that concern about league tables, but we have supported the publication of this data on the basis that the overriding consideration that the LNP wishes to support is that parents have a right to this information. For the same reason, we will not be opposing the provision in this bill relating to logbooks being maintained in the child-care sector. I do wish to express some concerns and make some points that the minister and the department may wish to take on board.

I put the bill that the minister introduced in the last sitting week out to consultation among industry stakeholders and operators in the industry. I think it is very instructive to look at some of the feedback I received. It would be in the best interests all round if the government took on board some of the feedback that we have been getting for a while. I certainly will not name the industry participants who have made these comments, but it is pretty important to record their comments in relation to this bill. In relation to the keeping of logbooks, one respondent says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Every time we have an inspection the inspectors feel obliged to give a notice to justify their existence--not saying that these visits should not happen but that the consistency and veracity of what they do leaves a lot to be desired. For example, we could get a notice because the text on a staff member’s photograph was 16 point and not 18 point in size. We have had this happen at our centre, and many other centres report similar things. Now, if this gets published it is rubbish.

I don’t know if the legislators know this, but a disproportionate amount of our teachers’ time is keeping logs. For example, in the last accreditation rounds we had to introduce a log where each teacher documented all the interventions given to each child that day so that when the parents arrived to pick up their children they could read what had happened. A great idea, but it is a trade-off against actual care. This logbook is of the same kind.
XML.Hansard-Body: He then goes on to perhaps suggest a bit of annoyance in the industry by saying, ‘If the government wants this, then they should publish their own documents.’ Another respondent says in relation to the logbooks--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Child-Care logbook--more paper for nothing much. This is a factor for centres to share when nobody in their right mind is going to show a parent a logbook that is negative.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: From the opposition’s point of view, we do not think that justifies not having the information available, of course. The respondent continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Government knows that closing a seriously non-complaint centre will lose them votes so instead of getting tough they are loading us, the operators, up with more useless paperwork.
XML.Hansard-Body: There is a theme of concern there that we are not adequately differentiating between the serious breaches--the things that may endanger a child--and things that might be considered administrative breaches or minor breaches.

Another very senior industry participant was concerned that this sort of focus, particularly when it is on minor issues such as the point size of the writing on a staff member’s photograph, may lead to us becoming so totally risk averse that we affect normal childhood experiences. This is a theme that I have had repeated to me by a number of industry participants. This major stakeholder in the industry, whom I will not name because I have not sought their permission to use their name, said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Even though I am sure some services will continue to receive non-compliance notices, I am more concerned with what may constitute noncompliance, particularly in outdoor environments, as history tells us there are quite varying degrees as to what is appropriate, safe or challenging in the outdoors. I would hate to see the trend to sanitise early childhood advanced any more through an overzealous compliance regime.
XML.Hansard-Body: Those saying this are all major industry participants in child-care and kindergarten services. They are certainly well known to the opposition and reputable operators. Those concerns about red tape and about getting the balance right between protecting children, a parent’s right to know and tying up a lot of time for incredibly minor things that will lead to industry simply becoming very risk averse and very focused on pretty trivial things may have some counterproductive effects.

The opposition will be applying its overriding belief that parents have a right to this information. We will not be opposing the provision to maintain logbooks in child-care centres, but we do want the government to understand the concern that is out there in the industry and the fact that sometimes there is a difference between what we enact here in legislation and how it is applied--that is, whether it is appropriate and whether common sense is used. I appreciate the minister’s nod on that.

The second of the three areas that this bill applies to is the Masters report recommendation that teachers graduating from university and seeking registration as a teacher should sit a test of their proficiency in literacy, numeracy and science--the ‘test the teacher’ provision. The opposition has given the government bipartisan support on this issue, as we will continue to do by supporting the measure in the bill today. It is a difficult issue to discuss in some contexts. There has been concern expressed, including within the teaching profession, within universities and within other forums, that the standard of teachers coming out of our universities may not, in some instances, be good enough. I hope that is taken in context. That concern is there. Masters identified and expressed that concern. He recommended that this measure go forward. We will be supporting the government in doing so.

There are a couple of things that the minister may care to clarify for us. The explanatory notes to this bill indicate quite clearly that there will be no cost to government as a result of the measures in this bill. That leads me to conclude that the Queensland College of Teachers, which will be required to purchase these tests or write them themselves and presumably apply them, mark them and collate results, will not receive additional government funding to do this.

The Queensland College of Teachers is largely funded by the fees that teachers pay. Teachers might feel particularly aggrieved that existing teacher registration fees have to fund this test.
