The only other way I can see this being funded--and the minister, I trust, will clarify this for me in his summing-up--is through some sort of user-pays system. That is, those sitting the test through the Queensland College of Teachers will be required to pay the cost of sitting the test. I think that is potentially a very harsh outcome, but at the end of the day someone is going to have to pay the costs for these tests and this bill indicates that the government is not going to be that somebody.

We have seen recently that an overwhelming majority of teacher graduates in Queensland have been unable to obtain a full-time teaching job--the overwhelming majority. Many of these kids graduating from university--many of them will be very good teachers given the opportunity--have a right to ask some questions about what has gone on in relation to planning in that we are producing teachers, we appear to desperately need teachers but when they graduate there is in fact no job for them. I fear that some of these graduates will become very disenchanted and feel that they are not wanted. I certainly would not like to see the Queensland College of Teachers, because it receives no government funding, then pass another major obstacle on to new graduates in making them pay the cost of these tests. It would be particularly galling if they have to pay the cost of the test in order to be registered but when they get registered there is no job for them anyway.

The third part of the bill relates to workers in non-school areas. Some of these changes in my view are necessary changes. There are probably three areas where we are making changes in this bill. One issue revolves around the requirement of teachers to re-register every five years and in order to keep their recency of practice they must have worked the equivalent of one year in five; otherwise they need to go through a process to re-establish their recency which can be in service but requires them to upgrade their knowledge of the syllabus and so forth.

Under the existing act, to be considered to be working as a teacher one needs to be working in a school. But, as we know, teachers do sometimes work in places that are not technically considered to be a school. The obvious one that is going to grow greatly in importance is in the area of early childhood where we will have four-year trained university teachers working in child-care centres, which are now moving to deliver the kindergarten programs, or in the government’s new C&K operated centres. These teachers would not at the moment be technically considered to be working in a school. Therefore, that teaching work would not qualify them for recency of teaching work when they come to re-register. The opposition would certainly support the measures in this bill that would allow those teachers to have that work recognised as teaching for recency purposes.

Another example is the TAFE senior colleges. Provided the teacher is delivering a Queensland curriculum for schools as part of that TAFE senior college, that will also be recognised as teaching experience. There are a number of TAFE senior colleges around the state, notably in the electorate of my colleague the member for Hervey Bay and also in Alexandra Hills. Again, provided those teachers are delivering an approved school curriculum, I do not think anyone would have any desire to dispute the fact that they are currently teaching.

It becomes a little bit greyer when we move into the area of education advisers or what is referred to in the explanatory notes as people who are on leadership duties, and I think it is quite a bit greyer. I understand that there are something like 20 education advisers per education district, so we are possibly looking at around 200 people. It also applies of course to literacy and numeracy coaches. It would be fair to say that the opposition would prefer that people in these educational advice roles were in fact still meeting the requirement for recency--that is, that they did the equivalent of one year in five in the classroom. In any sort of profession, particularly a rapidly moving profession like teaching, there is not really a substitute for spending at least some time--perhaps only the equivalent of one day a week--in the classroom at the coalface. That would certainly be our preference.

I do hope that the minister might give some more detail in relation to this matter. I do note that there is an assurance in the explanatory notes--and a very important assurance as far as the opposition is concerned--that this measure will not extend to bureaucrats or white-collar workers within the department whose role is not directly related to activity in the classroom. I would rely on that assurance, but we would like some more detail. The opposition would not wish to penalise any particular group that is genuinely working in teaching related activities or classroom related activities and we would not want to necessarily single out a group to oppose the fact that their work should be treated as currency. It is not our intention to oppose any of these provisions that I have just discussed, but more information will go some way to assuaging some concerns.

I would also ask the minister in his summing-up to give us more information as to how many extra teacher registrations his department considers will result from the extension of the currency arrangements in this bill. The three areas that I have spoken about today are the key areas of the bill, so I do not intend to go on any longer in relation to it. I look forward to the minister making some additional comments and I will ensure that I have a few questions for him during consideration in detail of the bill.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (12.26 pm): I rise to contribute to the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010. The objectives of this bill are to amend the Child Care Act 2002 to require licensees of child-care services, other than school-age care services, to keep logbooks of their compliance and to amend the Education (Queensland College of Teachers) Act 2005 to test persons on literacy, numeracy and science prior to their registration as teachers and to recognise certain teaching experience for the purposes of teacher registration. I have a particular interest in the child-care portion of this bill given that in the electorate of Mudgeeraba there are 27 child-care centres in areas such as Mudgeeraba, Tallai, Gilston, Merrimac, Worongary and Robina. I have visited each of these centres so that I can represent their views in parliament and I have previously shared their concerns in this House over proposed changes to legislation relating to the ratio of children to teachers and the process of standardisation to bring Queensland into line with other states.

In addition to private child-care providers, there is a C&K community kindergarten in my electorate which has been neglected by the government in terms of funding for many years. During the election this C&K kindergarten was reannounced again, with funding to include a new kindergarten attached to Mudgeeraba State School. This announcement was greeted cynically by the private operators who saw this as nothing more than political pork-barrelling, as it had been reannounced three times earlier. This has now commenced construction. Of particular interest and prior concern to the private operators was the name and shame requirements to be added to a website for even minor infringements. It was reported in the Courier-Mail on 6 October 2009 when child-care centres were being named and shamed under the legislation that--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ‘Childcare Queensland president Gwynn Bridge said operators did not support the laws but would work with the Government to ensure they were applied fairly. Everyone is concerned about these laws,’ Mrs Bridge said.
‘We need to ensure natural justice is followed and businesses which are to be named are given the chance to correct their problems.’
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This bill will now require child-care services to keep a logbook under the Child Care Act 2002. This will include centres such as long day care, kindergartens and limited hours care, and home based services such as family day care.
XML.Hansard-Body: It also regulates stand-alone services where child care is provided to no more than six children, four of whom are not yet schoolchildren. The CCA includes a rigorous monitoring and enforcement regime to ensure that child-care services comply with the terms of their licences and with the guiding principles of the CCA. Where a service fails to meet these requirements, a range of measures may be taken against it. These measures range from issuing compliance notices requesting the service to remedy any contravention of the act to taking action to amend, urgently amend, suspend, urgently suspend, refuse to renew or revoke the service provider’s licence.

The first stage of these amendments, which commenced on 1 February 2010, enables the Department of Education and Training to publish on its website information about child-care services--other than school-age care services--that demonstrate that serious and repeated noncompliance is more than minor in nature. Childcare Queensland and associated child-care centres are working closely with the government to ensure that members are compliant under the previous changes in legislation to name and shame and will work in collaboration to ensure that centres are compliant.
A recent press release from the President of Childcare Queensland, Gwynn Bridge, states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... that compliance letters are issued by a state compliance officer during a visit and are often fixable the same day.
‘Compliance letters are issued to private and community child care providers during prearranged and unannounced spot checks,’ Ms Bridge said.
‘In 2009, 97.6 per cent of compliance letters were addressed in the time allocated,’ she said which leaves 2.4% of compliance letters becoming the more serious ‘Compliance Notice’.
‘We do not condone child care providers that delay addressing compliance issues, however each compliance letter and issue must be placed into context and taken on a case by case basis.

‘We are working with the Government to ensure that a quality system is maintained that fairly identifies and deals with the small number of service providers in Queensland who are having difficulty meeting regulations.
XML.Hansard-Body: As a result of collaboration on the legislation, the majority of service providers already comply with the legislation. However, there are limited exceptions where some service providers contravene the CCA or expose children in their care to serious risks to child safety and wellbeing.

The second stage of these amendments, which is the subject of this bill, will require all licensed child-care services--except school-age care services--to record in a logbook information about any notices given to them under the CCA relating to minor, moderate or serious noncompliance. The logbook will be accessible to current and prospective parents of children attending the service. The requirement for licensees to keep a logbook for their services will apply to all licensed centre based child-care services--for example, long day care, kindergarten and limited hours care--except for school-age care services. These are excluded from the scheme. The provision will also apply to all licensed home based services, such as family day care.

These amendments are aimed at providing parents at the local level with access to information about the quality of the child-care service and to enable them to make informed decisions about a child-care service that is providing or will potentially provide a service to their child. However, the LNP believes that these amendments to the Child Care Act are another layer of bureaucracy for the centres to fulfil. Although the safety of children is always paramount, the government’s view appears to be that increasing the paperwork alone will accord with an increase in safety in child-care centres. The introduction of compliance logbooks imposes a large amount of compliance on the child-care providers, where each clause is accompanied by a $1,000 fine.

Centres in my area are already struggling with the changes that were made through compliance legislation that was introduced in 2009. These changes include the impending implementation of national guidelines, the impact of the prep year and the threat of a pre-prep year. Many local operators in the Mudgeeraba electorate have expressed their concern about bearing the increased cost of these changes whilst also facing decreased revenues through the changed guidelines in the size of rooms in Queensland and the number of children they can now accommodate. That in turn leads to an increase in child-care fees for parents.

The Mudgeeraba electorate is a fast-growing electorate, with over 65 per cent of the electorate under 45 years of age with school-age children. Many more children are at the preschool level and under, and this number is growing rapidly. This young community needs the services that it deserves. The Mudgeeraba electorate has 27 child-care centres and eight feeder state primary schools. Unfortunately for this young and vibrant electorate, it is yet to have a state high school west of the M1. Parents of children at child-care centres in my electorate have all raised this issue with me and have signed petitions for a feasibility study for a new state high school. Currently, over 35 per cent of the children in my electorate cross the M1 to access education services. It is high time this government took its head out of the sand and provided the Mudgeeraba electorate with that much needed infrastructure now and not in 20 years time.

I would also like to take this opportunity to thank many child-care operators in my electorate who have actively assisted in providing me with information so that I can better enunciate their concerns about legislation being rushed through. In particular, I would like to thank Kerrie Lada from Hardy’s Road Early Childhood Centre, who is also the secretary of Childcare Queensland, and Mary-Anne Hossack from the Montessori child-care centre in Mudgeeraba for their continued input into this debate. I will continue to work closely with all of the child-care operators in my electorate so that I am their voice in parliament. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP) (12.34 pm): Unlike the previous speaker, I rise to speak in full support of the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill. Arguably, the greatest achievement of the Beattie and Bligh governments over the past 12 years has been in the area of education. I think people throughout Queensland are well aware of the fantastic reforms that this government has undertaken in the area of education. Those reforms include implementing the prep year--something that was absent from Queensland’s education system for decades. Much research has indicated that that absence is one of the causes of some of our relatively poor literacy and numeracy results in recent years. This government also introduced the ‘learning or earning’ reforms into secondary schooling, which required all young people up to the age of 17 to be engaged in school, training or work. We have also introduced a greater focus on literacy and numeracy, and that has been a particularly recent effort.

Some members are aware of kindergartens that are in the process of being constructed in their own electorates. I am fortunate enough to have a new kindergarten being constructed at the Prince of Peace Lutheran College at Everton Hills in the electorate that I represent. I know that the community of the Prince of Peace Lutheran College is very excited about that, as am I. Two hundred and forty new kindergartens will be rolled out in the next few years to give our young children the flying start that they need in education.

Recently the government released a green paper proposing some additional education reforms. I have heard the Premier say that, as much as we have achieved in this area of education and training, we can never stand still. This green paper proposes some further dramatic reforms to Queensland’s education system, particularly a proposal to move year 7 to secondary school. Other reforms implemented by this government have included integrating our curriculum, assessment and reporting regimes and--something that is relevant to this bill--the provision of greater information to parents and the general community on school and student performance.

I think this bill represents another plank in this government’s education reform agenda. The first element of the bill that I would like to address is the requirement for licensees of child-care services to keep logbooks of their compliance history. As many people would be aware, the child-care legislation that we have in Queensland allows child-care services to be breached for a failure to comply with their licence and the legislation. As I think the member who spoke before me implied, these breaches are not necessarily trifling matters. The kinds of things that child-care services can be breached for include a failure to provide children with a safe environment.

As the father of a young child who attends a day-care service, I would want to make sure that his child-care service provides him with a safe environment each and every day that he attends but, more importantly, I would also like to be aware of the compliance history of the child-care service that my child attends. Until now, parents have been unable to find out the compliance history of the child-care centre that their child attends or a centre that they may be intending to send their child to. As I mentioned, I would want to know this kind of information and I think most parents would be in the same boat. Of course, wanting to make sure that your child is going to be in a safe place each day is an absolutely critical component of your decision making when deciding what kind of child-care service--or indeed school--that your child will attend.

I think this reform, which will require licensees to have a logbook and publish instances where they have failed to comply with their licence or the legislation, is a very good step forward in giving parents the kind of information they need to make good decisions about which child-care centre to send their child to.

We need to be very careful about the use of published data on schools and child-care services. In recent years there has been great debate in the community about this issue. I was very proud to be involved, as the then adviser to the then education minister, who is now the Premier, when our government brought in greater reporting of school performance in Queensland. We were the first government in Queensland to publish a range of data on secondary school performance. Most attention was given to the publication of OP scores in high schools, but a much wider range of information was provided at the same time, ranging from the number of students attending and the number of staff who were present to the vocational education and training achievements of that school, which is obviously also an incredibly important component of what our schools provide to students.

Our government has a good record in providing information to parents and communities about the performance of schools. This is now extending to the child-care sphere courtesy of this bill. As I said, there has been a large debate around this issue, most recently around the federal government’s My School website which has published a range of data on literacy and numeracy performance of schools. I personally believe that that website has had some teething problems, particularly where it attempts to compare one school to another. I think there have been some invalid comparisons between different schools around Australia. I am sure that as time goes on the federal government will tackle these teething problems and this resource will prove to be highly valuable not only for parents but also for schools themselves in trying to address their own performance.

A couple of weeks ago I was at a P&C meeting at one of the high schools in the electorate I represent. They were talking about some of the new initiatives they are putting in place to try to improve the literacy and numeracy performance of their school. I will not mention the name of the high school, but it is a very good high school, as are all of the high schools in the electorate that I represent. They recognise that improvement is always possible. I think that they would probably admit that the publication of these literacy and numeracy results is one of the factors that has led to them deciding that they need to take further action around their literacy and numeracy performance and to always be looking at ways to assist their students achieve more highly in the area of literacy and numeracy. While we need to be careful with the publication of data, as long as appropriate safeguards are put in place it is a worthwhile objective and this bill accomplishes that in the area of child care.

The second element of the bill that I would like to discuss is the introduction of a literacy, numeracy or science test prior to someone being registered as a teacher. The Queensland government made a commitment last year to improve school performance following the results of the first national literacy and numeracy testing in 2008. These results were a wake-up call to our education systems at our schools. Literacy and numeracy are obviously the foundations of all learning and we need to lift performance to give our children the best chance in life.

Last year the government commissioned Professor Geoff Masters, an acknowledged international expert in education, to review performance in Queensland primary schools to find areas where we could make immediate improvements. His report emphasised that highly effective teaching requires teachers to have a strong knowledge in their subject areas and how to teach them. He also noted research and findings from his consultations that in many cases Queensland teachers did not feel adequately prepared particularly in areas such as the teaching of literacy and science. People undertaking teaching courses may not necessarily have a strong background in the area of science and yet we expect them, with minimal training in this field in their university studies, to be able to get out in front of a classroom and educate students in the area of science.

There are obviously a number of things that the government is doing to provide further support and in-house training to our teachers to ensure that they do feel confident to teach these areas. In relation to this issue Professor Masters recommended that we should introduce a test so that all aspiring teachers would have to demonstrate their knowledge of literacy, numeracy and science content and their teaching techniques before they can be registered to teach.

Some may say that to qualify with an education degree would by necessity mean they have demonstrated their literacy, numeracy and science content skills. I know from personal experience that at times universities have not been very responsive to the needs of our education system in designing their education courses. Unfortunately, there are some instances--not many, but some instances--where, on graduating, teachers do not feel confident of their knowledge of the material that they are subsequently required to teach. Introducing this kind of test is a good way not of punishing those teachers but ensuring that they have the skills and the content knowledge they will need to front a classroom. If they do not have that knowledge then there are obviously things that the government and the Queensland College of Teachers can do to assist them to gain that knowledge so that they become highly effective teachers in our schools.

The Queensland College of Teachers has been charged with developing and administering these tests. These legislative amendments will enable the college to implement the government’s commitment to introduce preregistration testing in response to Professor Master’s recommendation. They will enable the college to develop, trial and administer this testing program starting in late 2011. Queensland will lead Australia in requiring preservice teachers to sit a test and demonstrate threshold knowledge and skills before being registered. This type of testing already takes place in other countries that are, like Queensland, striving to raise student performance outcomes. For example, aspiring teachers in both England and the United States are required to sit literacy and numeracy tests before they can begin teaching.

All of the Master’s review recommendations, including the introduction of testing of aspiring teachers, aim to improve results for Queensland students. The work of the college to implement these tests is a key step in improving our students’ performance in literacy, numeracy and science. This will contribute to providing a flying start for all Queensland students.

I end where I began: this government has an extremely proud record in the area of education and training. The Prime Minister likes to talk about an education revolution but I think we have had our own version of that in recent years in Queensland. The education system that we have in place in Queensland these days is completely different and an awful lot better than it was even five years ago, let alone what it was like in the dark ages when I went to school.

Mr Reeves:
You attended a great primary school though.

Mr WATT: I take the interjection from the member for Mansfield. I did go to an excellent primary school in the electorate he represents. It gave me most skills, other than the ability to ignore interjections. As I say, this bill builds on the government’s record of achievement and introduces fantastic reforms that will continue to provide our students with a high-quality education. I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP)
(12.45 pm): I rise in support of the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010. This bill amends the Education (Queensland College of Teachers) Act 2005, herein referred to as the act, to recognise certain teaching experiences for the purpose of renewal of teacher registration. The child-care centres in the electorate of Mount Ommaney provide a great service, setting high standards with the support of local parents. It is important that teachers working in these centres are encouraged and supported. Under the current legislation, where Queensland Studies Authority approved and accredited syllabuses are taught, they must be taught by a registered teacher. However, while teachers delivering these programs in non-school settings are required to be registered, this teaching experience in a non-school setting has not been recognised for the purposes of renewing teacher registration. These teachers have had to be registered to deliver the education program but under the current legislation have not been able to rely on that teaching experience to renew their teacher registration. The bill corrects this anomaly.

The bill also clarifies an area of uncertainty regarding experiences that can be recognised when renewing teacher registration. The current act’s definition of teacher recognises ‘administering educational duties’. However, it has been unclear whether those teachers who have provided educational leadership, such as education advisers and the literacy and numeracy coaches engaged under the Council of Australian Government Smarter Schools National Partnership, would have such leadership experience recognised when applying to renew their teacher registration. This bill makes provision for such recognition, making these important leadership roles more attractive to high performing teachers. I commend the minister and the bill to the House.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (12.47 pm): Children are like wet cement: whatever falls on them makes an impression. I see no clear reason for the haste with which this bill has been introduced into the House for debate when the minister’s second reading speech only occurred in the last sitting of parliament. Before government members complain, a quick scan of the list of bills that have been relegated down seems to suggest another motive. Is the government or the minister trying to portray themselves as some kind of forward-thinking policemen of sorts or even fearful of the speed of change in an area such as education? There appears to be an unnecessary, almost indecent, haste to constrain the system by regulation. I am worried that it looks like the government wants to be seen to be doing something without examining the justifications for the legislative step. Specifically, the bill appears to have been overindulgent in adding even more layers to education areas, from child care to teacher qualifications, without any compensatory beneficial addition that comes with the changes.

This raises the further concern that the government wishes to window dress its response to public concerns regarding difficulties that are periodically being reported as problems in specific circumstances. Rather than following a detailed careful approach to examining what problems there are, where they occur, who is involved and how best to treat them, this government’s response is, in the case of child care services, to implement logbooks and, in the case of teachers, to implement a system of testing teachers in literature, numeracy and science prior to registration.

To examine the government’s response, one might also include a reasonable review of what is considered best practice in our global first-world society. One might also ask what government did on the basis of advice, that being the Master’s report in this case. Parts of that report have been highlighted by the member for Everton. I do not disagree with what it said.

Did it choose the most favoured option so as to reduce its own budgetary outlay and merely transfer the costs back onto teachers themselves? Did the government baulk at the tougher choices because it wanted to be seen to be doing something whilst it did it? Procrastination and wasteful financial outlays are the norm in the current Labor administration. Twenty years of nothingness and management in crisis is how policy has ended up being rolled out. Do people realise that 20 years ago, in the most formative study that was completed, Queensland was the leader in maths and science in Australia? Now nationwide Queensland is second last in the government results alone and arguably it could be said to be lowest in the NAPLAN results. This closely approximates the results in health management and the status of Queenslanders when compared to other states. It is no wonder this government has finally realised it has to do something in literacy, numeracy and science.

However, the government has discovered the value of science far too late in its life. It must have a very short memory. Several years ago when I was in parliament the former member for Inala, the father of the current member, derided a scientific approach when confronted on an issue relating to water management. He said, ‘Science has no answer for us. We have a better idea. It is a water grid and the Traveston Dam.’ We know what happened there. The member for Cairns described dams as ‘old technology’ and said ‘water comes from a tap’. Science is not always complex, but it is factually based. A purer definition is that science is about proof gathered by confirmation by experimentation, correctly conducted and recorded, and by reproducing the results. The Labor administration’s idea of science is to talk about it when the rest of the nation effectively damns it for ignoring it for so long. Similarly, the government’s belief in literacy is by saturating everyday people with propaganda such as this disgraceful state-wide personally mailed brochure outlining reasons why the state Labor government has the right to sell state assets.

This is not what the teaching of literacy, numeracy and science is about. By its actions, Labor does not believe in such a serious approach to education. For many years it has embraced a belief in a dumbing-down approach to both educational standards and values. How things come back to haunt one when such a policy is implemented! Year after year schools have reduced mathematics standards and compulsory levels taught, there has been a conscious avoidance of national standards teaching, and the government has ignored what the teachers were genuinely saying. As a result, our students’ levels declined and nothing was done. It is tough when the screw turns. I predict that it will take a generation to turn this problem around.

There has been far too great an emphasis on sport in schools at the expense of genuine education, yet far too little compulsory sport or even exercise occurs for the majority in our schools, that is, those who have no desire to become professional sports people. Now, one in five children aged below 15 are obese. Far too many students are falling through the gaps early in their schooling for reasons ranging from not being fed before school starts to terrible family circumstances. Teachers are asked to provide parenting but are unable to provide a reasonable education for the majority because of the multiple problems arising from individual students. It is almost as if children are being asked to learn for themselves. It it is all very well to teach children to learn how to acquire knowledge when they are young, but it is absolutely critical to assist them to learn both the correct techniques to do so and the essential skills that they need in life. Listening begins at the moment of birth and for most should only cease just moments before death. We never stop learning, but humans have a dreadful predisposition to learn bad habits. Sadly, laziness and ignorance are learned bad habits and they are difficult to correct.
Ms Croft interjected.

Dr DOUGLAS: If the member listened, she might learn something. To implement a top-down approach to manage a problem once identified without a parallel opposing bottom-up approach is fundamentally wrong. I was very interested to hear the Premier say that she is going to appoint extra science teachers and that the emphasis is on science, literacy and numeracy. However, the reality is that children are not continuing with science subjects in secondary and tertiary education. Mathematics is being reduced to a very secondary and basic level. If one excludes general maths in grades 11 and 12, it almost becomes an optional subject. Tragically, there is no longer a seat of mathematics at the University of Queensland. One cannot pursue a primary degree in mathematics at our major university.

If we do not put enough students through both science and maths at schools, we will never have the teachers to provide the courses for children in everyday schooling. I know a little about this. My daughter, Caroline, teaches mathematics at university. She is studying towards a PhD in mechanical engineering in New South Wales. She pursued engineering because that is the major area where maths and science retain a powerful hold. I say, ‘Thank God for the engineers’, as they are not influenced by populism because they deal in reality. Professionally speaking, they live or die on their signing off of everything from large systems to simple constructions in everyday life.

Mathematics is the core skill for life. Personally, I have studied and enjoyed it for a lifetime. It endlessly challenges and surprises. Many do not realise that it is closely related to many other studies in life, including music. It is a fundamental part of science and, via information communications technology, represents a core critical part of our lives. Computers are operated in binary code at the level of machine code. At that level the maths is both simple and complex at one time. However, it is what you do with it that makes the difference. This is the same for children learning maths, taught correctly and endlessly. It is rather simple and, indeed, it is what one does with it that makes the difference.

To make the difference in mathematics, literacy and science, teachers, parents and the community all need to be travelling in the same direction. I do not believe that this is occurring now. Far too many social agendas are still being rolled out through our public schools that bear little resemblance to that which science students need as a fundamental base to their educational needs. Specifically, subjects such as SOSE have emerged that appeal to populism and not to a factually based status. At every level children who do not reach satisfactory levels, year after year, are being pushed through or diverted into the sorts of programs that allow for lower levels of educational attainment. Often parents do not realise this, although teachers do and fear for their jobs if they speak out. Children are the victims in this dreadful scenario. It is compounded by tolerance of behaviour that in many cases is grossly unacceptable.

Australia-wide there is a progress to private education as families shrink, incomes become mobile and parents worry about their children’s lives. For most the economic cost of this is too great, but it is what they want because they want a similarity in values and educational standards to those in private education. This is based on evidence based research that I will not fully detail in this speech today. Primarily private schools do not have to respond to state government masters and, as such, can demand standards of students and teachers on a take-it-or-leave-it basis. For many, they combine it with a heavy pastoral element. Their success must be copied for all our students in public schools where it is appropriate.

In the recent NAPLAN test, many Queensland public schools did better or met equivalent standards to many private schools, but way too many fell far too far below in performance. We must truly copy all those models that are working and abandon those that are not working. This is the true lesson of NAPLAN and the formal listing of comparative school tables for parents. This must be the correct avenue for change, not only from the bottom but also from the top, and we should intervene at every level where an interventional step to assist improvement can be inserted relatively easily.

I wish to address more specifically the issue of literacy. I applaud the comments made by the Premier this morning. Parents need to encourage their children to read. Reading is one of life’s greatest pleasures. It builds on both a factual and a socioeconomic reference base from which an individual can both understand and appreciate life. Whilst all understand how critical it is to teach people to read and write, it may interest many to know how many in our present society, even with full free education, are unable to read and write. The most salient example is that 30 per cent of those in prisons are deemed to be illiterate and ATSI people now number high amongst those, whereas 20 years ago 90 per cent of them were deemed to be literate when they entered the prisons.

Literacy is a key passport to life in a modern society. Without it one is denied entry to most things in life and is assured of a life in near poverty. The most recent example of what happens when a social experiment in literacy goes wrong has occurred in Australia--
Sitting suspended from 1.00 pm to 2.30 pm.

Dr DOUGLAS: An example of what happens when a social experiment in literacy goes wrong is Wadeye in the Northern Territory, where over the last 10 years English was taught as a second language but it was not commenced until later primary school years and was not made compulsory thereafter. These children cannot read street signs, read things in shops or understand modern communication. They are excluded from everyday life. They are now too old to be largely recovered. It is a generation lost. That is the impact of failing to achieve a satisfactory level of literacy and English to grade 12 for those who finish at that level. It must be maintained as a mandatory requirement. It is equally important that teachers have proven satisfactory literacy levels that can be checked.

I found it rather compelling that during my speech here this afternoon members were seeking to know what more I could offer in the way of advice on the bottom-up approach that needs to be embraced in dealing with this very serious issue. I need look no further than the schools and kindergartens in my local area. The Nerang State School P&C meeting was held last week and I have also had conversations with my local child-care providers. I thank the outgoing chair of the Nerang State School P&C, Fiona Dryden; the incoming chair of the Nerang State School P&C, Carol Randall; and the director of the Small World Child Care Centre in Carrara, Julie Fox. This is a more grassroots approach. What they said was that teachers need more in-class support. They need a greater range of materials and funded teacher aides. They need budgets for electricity to be able to afford to run the air conditioning and stop children overheating in classes.

Nerang State School has been granted the right to be involved in the Stephanie Alexander cook-what-you-grow-at-school program. They now need a budget to be able to build a garden that can supply enough of a diverse range of vegetables to feed the children. They also need a room that is set up as a commercial kitchen that is child friendly, where a child can learn not only what to eat but also how to grow it and how to cook it. They all know what they like.

The school also needs a pool because it is in the Nerang hinterland and the local Nerang pool is not as close as it could be--there are some major roads between the school and the pool--and the lessee of the pool has increased their charges and it is too expensive to go there. On the Gold Coast it is even more important to learn to swim due to the high number of homes that have pools and also our coastal location. Also, teachers need to have upskilling to deal with children from Pacific islands whose primary language is not English as they need to raise their literacy levels substantially. It is not about teachers needing to have their registration checked; it is about upskilling the teachers and paying for that upskilling.

In child care, the log of compliance is seen as a scare tactic for the public. Most centres think it will be a nightmare to implement and run. The logs are about the most trivial things. Examples that were given were: a parent reporting a spoon left out on a bench or a staff member without a hat on their head outside, even if it is raining. It is not actually an offence or anything other than the most trivial of things. Parents are thinking it is something else. The centres all believe that nothing beneficial will come of it and it will be irrelevant.

Child-care centres and kindergartens in my electorate--and I have 23--all feel that the government rollout of the program is about having super-duper kindies. It is all about style over substance. One compared it to super-duper medical clinics. They all said that this was an excessive duplication of service when in fact it is not about service delivery. It is all very well to build these kindies, but what will they provide? Why are they being built beside existing centres? What was needed was more funding for child-care services. The government needed to provide funding for teachers’ wages and that funding needs to be recurrent. All of them said that you cannot generalise with children and that, equally, one cannot compare areas of service easily because socioeconomic status and literacy levels of parents make a significant difference. Even within one area, there can be significant differences over a distance of just 500 metres or so.

So what comes out of that? We should not generalise with children. More and more service provision is what is needed and we should not constrict it. Logbooks are a distraction. Why are we scaring parents? And we need to raise all levels of literacy and numeracy, including those of parents.

Like the shadow minister, I support the bill, but my aspirational requirements of the bill would have been far greater. I feel that the government bill is reflective of the theme that the government has consistently rolled out. It attempts to use heavy-handed, user-pays approaches for the industry to address populist demand when what was called for was an integrated partnership based, inspired professional approach built on a theme of pursuing excellence and innovation. I think logbooks are a pedestrian approach to child-care compliance. Equally I am concerned that some of the changes look like they are seeking to exclude teachers, especially supply teachers and others who generally add to the skill and pool base of our education system. I see very little benefit in the state duplicating kindergartens in an area such as my own in Gaven when there is a nearby kindergarten at Merrimac where existing services still have available spaces.
In conclusion, there is a wonderful quote by John F Kennedy which says, ‘Children are the world’s most valuable resource and its best hope for the future.’

Ms MALE (Pine Rivers--ALP) (2.36 pm): I rise this afternoon to support the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010. This piece of legislation is another step in meeting the Bligh government’s commitment to a quality and accountable education system in Queensland. It is about ensuring that parents have access to information that will enable them to make informed decisions about our most precious young Queenslanders. It is about ensuring that our teachers are fully equipped and tested to teach our kids every day. And it is about ensuring that our children get a flying start to education with quality checked early childhood teachers. This government prioritises the education of our children.

We have introduced a new year of schooling, we are building 240 new kindies and we have had the largest spend on school building works ever. As Parliamentary Secretary for Education, I am very pleased to be speaking about this bill and the many benefits it will have for Queensland parents and children alike. As a parent, I understand that choosing the appropriate care for your child is a very difficult decision. The bill before the House is designed to give parents another tool to assist them in making this really big decision.

The Bligh government has made a strong commitment to transparency and accountability in government. In this same vein, it is time that ECEC services are held accountable for the quality of their service. Queensland will be the first state in Australia to introduce a logbook of this kind. Once again we are leading the way. The Bligh government is at the cutting edge of compliance reform and we will pave the way for other states to complement the new national reforms in this area. At a national level, new standards for services are being introduced, and Queensland is taking this one step further so that parents can access important information about early childhood services.

Literacy, numeracy and science are the foundations of every child’s education. The Bligh government made a commitment to reform education in Queensland when it commissioned Professor Geoff Masters to review primary school education. We are keeping that commitment. Preregistration testing is a clear recommendation of the Masters report and will ensure that every teacher has a demonstrated ability to teach literacy, numeracy and science before they enter the classroom.

Our results in the recent NAPLAN tests show that we are improving, but we still have a long way to go. That is why we are introducing this bill today, that is why we have released a green paper which talks about moving year 7s to a specialised teaching environment and that is why we are introducing a suite of initiatives to improve outcomes in Queensland education. In addition, we have proposed a review of the quality of teacher training courses provided by Queensland universities. Queensland parents should expect quality teaching in our state schools and the Bligh government is going to deliver that quality.

Research shows that the early years of a child’s life are the most important. Queensland has been focusing on early childhood education and working with the federal government to deliver the biggest ever reforms to this sector. The amendments before the House today go to recognise early childhood teachers as qualified professionals to be registered. Registration acts as an additional check on teachers and it is important that teachers teaching a kindergarten program are able to be registered. This complements the commitment by the Queensland government to deliver universal access to kindergarten by 2014. Recognising ECEC teachers as registered is the first step, and we will look to mandate registration in the future so that every early childhood teacher is required to be registered.

This bill is an important plank in improving the quality of care for our youngest Queenslanders and in ensuring our teachers are fully equipped to educate a new generation of Queenslanders. As a parent, I urge everyone here to support the bill and, as a person and a member with a commitment to the future of our state, I commend the bill to the House.

Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (2.39 pm): I rise to support the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010. This is an important bill because education is the keystone that will deliver future success for Queensland children. The quality of our education system and the quality of education received by our children reflects directly on their quality of life as adults. Studies have also shown that the biggest influence in the quality of education received is the quality of the teaching. The first five years of a child’s life is the time when they have the capacity to learn most rapidly, and both the quantity and quality of their learning during this time creates the capacity for greater learning for the rest of their lives. It is, therefore, vital that the state government ensures that all Queensland children have the highest quality learning experiences from their earliest years.

Early learning experiences are not just about formal learning. Early learning is about creating rich learning environments and experiences, such as creating a stimulating and exciting environment that children can interact with, discuss with their friends and recreate, and then they can learn from that and grow. For young children, play is their vehicle for learning, and the quality of the experience that a child might have in play is increased by giving children a purpose for an activity. Can you build a tower that is as tall as yourself? What happens if you do this? They are then focused on finding out if something works.

For these reasons, it is vital that people working in child-care centres are qualified to enrich learning experiences for children. It is for this reason that the Bligh government is working to improve the training of supervisors in kindergartens and child-care centres. It is not just about an activity; it is about framing the activity to focus children on developing predetermined concepts which form the basis of the knowledge they will need to accelerate into formal learning at a later stage.

This bill amends the definition of ‘teacher’ to include people who supervise children in child-care centres and kindergartens that undertake an education program but are not schools. This includes recognising teachers in leadership roles, such as principals in schools, and in other organisations like kindergartens, child-care centres and TAFE. It is likely that in the future there will be formal training expectations for all Queensland teachers in kindergartens and child-care centres to ensure there will be quality learning experiences for children from a much earlier age.

In this bill, kindergarten programs will be accredited by the QSA to be delivered in the year before the prep year. This bill also ensures that the licensee of kindergartens and child-care centres complies with the licence specifications and records their compliance issues in a logbook that must be available to parents and community members at all times. This means that if a child-care centre has a compliance notice issued against it, it must be recorded in its logbook for the scrutiny of all parents of clients in the centre. Similarly, amendments or suspensions of their licence must also be recorded in their logbook. This is an important avenue for providing an open and transparent child-care service. At a time when a growing number of parents are entrusting their children to the care of kindergartens and child-care centres, it is vital that parents feel confident in the quality of the care their children are getting. The training of teachers is paramount for us to achieve the highest quality education for students.

This bill introduces preregistration testing in literacy, numeracy and science for new primary school teachers to ensure they have the capacity to facilitate learning to a high standard in the classroom. For teachers renewing their registration after a break in service, there is a renewal provision to ensure they have kept up with current teaching practice and have recent teaching experience.

This bill also provides that teachers may have their registration renewed without a ‘returning to teaching’ condition if they have been practising as a teacher--such as, for example, working in a kindergarten or a child-care centre--or if the teacher has attained experience that is recognised as relevant to teaching for the required time frame. The provisions of this bill are about adding details to the broad sweep of education legislation that will value-add to our current processes for the training and skilling of our teachers and to the development of kindergartens and child-care centres as learning centres for our children as well as places they come to when their parents are working.

Queensland has high-quality teaching staff and programs and I am proud of the quality of work they do. Queenslanders have been very well represented among university graduates and industry leaders, but now the Bligh government is ramping up expectations for teachers and learning organisations to ensure Queenslanders will continue to be competitive when they leave their formal education. I believe the professionalism of our teachers and our teacher training means they have the capacity to encompass these changes and they will be able to ramp up their outcomes to produce results that in the future are the best in the country. Kindergartens and child-care centres will become rich sources of learning for our young children and will give them the flying start to their formal education that will see them become even more successful than they have been in the past.

I am surprised at the comments from the members opposite about this bill. They do not agree with provisions in this bill and they do not agree with other measures we have put in place to ensure our children have the quality educational outcomes they need, but the LNP has no alternatives. Is the education of our children important to them? Actions, after all, do speak louder than words. I would like to thank the minister for his detailed planning and vision that will deliver not only a flying start for Queensland children but a better landing when they exit their formal education. This bill is a pivotal piece in the big picture of Queensland’s education legislation. I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs SCOTT (Woodridge--ALP) (2.48 pm): It is a pleasure to speak on the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010 today. We live in a world which is increasing in complexity, with children born today facing life in a very challenging world. We also importantly require transparency, accountability and, as much as is humanly possible, assurances that when our children are in the care of others--be they in child care or at school--they are receiving not only the best of care but also the best educational foundation for their future development.

This government is progressively introducing safeguards and innovation into our child-care sector. Earlier this month, the website of the Department of Education and Training gained the right to publish details of child-care centres guilty of serious noncompliance which they have failed to rectify. This bill will now move to the next phase of ensuring that parents have access to information regarding the child-care centre their child attends or a centre they are investigating for future child-care services for their child.

This will apply to long-day-care centres and kindergartens as well as family day care conducted in private homes. The one service not included is after-school care. Each centre will be required to have a logbook, which is available to parents on request, that will record any compliance notices as well as when issues are addressed and notices lifted. I would like to mention that most centres are of a very high standard, and it is not envisaged that there will be a high number of reported issues. However, we must be constantly vigilant.

It is also an important initiative that each pre-prep year will have a four-year trained teacher following a set curriculum to increase children’s readiness to commence school in the prep year. The announcement of 240 additional kindergartens throughout the state to give this opportunity to many more children is indicative of how serious this government is about the early years of education.

The issue of literacy and numeracy as well as science has been highlighted recently at both the federal and state level as requiring new direction and renewed vigour in our schools. However, we all know that education starts way before a child goes to school. I must commend the Premier on her initiative for each new mother in the state to receive a children’s book to encourage reading to their child.

As a result of the Masters’ review, one recommendation included in the bill is that teacher graduates seeking registration be given literacy, numeracy and science testing from the end of 2011. These areas of teaching are the basic building blocks for future learning, and it is thus vital that all of our teachers have these basic skills. We are serious about ensuring that our young students are given the skills and every encouragement to succeed in our schooling system. When I visit my schools, I am encouraged by the positive enthusiasm of teachers and principals. My schools are all national partnership schools so have additional funding for innovative programs. I believe we will see huge improvements in educational outcomes in future years, with both the federal government and our state government placing such emphasis and resources in the areas which matter most. I have much pleasure in commending the bill to the House.

Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP) (2.52 pm): Today I rise to make a brief contribution to the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill. I will be supporting the bill but, like many others before me, there will be both compliments and concerns. I do have some questions which the minister might answer in his summing-up or at the consideration in detail stage. I will flag some of the issues now. Others have been raised by other members.

I noted in the minister’s second reading speech that the bill has three objectives. One was to require licensees of child-care services to keep compliance history logbooks. The second was to implement a system for testing of persons in literacy, numeracy or science prior to their registering as teachers or prior to registering them as teachers. I appreciate that applies to new applicants in late 2011. The third was to recognise certain teacher registration.

We all, as elected members, when we wander around a community go and talk to those people who are most likely to be affected. In this case I talked to teachers, I talked to people involved in the kindergarten industry and I talked to parents. They are not all brimming with confidence. They are not all absolutely certain that this is a great step forward. They all admire the initial motivation behind the legislation, but beyond that is where they get a little concerned.

I will move to the first objective. Everyone would support in principle the strategy that sets out to protect and improve our child’s education and safety outcomes. I do, however, question the cost associated with this--the cost of time and personnel, and the cost in maintaining those logbooks. That time taken by staff and management is time which comes at a cost, and it is time which is not spent on the very people they are charged with educating, supervising and looking after. As I say, I agree in principle with the extra information to prospective parents and to parents of enrolled children, but it has been my experience throughout life that this government has a history of thinking things up but failing to think them through. Again, there is detail that is lacking here.

I remind the House again that time is money. While the government has vowed and declared that the money will not come from the state, someone will be picking up the tab. This is at a time when the industry has already undergone some changes through regulation and processes, and those costs are still being borne and rippling through. Now we are adding this new layer of misery in many circumstances. More importantly, there is no real measure of an outcome. There is no quantifiable way of measuring that, if we do this, this, and this, our children will be better served and that the outcomes will be beneficial.

This is confirmation that Labor has let down our children in the education provided to them over 20 years, because Labor has been in power for 20 years. Child safety is a motherhood statement--nothing more and nothing less. We all rally to it, but I do not see in this any great step forward or any quantum leap in addressing some of those issues. I see no real action, and that is quite typical of legislation that comes before this place. With the inclusion of issues such as trivial font sizes, this type of legislation becomes irrelevant and ludicrous. I again raise concerns, because when you get down to that level of micromanagement you are losing focus on the big picture.

Again, the second objective is admirable, but it begs the question: how could anyone who has qualified as a teacher--albeit a currently serving teacher in a casual or part-time arrangement--and who requires a new registration next year not be competent in literacy or numeracy at a primary school level? It seems to be just another new hurdle with nothing more than a feel-good factor or a headline. How on earth could someone go through 16 years of education under Labor in this state, come out university graduated as a teacher and not pass the basic numeracy, literacy or science qualification to teach our children? There is something wrong. We have had 20 years of Labor, so do not be critical of this side of the House. Those opposite have been at the wheel but they have been asleep at the wheel. You are the ones who have failed the education system, you have failed our teachers and you have failed our system. That is where the buck stops. I have heard the words ‘the buck stops’ a few times today, but it starts and ends with Labor. Do not look at this side. Look in the mirror if you are looking for fault and blame. I do applaud some of these measures, because anything you can do that is a step in the right direction--albeit you have been sprinting in the wrong direction for 20 years, and we are now starting to walk in the right direction--is a step forward.

I suspect that new graduates will be forced to pay, because we are not paying. The educational institutions can take their pick because there are so many teachers and so few positions out there. So the education system will not be picking up the tab for the test. New, prospective teachers will be the ones picking up the tab. What we do not know yet is how much that test might be, how onerous that test might be and the circumstances surrounding it. The graduates from late 2011 will certainly be caught up in that.

I say to the minister that we understand literacy and numeracy. If there are some issues concerning the competency of teachers coming out the other end of this state education system, I wonder whether history, geography or other disciplines might be added to the system later to ensure that those we empower to teach our children have some baseline knowledge and can pass that test themselves. I do accept that there may be immigrants or migrants who have a different standard, and some assessment should be undertaken prior to any registration.

In closing, I remind those opposite that our children have not been served well under Labor. Even the Premier had a stint as minister for education, and our children when compared to other states did not measure up well. It is Labor that has caused that--not the teachers. They, too, have been failed by Labor. It is the curriculum that has been laid down by Labor that has failed our children. Teachers who have spent 16 years under a Labor education system have not been served well, and now we are asking the teachers who will qualify to pick up the tab for their test.

All we really see here is no confidence, on the part of my community, in Labor and the education system. We also see another layer of bureaucracy being added. I suspect there will be countless people employed in those areas to count beans, measure beans and weigh beans. At the end of the day, that does not contribute to the educational outcomes of our children and that is deplorable. There are no measurable outcomes.

There is no way to actually determine whether anything in this bill makes a damn bit of difference--the tiniest jot of difference. That seems to be typical of legislation that comes into parliament. It is well intentioned, well meaning, well dreamt up but not well planned and not well executed. That is where we let ourselves down. This is compounded by the fact that there is no real commitment from Labor and no funding going into supporting any of this.

It will be our children and our children’s children who will pick up the tab when they come out of 16 years of education under Labor and cannot read. We need to blame Labor. We need to blame the Premier. We need to blame this government.

Ms FARMER (Bulimba--ALP)
(3.00 pm): I rise to speak on the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010. There are few more important jobs than looking after the welfare and development of our young children. Teachers, carers, child-care workers and teacher aides are some of the most critical workers in our community. As parents, we hand our children over to them day after day, week after week, year after year and trust that they will do their very best. As parents, we also trust that the government will put systems in place to ensure our children are looked after well and in such a way that they will be happy, fulfilled and able to reach their full potential.

This government has a proud record in education and early childhood. The earn or learn strategy, among other things, has seen Queensland become one of the most active participants in Australia, compared to the other states and territories, in school based traineeships and apprenticeships. We have also seen the introduction of the prep year, the rollout of 240 new kindergartens across the state by 2014--and I am very grateful that one of those is in my electorate and attached to the Seven Hills State School--and the focus on literacy and numeracy. These achievements are already on the record.

Now, with the recently announced initiatives under the banner of the Flying Start for Queensland Children we will see a renewed focus on providing the best possible opportunities for children in their early years. The transition of year 7 to secondary school, the early reading initiatives, the quality assurance across all education sectors--these new proposed reforms--are causing great excitement in the Bulimba electorate.

This bill will lay important foundations for some of the Flying Start initiatives. One of its objectives is to implement a system for the testing of persons in literacy, numeracy or science prior to their registration as teachers. This government makes no apology for expecting the highest standards for the environment in which we place our children. We know that well prepared teachers and excellent curriculum are some of the key ingredients to learning. I know, from speaking to the many excellent teachers in the schools of the Bulimba electorate, that teachers expect this of themselves.

The provision in this bill which implements the Masters recommendation that all aspiring primary teachers should be required to demonstrate, through test performances, that they meet threshold knowledge levels for the teaching of literacy, numeracy and science and sound content knowledge in these areas prior to registration as a teacher will be an important step in ensuring that our teachers are as well prepared as possible for their task. This, along with the proposal under Flying Start that the government review the quality of teacher training courses provided by Queensland universities and the support provided by schools to beginning teachers, will bring a comprehensive approach to ensuring that we have the building blocks right to provide a high-quality learning environment for our students.

It is hard being a teacher. The learning environment is complex and demanding and there are a range of student abilities to tend to. By supporting our new teachers with the appropriate training, support and accreditation and by not leaving our teachers vulnerable when they first enter the classroom we are doing the right thing by everyone--the teachers, the parents and carers and, most importantly, the students.

In addition to providing a high-quality learning environment, it is critical that as a government we are taking all steps to ensure there is a safe learning environment for our children. I wish to refer specifically in this regard to the objective of this bill which requires licensees of child-care services, other than school-age care services, to keep compliance history logbooks.

This government is committed to openness and transparency. We have already seen the passing last year of amendments to the Child Care Act to enable the Department of Education and Training to publish information on its website about early childhood education and care services that demonstrate serious noncompliance. The requirements regarding logbooks in this bill will now ensure parents and carers will have information about the quality of a service so they can make informed decisions before they book their child into a service and also monitor the service over the period in which their child is attending.

These and the previous measures will honour longstanding commitments that have been made by the Queensland government since March 2007 to provide parents with access to information about non-compliant child-care services. It will also align with the national early child development reform agenda which has a strong focus on improving the quality of services and parental access to meaningful information.

This government again makes no apology for requiring the highest standards for our children in terms of a safe environment. Again, I fail to see how the members opposite can disagree with the bill in this regard. Like many members in this House, I speak to hundreds of parents every week. I am a parent myself. When I looked at child-care centres for my daughter the most basic consideration for me was safety. There is not one parent I know or have met who does not want to make sure their children are in a safe and supportive environment. I cannot imagine that it is any different in an electorate held by an LNP member.

As a parent, particularly as a first-time parent, who might often not be aware of all the questions they need to ask, it is extremely useful to have as much information as possible about the place where one’s children will be entrusted. This is what the logbooks will provide.

There are numerous child-care providers operating in my electorate. I have spoken to many of them during the progress of this and the previous related bill. They are not frightened of being open and transparent. In fact, many of them already have systems in place to make sure parents are informed of any issues occurring at their centres. Many of them are very pleased that the early childhood sector is being afforded the attention it is by the state government and that it is being recognised for the services it provides to children at the most important time in their lives.

In talking about child-care centres, I would like to make particular mention of the Bulimba Child Care Centre. I hold this centre up as a model of care for young children. This is vindicated by the people of Bulimba and surrounding suburbs in the form of the extremely long waiting list which is in place there. I would like to thank Bev Book and Karen Brookfield, the co-directors of the centre, and the members of the management committee at the centre for the many hours they have spent with me giving me their ideas and providing a sounding board on early childhood issues in our local community and beyond, including most recently regarding the Flying Start initiatives around the Ready Reader and parental involvement programs. I have great faith in their expertise and judgement.

This is an excellent bill which establishes yet another plank in the ongoing raft of initiatives being put in place by this government to provide the best possible start for Queensland children and young people. I congratulate the Minister for Education and Training for his passion on this subject and I commend this bill to the House.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP)
(3.08 pm): I rise in support of the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010. This government is very committed to providing parents with information about licensed early childhood education and care services that fail to comply with the Child Care Act 2002. The government is taking a staged approach to this issue. The first stage, which commenced on 1 February 2010, enables the Department of Education and Training to publish information on its website about the ECEC services which demonstrate serious or repeated noncompliance that is more than minor in nature.

The second stage of amendments, which are the subject of this bill, will require licensed ECEC services to keep a compliance history logbook which will be available for inspection by any person at the service. These legislative changes are focused on services that primarily care for children under school age. However, the department is also exploring whether the website publication scheme and logbook requirements should also apply to school-age care services. This initiative will provide parents, guardians and the wider community with easy access to information about whether their local ECEC service is meeting minimum legislated standards.

Access to this information will particularly assist parents when it comes to making the sometimes difficult decision about which education service their child should attend. We know that in the majority of cases these service providers deliver quality care to our children by meeting child-care laws, but the logbooks of these providers will demonstrate their commitment to the provision of quality care because they will contain no or very little information about noncompliance by the licensee. However, for the small number of licensees who do contravene the act and who receive formal notices about such contraventions, the obligation to record this information in their logbook will ensure that parents and guardians can be informed of the licensee’s compliance history. In some cases, knowing this information may of course influence a parent’s decision about whether they feel comfortable with the quality of care a service provides and therefore whether they feel comfortable about having their child attend that service.

We also anticipate that the introduction of this scheme will motivate service providers to maintain their already high standard of care or, if they are one of the providers whose services are not always up to scratch, lift their game. We believe that licensees will be even more keen to do the right thing, not only in the interests of providing safe, supportive and nurturing care environments for children but also to ensure they are not required to enter information in their logbook about formal notices, which will be available for parents’ scrutiny. Therefore, the scheme is expected to encourage greater sector accountability and drive a culture of continuous improvement. This should raise the overall standard of ECEC in Queensland and strengthen parents’ confidence in the services in general.

The requirement to keep a compliance history logbook will apply to, firstly, licensed centre based services such as long day care, kindergartens and limited hours care and, secondly, all home based child-care services--that is, family day care. Generally, information that licensees must record in their logbook will include the name by which the service is known and the address of the service, details about the enforcement action that was taken--for example, if it was the issuing of a compliance notice or the amendment, urgent amendment or suspension or urgent suspension of a licence--the reason the enforcement action was taken as well as information about any steps the person may take to remedy the contravention. Licensees will also have to update their logbook to indicate when a suspension has been lifted or the steps the licensee took to rectify a contravention. The information must remain in the logbook for as long as the licensee holds a licence for that service.

I am aware that the department of education continues to work collaboratively with the ECEC sector to ensure providers meet standards without having to give a compliance notice or take more serious enforcement action. In the 2009-10 year to date, 5,077 monitoring visits were made across the state. The results of the visits so far have revealed a very high level of compliance. Based on 2009-10 year-to-date compliance data, only 31 from around 2,000 licensed early childhood education and care services would have been required to record information in their logbook. This logbook scheme will give parents greater certainty about the quality of an ECEC service and the extent to which a service meets the minimum legislated standards. Therefore, not only will this bill benefit parents and the wider community; it is anticipated that the changes will also be of benefit to the ECEC sector.

I want to comment on the contribution made by the member for Mudgeeraba and the concern that this bill will put a lot of bureaucratic paperwork in front of our service providers. I do not think that is entirely true. The bill before the House today clearly lays out that if our child-care services provide a level of care that meets the requirements they will not need to put anything in their logbook.
