If the member for Mudgeeraba has really talked to her constituents about the proposal in this bill then I have to disagree with her, because many residents that I have spoken to, particularly parents, feel that this is a way for the industry to lift its game. It also gives great comfort for those services that are doing the right thing that our officers will now be concentrating on those in the sector that are not doing the right thing.

The other aspect of the logbook is that it will meet the needs of people who do not have access to the web. There are still many people who do not have a computer in their home, and we need to provide that information and give them access to it. There are many people to whom providing a logbook they can access at the centre to which they take their children is of great importance so that they can have that information and be well informed. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--LNP) (3.16 pm): The Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010 makes amendments to the Child Care Act 2002 to require compliance history logbooks to be kept by child-care services catering for non-school-age kids and also amends the Education (Queensland College of Teachers) Act 2005 to implement literacy, numeracy or science testing for teachers before they can be registered. This side of the House will agree to both amendments because they offer, if managed properly, an increased chance to improve the educational standards of Queensland children and their safety.

I congratulate the minister and those opposite for introducing this bill. I also congratulate our shadow minister for his assessment of this legislation and wise advice. I also congratulate the members for Mudgeeraba, Gaven and Redlands, who have accurately described the size of the educational hole that we have dug ourselves into over the last 20 years. This bill is proof of the size of that hole and, of course, the Labor Party’s failures. The Premier and especially the long-serving members opposite share the responsibility for the poor numeracy and literacy standards of our children. I do not take any joy in saying that, because it is a sad fact that many children have not reached their full potential or realised their dreams because of a policy failure by a political party.

The aim of the amendment to the Child Care Act is to increase information available to parents about issues relating to their children’s safety, thereby increasing accountability and the child’s safety. As the shadow minister has said, this is summed up by the phrase ‘the parents’ right to information’, which we agree with and which is one of our principles. However, that is not to say that this government initiative should not be approached with caution, because it does create more paperwork for child-care centres. It is another layer of bureaucracy, and the costs and benefits must be carefully scrutinised and monitored closely.

For a balanced point of view, I will provide two pieces of community feedback. One appeared in a Sunshine Coast Daily article titled ‘Fears red tape will hurt child care’. Gwynn Bridge, the President of Childcare Queensland, said that the introduction of the log system could result in child carers becoming focused on compliance rather than looking after children. Ms Bridge is quoted as saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: My major concern is that across Queensland we have many educational zones, which are all inspected by different compliance officers ...
It is known some of these officers can be pedantic and over-zealous, which leads to paranoia among child care operators and staff.
There needs to be consistency if the log system is to work.
XML.Hansard-Body: However, Ms Lyn Albury, a teacher of 15 years at the Palmwoods Community Kindergarten, is reported as saying that she was fully supportive of the state government’s new logbook system, which will allow members of the public to access information about child-care centre staff and safety issues. She believes that any measures to make child-care providers more accountable has to be a good thing. ‘I have nothing to worry about and other providers who are doing things right don’t either,’ said Ms Albury.

It is a little bit deceptive that those opposite would paint us as being total knockers of these initiatives. We are here to support these initiatives, but we are here in the Queensland parliament to properly scrutinise these measures that have been put forward by the government. We are doing our job. We are holding the government to account.

As we have heard, child-care centres have already been hit with changes that have been made recently and are struggling to keep up with the impact of the introduction of prep year and the threat of a pre-prep year and the impending implementation of the national guidelines. Centres are bearing the increased costs associated with these changes and face decreased revenue through changed guidelines and a decreasing range of services. In order to illustrate that point of the increasing costs for child-care centres, I would like to share with the House and the minister correspondence from a local child-care service provider that I have, and which I am sure is covered by this legislation. The hardworking president of the South Kolan kindy, Tanya Jones, wrote the following to me--and other members of parliament--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Dear Members of Parliament,
We are writing to you about the recent announcement of changes to the Department of Education Kindergarten Assistance Scheme (DEKAS).
We represent a small rural C&K community kindergarten situated north of Bundaberg. The kindy has been operating for 40 years and services a radius of about 20km.

Although we can have up to 22 children enrolled, it has been some seven or eight years since we have had full enrolments. Our target age group is 3.5-4.5 year olds, or those attending prep in the following years. However, to increase our enrolment numbers we always also enrol children as they turn three. This also secures enrolments for the following year.

Because of our lower enrolment numbers, our volunteer management committee needs to fundraise quite large amounts to keep our budget balanced. For example, at this time of year we have 16 children enrolled, but started the year with 12 children. Of those 16 children, eight are pre-prep and eight are 3 year olds. Our fundraising target this year has been $12,000 with these numbers, which is very difficult for such a small group of people.

We operate for two days per week and employ a qualified early childhood teacher and a qualified assistant. Our DEKAS funding has been about 80% of wages, not including long service leave and sick pay, which is about $36,300.00 this year.

The new funding model for DEKAS which comes into effect in 2011 will fund per child and will only fund children in a pre-prep age group (3.5-4.5 years). This will have a profound affect on the viability of our kindy, as we rely heavily on our 3 year old enrolments to provide additional income through fees. The new funding model will see us getting $2,625.00 for each pre-prep child. If we go on this year’s numbers in term 4, that would be only $21,000.00. This is a difference of $15,300.00 from what we are receiving at present.

Our small rural kindergartens in our region are in a similar situation, with 3 years old enrolments filling up enrolment spaces to produce extra income for the kindy. At no time did the 3 year olds take spaces away from the pre-prep target group.
Wallaville C&K kindy at present have seven pre-prep and nine 3 year olds.
Biggenden C&K kindy at present have seven pre-prep children and seven 3 year olds.
Gin Gin C&K kindy at present have fourteen pre-prep children and six 3 year olds.

As you can imagine, being funded only for the pre-prep children will adversely affect all of these small rural kindergartens, who also have to fundraise within the present funding model to keep their budgets balanced.

We are asking the members of parliament to look at this new funding model and reconsider the decision to only fund the pre-prep children, especially in circumstances where the kindergarten is relying on the financial support that 3 years old enrolments give to the organisation.

It must also be noted that because kindy has always been available to 3 years olds in these rural areas, parents may seek other options for their 3 year olds and then not send them to the local kindy when they are of pre-prep age. This would also lose these kindergarten enrolments who desperately need the fees from these children to reduce their fundraising targets.
We implore you give this matter your due consideration.
XML.Hansard-Body: The letter is signed by the staff and management committee of the South Kolan Community Kindergarten. I will table this document.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of a letter, dated 26 November 2009, from the staff and management committee of the South Kolan Community Kindergarten to members of parliament regarding changes to the Kindergarten Assistance Scheme.
XML.Hansard-Body: The amendments to the Education Queensland (Queensland College of Teachers) Act 2005 introduce a literacy and numeracy testing scheme for teachers prior to registration. This was a recommendation by the education researcher Professor Geoff Masters as a result of his review into Queensland’s failure in literacy and numeracy testing. The aim is to lift literacy and numeracy standards in Queensland. Although the preregistration testing of teachers in literacy and numeracy and science is supported, the LNP notes that this action alone will not provide a solution to the literacy and numeracy problems that are currently being experienced in Queensland.

On 20 June, 2009 the president of the Queensland Teachers Union, Steve Ryan, stated in an online article for the Brisbane Times that the tests were a band-aid solution to a more complex problem. He stated further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It’s a much larger issue... What should occur is an investment in education and providing the resources that teachers need in those classrooms.

For some of the students who are underachieving and not reaching those literacy benchmarks, they need to be in smaller classes, they need to have better resourcing in terms of help and they are just not getting it.
XML.Hansard-Body: I agree wholeheartedly with Steve Ryan, and I say that from a personal point of view. I honestly believe that both sides of politics need to find a way to significantly boost teachers’ pay accompanied with a significant increase in professional and academic standards. That is why I am very excited about the provisions in this bill, because they are a small step towards increasing those professional and academic standards.

One of the issues relating to literacy also relates to the issue of school discipline. I think we need to introduce higher standards of discipline in our schools. Some schools are getting it; some schools are not. As part of that higher standard of discipline, I think we should have a zero illicit drugs and weapons policy, which I will speak about later.

There is a teacher, Mrs Lex Black, whose 54 years of service this year deserves to be recognised in this place during this debate. On her own, Mrs Black has significantly contributed to the betterment of the numeracy and literacy skills of many thousands of Queenslanders. If the minister is serious about positive and effective educational reform, he will contact Mrs Black, who is or was relieving at Oakwood State School today, and organise a time to sit down and talk with her about the lessons that she has learned in education over the past 54 years. I cannot think of a teacher who is more respected and loved by thousands and thousands of students.

At this point I have to declare an interest: Mrs Black was my grade 1 teacher at South Kolan State School in 1976. I had the pleasure of bumping into Mrs Black down the street and we talked about those 54 years and some of her memories. We talked about the whole revolution that came about when we went from phonics to learning whole words and the mixture in between and the coloured blocks that we used to have in grades 1 and 2. I would like to detail for the House some of Mrs Blacks’s service. Mrs Black spent one year in teachers college. From 1955 to 1959, her first posting was at the Bundaberg Central State School. From 1959 to 1964, she was at Mount Isa and then transferred to Townview State School, which is also in Mount Isa. From 1965 to 1993, Mrs Black taught at South Kolan State School, where she gave wonderful service. In 1993 she retired and then relieved at 20 country schools. Like me, Mrs Black is of the belief that country towns and country schools are the best places in which to raise children and give them an education. In 2000, once again Mrs Black became a permanent teacher. From 2000 to 2004, she was teaching permanently at Maroondan State School and then during 2005 and 2006 at Wallaville State School. Mrs Black is now back to relief teaching. I am looking forward to a time when she might become a permanent teacher again.

This morning, I asked Mrs Black why she became a schoolteacher. She said that it was something that she had always wanted to do from the age of five. She came home from school and announced to her whole family that she was going to be a schoolteacher. It never changed from that moment on. That is an indication of the great quality of teaching that she had. She loves kids and helping them progress. I asked her who her favourite student was--apart from me--and she put me back in my place very quickly and said, ‘Teachers can’t have favourites.’ I remember her warm, giving, caring nature, her patience and her love. Today, which happens to be her golden wedding anniversary, on behalf of the people of the Burnett I thank her and wish her and her family the very best and another 54 years of teaching.
Government members: Hear, hear!
Mr MESSENGER: I appreciate the interjection from the members opposite.
Mr Wilson: Can I formally interject and acknowledge the tremendous contribution Mrs Black has made to Queensland schools.

Mr MESSENGER: Hear, hear. Very well said, Minister. Now I will get into the tough stuff. We were educated in the old-fashioned way by a very strict head teacher, Mr McLachlan, who would give us the cuts if he thought it would improve our discipline and academic record. I know that many members opposite were probably educated in the same way. During my time at South Kolan Primary I can never remember seeing a fight or feeling as if I needed to fear for my safety in the schoolyard because we knew that if we stepped out of line we would get the cuts. There was the fear of God in us then. Sadly, that was not the case when I graduated to high school. Going from South Kolan Primary to high school was like going from a Utopia--although, yes, we did receive the cuts--to an island where sometimes it felt like we were in a scene out of Lord of the Flies, where bullying and intimidation was common--when compared with South Kolan Primary.

I believe that if we took care of the basics of education--safety and discipline--there would be an immediate increase in academic standards and a decrease in the incidence of student assaults and self-harm. I went to a graduation at the Burnett Youth Learning Centre in the Burnett, a wonderful learning institution doing a great job for children at risk of disengaging. I spoke with the mother of a young lad who, for the first time in his senior academic career, was excelling. This lad’s mum, herself a professional working in the medical system, was unequivocal as to the reason why he was doing so well: he was not being bullied and he was not being assaulted by other students between classes. They do not stand for that at the Burnett Youth Learning Centre. She went on to tell me that it was her professional opinion that assaults on children by other children were all too common and it was a sad fact that it is not well known or appreciated in the broader community, although events of late have brought that more to our common consciousness.

No child should have to sit in a classroom wondering if they are going to get a flogging at big lunch, at the bus stop or on the way home. This is now the 21st century and after recent tragic events it is time to take the tough decisions to protect schoolchildren and teachers from illicit drugs and weapons. When Burnett-Bundaberg parents send their children to any school they have a legal and moral right to expect the school has taken every reasonable step to ensure that the school is illicit drug and weapons free. In light of the recent tragic death and violent offences in our school grounds throughout Queensland I think that a reasonable step to ensure that a school is illicit drug and weapons free is to give the P&C, in cooperation with the principal, the option of choosing to introduce random searches by police and sniffer dogs for illicit drugs and weapons in schools. The police are already carrying out these searches on the streets and in nightclubs. Why should there be any difference inside the schoolyard? This would show bullies and thugs who want to intimidate students and even teachers with the threat of weapons that they will be caught and punished if they continue with their illegal behaviour.

If the government does not provide this option to parents and schools then I believe there will come a day when the matter will end up before the civil courts and a judge will be asking the question: has the government taken all reasonable steps to ensure that students and teachers are kept safe while on school property? If the government refuses to give parents this option of random searches then obviously the answer will be no.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Member for Burnett, whilst I appreciate the thrust of what you are saying, perhaps we could deal with logbooks in kindergartens and registration of teachers, which is set out in the bill.

Mr MESSENGER: Thank you for your guidance. I return to the provisions of the bill which, of course, are logbooks and the registration of teachers which, in part, aims to increase the academic and literacy skills of students. I will leave that point at that. I thank the minister very much for his praise and the compliment that he paid Mrs Black. That will go down a treat back home in the Burnett. I will make sure that she receives a copy of the transcript and his personal thanks. I commend the bill to the House.

Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP)
(3.35 pm): I rise to support the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill before us today which is aimed at improving the education of the children of this state. I rise in this debate because I feel the need to add some balance to some of the comments that I have heard from the opposition. We heard from the previous member that 20 years of Labor government has destroyed literacy and numeracy in this state. My career as an English teacher, and sometimes as a maths and history teacher as well, took place under National Party governments in the 1970s and 1980s. Things were no different in those days. In fact, I suspect that with regard to literacy and numeracy they were a lot worse than they are in schools today.

I taught at Calen Secondary College, Woodridge High School, Beenleigh High School and Browns Plains High School. There were students in grades 8, 9 and 10 who could not string a sentence together. They could not punctuate, did know what a verb was and had never read a book in their lives. They were excited when I read them Charlotte’s Web . This nonsense that there were glory days of education in Queensland prior to a Labor government is just that. I remember well one year teaching a group of grade 10s at Beenleigh High School. They were all lumped in the one class because they were the poorest performers at mathematics. I taught them long division that year. They had managed to get through 10 years of school without learning that. They could not multiply. By the end of the year they could multiply and they thought they were high achievers. That was in the 1980s. Things were no better then. In fact, what has changed over the last two decades is the new emphasis on education under a Labor government. There is more notice and attention given to standards and performance of our students than ever in the past.

I do not believe that behaviour has improved or not improved. I can tell members stories from my time at Browns Plains High School such as when one lunch hour students stoned a koala in a tree and killed it. I can tell members stories from Woodridge High School that are truly horrifying such as a year 10 male student who was dragging girls into the boys’ toilets. This notion that students today are less literate and numerate than we were in our day is simply incorrect and fanciful rubbish.

What I see from my own children and from my observations when I go into schools--and, let us face it, as members of parliament we do that on a regular basis--are students who are performing at very high and satisfactory levels. I look at my own children, and the quality and quantity of assignments that they have been asked to do in high school far exceeds anything I was asked to do as a student and far exceeds anything I asked my students to do when I was a teacher. As far as I can see, the standard and quality that students are producing in years 11 and 12 is much more similar to what I was producing during my university undergraduate degree than anything I was producing at school. Certainly the top half of our cohort today are producing a level of material that was unheard of for most of us.

While we are right to examine the poor performance of students throughout their school years, I think we do not want to lose sight of the fact that education has improved so much from the days when there were 35-plus students in a room, which was the case when I was teaching, or when there were barely enough classrooms. I remember every year at Woodridge High School teachers would spend the first month wandering around the school with their class trying to find a room. By the time they actually found a room half the lesson was over and the bell rang and they all moved on and did the same thing again.

In those days schools did not have school halls. When Browns Plains State High School opened with 800 kids--the next year it had 1,600 kids--we barely had a book in the library. Contrast that to the kinds of schools that we are building these days and the kinds of resources that we are giving our children.
Mr Schwarten: The lowest paid teachers in Australia, the biggest class sizes, the worst facilities in Australia and the lowest expenditure.

Ms SPENCE: I take the interjection from the member for Rockhampton, who also was a teacher in that era. He knows of the trials and tribulations that teachers faced in those days, yet we managed to produce some very good students and we tried to deliver a good quality education. Things have certainly changed, as they should and as they must. As we debate this particular topic, let us bring some common sense and intelligence to the debate. Let us not point the finger at one side of politics, because I am sure that each side of politics will try its best when it comes to educating our children.

Mr PITT (Mulgrave--ALP) (3.41 pm): I am proud of the Bligh government’s approach to education and its drive to improve results among our students. Specialised coaches and additional teachers in the areas of literacy, numeracy and science are a key step in ensuring our kids get a flying start in life. Next week, the community cabinet comes to Far North Queensland and, as part of the visit, I will have great pleasure in joining the Premier and education minister to officially open Innisfail State College. The new educational precinct is a $36.7 million investment in the local community. It will be the most modern education facility outside of Brisbane and will do amazing things to enhance employment and training opportunities for students. This is a learning opportunity that does not exist anywhere else in the state. It is just one of a range of education reforms that we are undertaking and it demonstrates this government’s commitment to providing our students with the support they need to achieve success at school and beyond.

Early childhood education and care is a priority for the Bligh government to help our youngest Queenslanders fulfil their potential. The Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010 incorporates three important amendments for the provision of high-quality early childhood services in Queensland. Firstly, it will ensure that child-care services are required to maintain a logbook of their compliance history. This logbook will assist parents in obtaining valuable information about licensed early childhood education and care centres that have previously failed to comply with the Child Care Act 2002.

Secondly, the bill will further amend the Education (Queensland College of Teachers) Act to enable the college to develop and administer preregistration testing of aspiring teachers. As we are all aware, the implementation of this testing was a recommendation of the Masters review. This is another example of the Bligh government coming through with an election commitment to improve school performance.

Thirdly, the bill will amend the Education (Queensland College of Teachers) Act 2005 to enable the recognition of certain teaching experiences for the purpose of renewing teacher registration. This is a step in the right direction in recognising the invaluable contribution made by teachers working in non-school environments like kindergartens.

I welcome the announcement in December last year that this year Mulgrave would benefit from new kindergarten services as part of the Bligh government’s pilot program. The ABC Learning Centre at Tamarind Gardens will be among the first group of long-day-care centres to be subsidised to offer kindergarten programs taught by qualified teachers as part of the government’s commitment to universal access. Having a kindergarten program combined with the convenience of long day care will be great for working parents who want their children to access quality early education. The Tamarind Gardens ABC Learning Centre is located in the fast-growing southern corridor of Cairns and I know the extra services will be welcomed by parents in our area. I also know that, as population growth will continue strongly, growth will fuel demand for early childhood education and child-care services.

As a father, the implementation of a logbook system for child-care centres is an initiative that is of particular importance to me. My wife and I can count ourselves among the vast number of families across Far North Queensland and the rest of Queensland that have two parents who work. This arrangement is common, as more families than ever are entrusting their pre-prep-age children to day-care centres and kindergartens during the working week. This year my son, Tristan, started day care in Gordonvale. Last week he picked up his first day-care cold and, as other parents would know, this meant that his mum also had her first day-care cold. He also received his first ‘love bite’ from another child. Each morning when I drop him at the centre, like other parents I expect that Tristan will be safe and will receive high-quality care. I am very fortunate that the centre he attends has wonderful staff who clearly have a genuine interest in the welfare of my son.

The amendments in this bill provide for the introduction of logbooks in child-care centres. This means that, as a parent, I will have the ability to visit Tristan’s centre and be made aware of any issues of noncompliance that the centre may have experienced. This measure offers peace of mind and ensures an open and honest relationship between service providers and parents. It also means that the community will be able to access information about whether a child-care centre is complying with minimum legislated standards.

There are many dedicated child-care workers at many good and reputable child-care centres in the electorate of Mulgrave that I represent. The owners and managers of those centres understand that the logbooks will be beneficial to their child-care centre. Because they do provide a high-quality service, their logbook will contain minimal entries of noncompliance. In this regard, the logbook serves as an incentive to maintain a high-quality service, because members of the community will be able to access information about any breaches.

As a parent, I know that this information will be invaluable when making a decision about which child-care provider to use. Ensuring that the centre that cares for a child is providing a high-quality service that meets legislated standards would play a significant role in any parent’s decision making, including mine. It is also anticipated that the logbook system will provide greater accountability in the child-care industry and will, therefore, encourage the sector to continually strive to improve. Knowing that the community will have access to the logbooks of each and every child-care provider in an area and that parents may chose between providers based on that information will motivate service providers to ensure they are consistently compliant with legislated standards. The Bligh government makes no apology for this. This improvement will increase the level of confidence that those accessing child-care centres have in those services.

The two groups within the child-care industry that will be required to keep a logbook are licensed centre based services, such as kindergartens, and family day care services. Once information has been listed in the logbook, it is required to stay in the book for as long as the licensee holds a licence for that service. It is important to note that the department will work alongside the child-care sector to ensure that minimum standards are being met without compliance notices necessarily having to be issued.

The introduction of logbooks will be advantageous to both sides of the relationship--between child-care centres and those accessing their services. For parents and the local community it provides easily accessible and accurate information about the performance of a particular centre in relation to its compliance with legislation. This creates greater confidence and comparability for parents and guardians around the service they are accessing. In addition, the need to provide this information to the community is expected to drive improvements in the child-care sector. This level of accountability to the community will ensure that service providers consistently strive to provide a high-quality service.

As I said earlier, I am proud of this government’s approach to early education and child care. We are driving reforms to meet the high expectations that parents quite rightly have. They want their children to receive the best education in Australia in a safe and secure environment. That is what we intend to deliver. It is my view that the amendments in this bill will be of great benefit to both the people of Queensland and the child-care sector generally. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (3.47 pm): I rise to support the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010 and I congratulate the Minister for Education on bringing this bill before the House. This bill highlights the benefits that have come from changes within the department of education, which now oversees early childhood services, the schooling system and the vocational education system. That means that we can deliver on development, job opportunities and training for the people of Queensland, regardless of age and regardless of where they sit in the education system.

The child-care reforms contained in this bill are part of a two-stage reform to the Child Care Act 2002 to ensure Queensland parents are getting the best possible care and the best possible information about the care being provided to their children. The first stage was the publication on the department website of repeated moderate and serious non-compliant services. This publication commenced on 1 February, 2010.

This bill comprises a second stage and requires licensees of child-care centres other than school-age-care services to display on their premises a compliance history logbook. This logbook will show the moderate and serious non-compliance issues in stage 1, as well as minor non-compliance issues. However, we need to be clear: this is only for formal non-compliance matters raised by the department and not smaller matters that are quickly rectified through the departmental investigation process. The sort of non-compliance matters we are talking about are issues where child-care centres are found not to have adequate staffing in place but do not include things like a notice to say that a tree root needs grinding to make sure it is not a trip hazard.

This change gives parents the information they need to make a decision about the care of their children--and what an important decision that is. Child-care centres are placed in a significant position of trust within our community. For a great part of the day these child-care operators are in the position of parents, having that role to supervise, care and nurture the development of young children. The reforms contained in this bill also ensure that the public can have confidence in the care being provided by our child-care industry. When constituents have raised concerns with me about child-care centres, I know that what hurts them most is often the not knowing. It is about when their child is injured and they are not told. Parents want to know what has happened to their child, what standards are being enforced at the child-care centre and what they can do about it. This logbook system gives parents that information.

I am delighted to see that the LNP will be supporting this bill, but I am concerned that we have a trend here that those opposite will support a bill but go through some insipid hand wringing trying to appease those people who have concerns about it. If they were to bring forward alternatives or amendments, we should debate them rather than have them saying, ‘I will support it, but I just want to put all my concerns on the record.’ This is the first time that the member for Burnett’s contribution has been quite a reasonable one, and I thank him for that. Many times I have got up after the member for Burnett and had to criticise most of what he said, but that is not the case on this occasion.

The other change is the introduction of preregistration of testing of teachers. This implements an important recommendation of the Masters review. Under this change, aspiring teachers are required to display a threshold level of knowledge about the teaching of literacy, numeracy and science. These are the building block subjects for our children, not only allowing them to develop further learning within the school environment but allowing them to search out further knowledge outside of school. The purpose of these amendments is not to exclude aspiring teachers but to ensure that parents and the public have confidence in the literacy and numeracy skills of teachers. I hope that not one person, after having already undertaken 12 years of schooling or maybe more and three or more years of tertiary study, fails this exam. But what we must do is ensure that our universities are changing the way they deliver their courses in teaching to ensure that by the time people graduate with a bachelor of education these young people are ready to become teachers of the future and the community’s expectations of the standards of teachers are being met.

In terms of education standards, this government has delivered such a great improvement over the last 10 years. We have seen the introduction of prep. We have seen the current rollout of 240 kindergartens--the year before prep. We have also seen the important ETRF reforms earlier this decade which introduced some great flexibility into our schools. When I graduated from high school I never thought I would go to a high school graduation and see a trainee of the year and an apprentice of the year. Our high schools with their ‘earning or learning’ requirement are now providing young people real vocational opportunities in a school setting that were never available in the past.

There has been constant reform of the education sector. This is an important next step, but this government will continue to ensure that Queensland’s education is of the highest standard possible. I congratulate the minister and commend the bill to the House.

Mr EMERSON (Indooroopilly--LNP) (3.52 pm): I rise to speak on the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill. Last week I very fortunate to attend the Helping Families Change Conference at the University of Queensland. That conference was organised by Professor Matt Sanders, who has become very well known to the community as a founder of the Triple P--Positive Parenting Program. It was a wonderful conference, with a lot of enthusiastic educators and specialists in child care and in parenting.

I was very fortunate, along with my wife Robyn, to be part of the pilot study for the Triple P program for teenagers. Whether it made me a better parent, I hope so. All members here who are parents realise the real challenges of being a parent and raising children. They also realise the significance and the role of parents in ensuring the education of their child. It is not just about child care. It is not just about schools or kindies that have a responsibility for education. It is a partnership often between parents and teachers, child-care workers and kindergarten teachers. So I was fortunate to be at that conference last week.

This bill deals with the issue of child-care services. In the last couple of weeks it has been a real pleasure to be able to attend a number of AGMs at community kindergartens in my electorate--again, seeing enthusiastic parents who are very keen to get the best outcomes for their children. This bill includes a requirement for licensees of child-care services, other than school-age care services, to keep compliance history logbooks. I can understand the need for that requirement, and I will be supporting that today. I recognise that it may create a greater administrative burden on some licensees, but it is important that parents are fully aware of what is occurring at child care and at kindy.

As I said, I attended a number of AGMs at community kindergartens. This issue was not raised at those meetings. A number of other issues were raised though including the issue of funding for those children attending kindergartens who are under 3 years. As many members would be aware, we have seen a change in the funding program and that will come into place at the beginning of next year. Historically, the state government has provided subsidies for children between three and 3 years, even though that was below the target age group for that funding.

A number of the parents came up to me during those AGMs and said, ‘My first child was here as a three-year-old and did get funding but now my younger child coming through will not be getting funding. What am I going to do?’ The alternatives for them are not great. They can raise money through their kindergarten committee, but many committees are already overburdened in terms of funding. Kindies are also looking at increasing the fees for those children. Another alternative of course is to take those children out of community kindergartens and put them into child care. This is a real challenge, because for some of those community kindergartens this could mean the end of those community kindergartens.

I have spoken to some of the kindergarten teachers at those facilities and some of the parents and they worry about the future of their community kindergarten. The parents do not want to necessarily put their child into child care but the reality is that they would get a much better subsidy by having their child in child care rather than in a community kindergarten. Also, many of the parents are not aware of this change. It is only slowly filtering through as we go through this process of AGMs at kindies. So, while the government is making some useful changes here, I ask the minister to ensure that he looks at this issue of funding for three- to 3-year-olds and the effect it will have. I am sure that he is not intending for this change in the funding to have that effect but it will have that effect.

I note that this bill will implement a system for testing of persons in literacy, numeracy or science prior to registering them as teachers and to recognise certain teaching experience for the purposes of teacher registration. I note that the minister’s second reading speech refers to the Geoff Masters review of literacy, numeracy and science in Queensland primary schools and his report A shared challenge: improving literacy, numeracy and science learning in Queensland primary schools . Geoff Masters concluded in his review that improved outcomes in literacy, numeracy and science are likely to be facilitated by a number of factors and they include access to a well-prepared teaching workforce, as the minister quite rightly says.

What the minister did not mention is that the Masters report also said that one of the most important things was direct funding of schools. Geoff Masters said that individual schools are best placed to determine the details of the resources and support they require. Appropriate funding for our state primary schools must be a priority, which is why I am concerned that as much as $100 per student in direct funding to those schools has been stripped away by the Bligh government. Earlier this month I attended a function with the Queensland Council of Parents and Citizens Associations, and I acknowledge that the minister attended as well. During that function a number of those attending came up to me to speak about this anomaly in the funding and the fact that the funding has not gone to the schools directly.

The P&Cs are also being increasingly called on, as you, Madam Deputy Speaker, would be aware, to raise funds to make up shortfalls--a task made even more difficult in the face of tough economic times. It is significant that in late 2008 the federal minister for education put this funding over and asked for it to go directly to these primary schools but, unfortunately, as many of the people at that P&C association meeting said to me, the money did not go directly to the schools. So while today we have heard from our opponents on the other side of the House about how wonderfully they have been doing in education, sadly they have not been providing the money for the schools that they were supposed to. This was direct funding, discretionary funding, that was supposed to go straight to these schools. The federal government put that money aside and it went to the Queensland government, but the Queensland government kept it aside.
Mr Hoolihan: What does this have to do with the bill?

Mr EMERSON: This is about education. We have heard repeatedly from members on the other side of the House about how well they are doing in education. We have heard about the history of the professions of the people in the House. But, sadly, when it comes to real, practical purposes for the money--the money that those principals wanted--it has not happened.

While I support this bill today, there are two crucial areas: funding for three- and 3-year-olds at kindies and that anomaly in funding--the money that should have been going to those schools. That is the true sense of what this government is about in education. The lack of funding in those two areas shows that the government is falling short. As I said, I support this bill but I raise those two issues with the minister.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (4.01 pm): I rise to speak to the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill 2010. I have to say that the other act that is being amended is very important and should be taken note of, particularly by the community. This bill came about in part as a result of the Masters report, as has been stated by previous speakers, and it has two elements. The first one is the logbook provisions. Whilst I recognise that keeping paperwork and storing information is an impost on those people who operate any facility, it is very important, as other speakers have said, that parents have confidence in the facility that they entrust their children to.

In my electorate we have excellent kindergartens and early learning centres. Very rarely, if ever, have I heard of problems in terms of their compliance. Indeed, one early childhood centre in the electorate ran into difficulties--and this was not under the current minister--because they went beyond the requirements in terms of their provision of space and toileting facilities et cetera and had a small space in their early childhood centre that was not used properly because they went, as I said, over the specification.

Once parents become familiar with the logbook, they will use it as a tool to decide where their children will attend. I certainly would use it if I had little ones. It is an easy tool to check compliance with the regulations. If centres comply with the regulations, it reflects the attitude of those who are running the facility and its resources. Whilst I recognise that there will be some impost, I think it will be a great tool for those early childhood centres and kindies that are doing the right thing and complying because they will have a way to positively reinforce their hard work.

The second element is the literacy, numeracy and science testing of students who have graduated but have not yet registered as teachers. I think all parents will welcome this but, in a way, it is regrettable that we have to do this. As other speakers have said, these are young adults who have completed maybe 16 years of education and at the end of that time they are having to prove that they have an adequate understanding of numeracy, literacy and science to be able to go into the teaching workforce. It used to be that that was a given. History has shown, though, that this additional testing has to be done to ensure that those who should be going into the teaching profession do so.

The member for Sunnybank commented on her teaching experience in the eighties and I know that several of the schools she listed were in particularly challenging areas. I am sure that, as a teacher in those areas, the member for Sunnybank saw some very sad and confronting incidents. The member also said in her contribution that some of the children there had never read a book, and I am sure that is 100 per cent true. We have noticed that the children who are not exposed to literature early in their lives--that is, their parents do not read to them of a night before they go to bed or do not read at some opportunity through the week on a regular basis--have diminished cognitive and literacy skills. I commend the Premier’s announcement in relation to reading in schools. I hope we can achieve the number of volunteers who are required to complete that job, particularly with the obligations for volunteers to be able to access the school. Those obligations are excellent but they have, in some ways, put people off volunteering.

To a great extent, the member for Sunnybank correctly compared then and now. We still do have children who have learning challenges. We have a curriculum that is extensive. We have parents who are regularly going to school and saying things like, ‘My child may be struggling with literacy. Can they drop off the LOTE program?’ because we offer such an extensive curriculum. We have wonderful teachers in the teaching system. As part of our role as legislators and decision makers, we need to ensure that they are properly recompensed, that they have opportunities for professional development, that their class sizes are appropriate to the mix of students they are required and asked to teach, and that they have appropriate resources for the task before them.

Many teachers whom you talk to love their vocation. They are very respectful of the children and desirous of those children reaching their full potential. Fundamental to them being able to achieve those goals is that they themselves have the skills. As I said, in some ways I think it is a bit sad that we have got to this point where people who have completed 16 years of schooling have to be tested to ensure their competency, but in the long run it will have benefits for the students.

I want to again put on the record my appreciation of all of the teachers in the electorate of Gladstone. I have met many of them. They are wonderful people. They are dedicated to our young people and their futures. I commend them for their dedication and application. I support the bill.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (4.07 pm): I rise to participate in the debate on the Child Care and Another Act Amendment Bill, and I also will be brief. I support the bill and the intention of the minister in what he is trying to achieve under this proposed change to Queensland law. But if we are going to require that primary school teachers be tested before they are registered and after they have been through a very extensive training program, let us see some consistency with other departments. I flag Queensland Health as an example. Let us see come consistency.

Some time ago a constituent came to see me complaining that a doctor at one of our hospitals could not be understood. I am relating this example to the bill we have before the House--that teachers need to have certain literacy skills, numeracy skills and science skills. I was stunned that we actually had an employed doctor in Queensland who could not speak English. The nurses could not understand him and the patients could not understand him. He got through the system. I give that as an example to say that, yes, we need to have this sort of testing to ensure that our professionals--be they teachers, nurses or doctors--have basic skills that we all take for granted and expect as the norm. After I raised that matter with a former minister for health I was assured that it would not happen again. Lo and behold, it did.

So I use this opportunity to ask the Minister for Education to please take the matter up with his colleague the Minister for Health to ensure that all of our overseas trained doctors, our agency nurses and our staff in our health system have the skills that we all expect and demand--just like we are proposing here in relation to our primary school teachers. It is just as important that our teachers have these skills as it is that foreign trained doctors who come into our Queensland Health hospitals have these skills.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms van Litsenburg): Order! I ask the member to please come back to the bill.

Mr WELLINGTON: I will come back to the bill, Madam Deputy Speaker. I take members to the second part of the bill which deals with the recognition of teaching experience of those dedicated persons. As stated in the minister’s second reading speech--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The bill also recognises the teaching experiences of those dedicated people who take on educational leadership roles but who are not necessarily directly involved in delivering educational programs to students in the classroom. These people include educational advisers who provide classroom teachers with curriculum leadership, guidance and support, and facilitate their professional development.
XML.Hansard-Body: I want to give the House an example of where an acting principal who was appointed by the department became the full-time principal. This principal spent most of their time in the department, and can I say what an embarrassment it was. The school fell apart. We had that many complaints. I have never had so many complaints in relation to a principal as I did at this school. It led to an investigation and eventually the principal moved on. We now have that school firing on all cylinders. It has a great principal, a great deputy, a great P&C, and the school community is united and working as one.

I raise that issue because I am concerned when I read this bill and listen to contributions from members about the involvement of the department of education in the policing and management of these notebooks and perhaps compliance issues. I am also aware of a matter involving a teacher who was stood down for over 12 months while the department investigated complaints. It concerns me that sometimes our departmental officers do not have their feet firmly on the ground. They need a reality check when they believe everything a student says, they believe everything a parent says and they give no credit to our teachers. They investigate a teacher who has been working in the schooling system for years and years, and these middle-management bureaucrats seem to think they have all the answers. I say to those middle-management bureaucrats, ‘Perhaps you need to spend some time in the classroom.’ Perhaps we should have a requirement that they need to demonstrate they have their feet firmly on the ground by spending time in the classroom and not automatically acknowledging and giving them credit for all the time they have spent in the department. I raise that matter now because sometimes we need a reality check. I think it is the Ethical Standards Unit of the department of education. That is a very important unit, but sometimes we need a reality check. We need to review the operation of these departments.

I will return to the bill before the House. I note that this bill is acknowledging teaching experiences and duties which people have performed while working as educational advisers in roles other than directly in the school. With that short contribution, I resume my seat.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (4.12 pm), in reply: I thank the Deputy Speaker for the opportunity to speak in reply on this debate. I thank all members for the contributions they have made. I will make some general observations and respond directly to some of the comments that have been made.

Firstly, I will take up some of the issues raised by the honourable shadow minister. In relation to logbooks and information about what constitutes noncompliance with the Child Care Act in outdoor settings, I am advised that this would include inadequate soft fall; poorly maintained, insufficient, dangerous or broken equipment; poorly maintained or unhygienic sandpits--for example, uneven ground causing tripping hazards--and things like that. I think that well illustrates that point.

In relation to concern about red tape, I draw the shadow minister’s attention to the observation of the member for Broadwater, who I think made a great observation. We have to get the balance right, and we believe we have struck the right balance. There is no more red tape if services are compliant and remain compliant. At this point I want to make the important point that we have a very highly responsive and responsible child-care industry in Queensland. The Office for Early Childhood Education and Care works extremely well with all of the stakeholders and across the industry. I want to commend the industry and the stakeholders for the cooperative and highly responsible approach that they take in not only protecting the safety and wellbeing of young children who are in their services now but also protecting and building upon the high reputation that our sector has in Queensland in the long term.

That is why over the years there has developed a highly cooperative relationship with the department between the Office for Early Childhood Education and Care and the sector such that there are many regular visits by officers of the early childhood care section of the department. Extensive conversations occur between those officers and particular child-care centres to ensure that they are receiving proper guidance about compliance with the relevant regulations. On occasions, correspondence is entered into between the officers and the centres to help guide better compliance with the legislation. In effect, as a last resort only compliance notices are issued where all other efforts on a cooperative basis from the department have not produced a satisfactory level of compliance with the legislation. Then one moves into the compliance notice phase.

That is a very small percentage of occasions and illustrates well that the vast majority of operators are doing the right thing. I recognise that and so does the department. It is a highly regarded and respected industry. That level of public high reputation is able to be maintained because there is such vigilance by officers and a cooperative effort undertaken to ensure that, where there may be a failure to observe proper regulation, there is proper discussion and understanding about how that can be achieved. It is only in a very small number of cases where compliance notices are issued.

As the member has indicated, there is the issue of getting the balance right between the parents’ right to know and the legitimate business interests of the operator. That is a position that I subscribe to. We believe we have struck the right balance. The pre-eminent concern ultimately has to be with the safety and wellbeing of young children and to the entitlement of parents to be well informed about whether or not that paramount obligation is being discharged by the early childhood education service that they are proposing to use or by the service that they are using.

Consultation was raised as an issue by the shadow minister. I am advised that there was very extensive consultation on the proposals in this bill as part of the consultation on measures introduced in previous legislation. That was stage 1. This is now stage 2. I was personally involved in some discussions with representatives of the various stakeholders to underline the importance of these initiatives and also the regard in which the industry is held and the representative organisations that speak for the sector.

A question was raised about compliance, and the review and the department’s actions to oversight and reflect upon whether or not the compliance mechanisms in the department are robust enough. That is underway. That has involved consultation with the industry sector. We want to ensure that there is consistency in the standard applied by the various officers in interacting with the child-care service providers; that those standards are high; that there is appropriate training for those officers; and that there is good communication between officers and child-care service providers to ensure the maximum quality outcome from compliance with the appropriate legislation.

Another issue is the demand for and supply of teachers in Queensland. Historically there has been a significant oversupply of teachers, particularly in the primary school setting. The graduates come out of various universities--I think about seven universities have education faculties. Universities are funded and essentially regulated, in terms of the degree courses they offer, at a federal level. It is based on a competitive model. The universities are doing their level best to provide the best teacher education they can for Queenslanders and others coming to Queensland.

The department has had very open conversations with the deans of education of the various universities over recent years and drawn their attention to the fact that there are far more teacher graduates coming through their education faculties than there are vacancies within the state system or, indeed, the Catholic and independent system. I am sure that is an issue the universities are considering carefully in terms of the allocation of resources they make within their universities. We will continue to urge them to carefully consider the implications of a significant oversupply of teachers from year to year and trust that that supply/demand imbalance can be addressed in due course.

I want to underline that there are many, many more people applying to teach in the Queensland state education sector than there are vacancies. There is no shortage of teachers to fill vacancies. There are particular teaching areas like science, maths and manual arts where there are shortages and some locations throughout the state where there are difficulties filling vacancies, but there is no shortage in terms of overall interest.

I turn to the issue of teacher preregistration testing. We are in the early phase in this regard. The cost of administering these tests when finalised is an implementation issue. This legislation will enable the college to get on with the work of developing and trialling these tests at this stage and then ultimately putting them into place. That will involve developing the test, putting in place the arrangements for people to sit the tests and writing support materials to assist applicants. Obviously, the cost of developing these tests is a very important consideration. The government has undertaken to fund the estimated $3.2 million cost involved in developing and trialling the tests in preparation for their launch in 2011.

We will work closely with the Queensland College of Teachers to finalise the longer term costs of delivering the tests. We will do that this year. That will involve consultation through the standard regulatory assessment process. That is consistent with normal practice. We will make sure that we consult with all stakeholders who have a legitimate interest in that.

I will make a couple of observations. I notice that the opposition spokesperson did address, in a fairly straightforward manner, the LNP’s response to this legislation. Regrettably, I observed--and I think other members on the government side might also have observed--that his view was not matched by LNP members individually. Despite protestations to the contrary, I suspect, they really spoke against the bill. They found various reasons for speaking against the bill.

It will be interesting to see whether they vote for the bill, given that their sentiments--if not entirely in words but in spirit--clearly attacked the bill in some respect or other. That does not seem to be consistent with the formal position as announced by the LNP spokesperson that the LNP will be supporting the bill. I look forward with great interest to see whether those members vote against the bill so that their conduct is consistent with the message that they have sent loud and clear in this chamber today.

I recognise the contributions made by all government members. They have identified that the initiatives in this bill are part of a significant reform of the education system in Queensland. I want to expressly acknowledge the contribution of the Leader of the House and the member for Rockhampton. They belled the cat in terms of the nonsensical illusion that members opposite are wanting us to imbibe that there was some golden era of education under the Bjelke-Petersen government. I do not need to elaborate how factually baseless is such an assertion because the Leader of the House and the member for Rockhampton belled the cat in that regard and knocked that assertion over.

Let us come to the current day. Nine out of 10, or 90 per cent, of Queensland students are achieving at the national level or above. Those on the other side seem to forget that. Yes, there are opportunities to improve--as every state, including Queensland, is doing. Queensland improved in 17 out of 20 NAPLAN test areas between 2008 and 2009. We are improving faster than New South Wales and Victoria. One needs to look at 100 per cent of the cohort and not just the 10 per cent that may not have achieved the 90 per cent national standard or above--and we recognise they need to improve--to have an across-the-board and fair-minded view about where Queensland’s education system sits relative to the other states.

If we go back to the Bjelke-Petersen era, we will not find a budget in which 25 per cent of the budget was directed to education. Some 25 per cent of this budget--some $9.3 billion--goes to education. That is unprecedented. The Bjelke-Petersen government never did that. In those years we never had top-level pay for teachers like we now have after the $1.130 billion wage agreement reached with teachers at the end of last year.

We in Queensland have equal to the best class sizes when compared to the other states, especially in the middle school years. If we were back in the Bjelke-Petersen era we would have been dragging the chain. Some $10 million a day is spent in capital to build new schools. That was not happening in the Bjelke-Petersen days. Inclusive education for children with special needs and disabilities did not happen then. The funding that is given to them now was not given to them then. I will just rule a line underneath this illusion that is being promoted by the other side about the golden era of education under Bjelke-Petersen.

I will address a couple of other points. One was made by the member for Indooroopilly, Mr Emerson, and related to the funding for C&Ks--that is, if I have heard the issue right, as he has raised it. The DECKAS funding program which operates this year and has operated for many years provides funding for 80 per cent of the salaries of C&K staff. It goes to the service; it does not go to the parents. To correct the impression that people might have, innocently acquired, of how this funding operates, I will outline how it operates. Some 80 per cent of the staff costs for C&Ks go to the service. They do not actually go to the parents.

Under the DECKAS policy, if a kindy-age child--that is, 3 to 4--does not require a place, then a younger child--that is, a three-year-old--could take up that place. The focus of the new model is on ensuring that every kindy-age child between 3 and 4 accesses the kindy. The funding targets are designed to ensure that the funds go into that year age span that is immediately preceding the prep year--that is, 4 to 5. So we are looking at kids aged 3 to 4 for the kindy program which underpins the prep program, which is for kids aged 4 to 5.
Dr Flegg: Is that through a cut-out of the three- to 3-year-olds?

Mr WILSON: As I said, the DECKAS never was formally allocating funds for kids aged three years to 4. The DECKAS funding was for kids aged 3 to 4. In the event that there was a vacancy in that cohort group, I am advised that the DECKAS funding program permitted a three- to 3-year-old child to be in that session group. The DECKAS funding was never for the breadth of kids aged three to 4; it was always kids aged 3 to 4. I am getting all of those visual indications from my advisers that that has been accurately conveyed to the member opposite on the advice that they have given me. There was one other issue that I will respond to later at an appropriate time so that I am sure that the record is clear. I do not want to mislead the shadow spokesperson or the member for Indooroopilly on the second issue that he raised, and I will address that at a later point during the debate on the clauses of this bill if the opportunity is available to me so that we can be clear on that. I commend the bill to the House.
Question put--That the bill be now read a second time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 1 to 3, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 4--

Dr FLEGG (4.32 pm): As the minister knows, we are supporting this measure, but some of the feedback is about the level of red tape and the amount of time that child-care centre staff have to spend on administrative procedures. Is it feasible that when a notice of some sort is issued to a child-care centre the detail that is required under this act to be included in the logbook could be printed off and sent to the child-care centre along with the notice so that that form that the government has printed off could be included in the logbook? It would firstly assuage some of the concern about red tape affecting the centre, but I suspect it might make the logbooks more accurate as well and get around the problem perhaps of illegible writing or a genuine misunderstanding on the part of some centres as to what information is required. It does seem to me that, given that the information will be contained in the notice anyway, it is probably not a difficult thing for the government to be able to do and it might make the system work better.

Mr WILSON: As I indicated earlier in my address-in-reply, the departmental officers work closely with child-care services where they have any concern of a potential noncompliance with the relevant regulations through close conversations and site visits and discussions about what changed behaviour or practice or other things need to be fixed. At a later stage there may be correspondence that is gone through to try to get greater clarity about what requirements need to be met. So the issue of the notice of compliance is actually in fact--not literally--a step of last resort. I would expect the departmental officers to be working closely with the industry after the legislation passes this House. They will work closely with the industry to ensure that the administrative arrangements involved in implementing this initiative are done in such a streamlined way that it maximises achieving the purpose of this legislation with the least impact in terms of bureaucratic processes and exchange of paperwork and that sort of thing.

The departmental officers will talk to the sector about how they can minimise costs in terms of sending and returning correspondence. Indeed, there may perhaps be a standard template of information made available for registering on the logbook. The legislation is very clear about the matters that do have to be registered on the logbook. In terms of whether it is administratively appropriate for a form reflecting the legislation to go out at the same time as a notice of compliance, I will leave that to the department. It is an operational matter, but I am confident that those officers will speak closely with the sector to ensure that there is only the minimum necessary administrative processes to implement a very good initiative.

Dr FLEGG: Thank you, Minister. I am pleased that that suggestion, which came from one of the child-care centres, might at least get some consideration. Minister, with the information required to be recorded in the logbooks for the child-care centres under the previous arrangement--which would still be in effect of course--where centres that breach the regulations have to be published on the website, that only dealt with moderate and severe infringements whereas the requirement to record in the logbook also applies to minor infringements, some of which are really quite minor. For example, the real-life case that was raised with me was that there was a problem with the font size of the printing on the staff member’s photo. Why has it been necessary to include such minor issues in the logbook when it was not considered necessary for the website?

Mr WILSON: The starting point from a policy point of view before the legislation was put to the House setting up the website as the vehicle for publication involved a consideration of whether or not all compliance notices should be published on the web. I believe that, quite rightly after consultation with the sector, a decision was reached that compliance notices in relation to minor matters should be excluded and that they should not be required to be published on the web, which goes to all and sundry of course, but to simply put repeated moderate offences and serious offences on the web. When it comes to a physical logbook in the centre, the view has been taken--and I think, on balance, the right view--that it is appropriate to have notices of noncompliance in relation to minor matters entered on the physical document that is only accessible at the centre and by those who are already using the centre or potentially going to use the centre because they are checking out the centre.

It was quite appropriate to do that because the parents at the centre are in a position there and then to take up with the centre manager some explanation for what that problem was. Whereas it would be quite unfair, I think, if that type of relatively low-level noncompliance was published to the world and the centre owner and manager had no practical opportunity to converse over matters that could be clarified and explained quite simply at the centre. So because the logbook is more of a traditional device accessible only by those using the centre where there is already an existing relationship between the parent and the centre owner or manager and daily conversations are able to be had about how the centre is running and any concerns that parents might have, I think on balance it is appropriate that those matters be able to be entered on the physical logbook only and then parents are in a position to have conversations with the owner or the manager.

It should be borne in mind that if the noncompliance is of a relatively minor nature--leaving aside what I trust is an anomalous example that the member gave earlier--it begs the question as to how the centre’s failure to address that issue could reach such a point. After all the efforts that officers go to to try to bring about compliance, a notice to comply is issued in relation to a minor matter. One would expect the centre, if it is a minor matter, to address it well before they get to a situation that a notice of compliance is issued. I will ask for some advice from my department about what I suspect is an entirely anomalous illustration that the member has given earlier--innocently I expect, of course. One would think that that is not a matter that--
Dr Flegg interjected.

Mr WILSON: Yes, I am sure it was, but I would like to think confidently that it was an anomalous outcome that in any event would be addressed by the review that we are doing of compliance--as to how the officers are working in the compliance area and interacting with the industry to ensure that they have the appropriate training and there are consistent levels of high-quality treatment of all of the centres to ensure that if incidents such as the member has reported have taken place then they are eliminated as far as human effort can do so.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 5 and 6, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 7--

Dr FLEGG (4.42 pm): I seek clarification from the minister in relation to clause 7 which stipulates which graduate teachers applying for registration would be required to undergo tests, which would be prescribed by regulation. Therefore, those tests are not in this bill that is being considered by the parliament. Could the minister clarify which graduates applying for registration would be required to undertake the English, maths and science tests and also confirm whether, as I have been led to believe, it would apply to teachers qualified in the primary area and the early childhood area and not to those in the secondary area--or whether, in fact, it is going to apply to all graduates?

Mr WILSON: The short answer to the member’s question is that the preregistration testing at this juncture is going to apply to those teachers who are seeking registration for the purposes of going into the primary school setting. We have already foreshadowed in the formal response to the Masters report that we would consider at a later point the issue of preregistration testing in relation to teachers who propose to go into the secondary school setting.
Dr FLEGG: I take it that would apply to early childhood teachers as well?
Mr WILSON: I am advised, yes.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 8 and 9, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 10--

Dr FLEGG (4.45 pm): I have a number of concerns in relation to this clause which the minister might like to clarify for me. If the minister has a pen, I might just set out all of my concerns to him up-front. It might be easier for him that way. Clause 10(25A) states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Literacy, numeracy or science test may be prescribed
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: ‘A regulation prescribing a test for literacy, numeracy or science.
XML.Hansard-Body: The issue was raised with me as to whether that would mean that some applicants would not be required to undertake all of those tests but possibly only literacy, only numeracy or only science because the word ‘and’ is not there, the word ‘or’ only is there. I am particularly concerned about subclause (e), which refers to the fees payable for undertaking the test. One of the issues that I raised in my contribution to the second reading debate, which I do not think the minister responded to in his summing-up, is that the government is not making a financial contribution to the Queensland College of Teachers for the acquisition of these tests or the application, or the marking, or all the other things that go along with testing. Somebody is going to have to pay. I do not think that the Queensland College of Teachers’ budget is all that flush with cash. I could be wrong. So it seems to me that the approach is going to be user pays. It also occurs to me that these tests could be quite expensive. Could the minister give me some guidance as to who is going to pay? Is full cost recovery going to be taken against those applying? Could the minister give me some guidance as to what he thinks the fees would be for graduate students taking this test?

We would all agree that it would be fairly irksome to be hit with a substantial fee in an environment where, as the minister said in his summing-up, we have a glut of primary school teachers. I think the minister was very clear that the seven education faculties around the state had overproduced primary school teachers, which has resulted in a glut. So many of the people graduating and applying for registration will be hoping for a job and, in fact, many will not get a job--certainly not in the state system and perhaps not in a school at all. The issue of the fees to undertake these tests in that environment becomes an even more important issue. So I would be very keen for the minister to clarify the issue of the fees.

There was also an issue when these tests were first mooted--and I know the Premier made some comments in relation to somebody who fails one or other or all of the tests--whether these people will simply keep resitting them until they pass or whether they would be required to go back and do some further study or whether a period of time would have to elapse before they could sit the tests again. There is also the issue of what the fee would be for a resit--for example, if somebody failed one of the three components and had to resit that component. As well, there is the issue about how long it would be before they could resit the test. There is an issue around what the fee would be to resit. Regulation would prescribe how long it is before somebody’s application lapsed if they did fail. These are important issues.

Mr WILSON: Turning to the member’s first issue relating to clause 10, the proposed section 25A ‘(Literacy, numeracy or science test may be prescribed)’, the advice to me is that parliamentary counsel advised it ought to be drafted that way.
