From a statutory interpretation and drafting point of view the expression ‘or’ includes an interpretation ‘and/or’. ‘And’ does not include ‘or’ so it does not give you the flexibility of how the test might be constructed. The test may not include matters to do with science because of the focus, at least initially, on the primary school setting, or it may include science if indeed eventually we move to the testing being expanded to the secondary sector.

While we are talking about the testing, I underline that the policy objective of the testing is to have teacher graduates coming from our universities of the highest possible consistent standard across all the university education faculties before they get into the school setting. The purpose is to have them pass those tests. No-one is interested in failing anyone. The objective is to create an appropriate high bar that reflects the quality of teaching that parents are entitled to expect teacher graduates be afforded through the education faculties of the universities. It is focused on ensuring that those responsible for training teachers, just like those responsible for training carpenters, metalworkers or any other skilled area, are required to take appropriate responsibility for having high standards of training. Graduates benefit from going through a system where they are the beneficiaries of high-quality standard training. They are the immediate beneficiaries, of course, but it is students in the education system across the three sectors who directly benefit and it is their parents who are indirect beneficiaries.

The test is a mechanism whereby we can, by working cooperatively with the universities, lift to a high consistent level the quality of teaching that graduates receive in the university sector. That will now be complemented by the work that has been foreshadowed under the A Flying Start for Queensland Children green paper. We will conduct a cooperative review with all of the universities looking at their education degrees and the teaching that is in those education degrees, particularly addressing the extent to which behaviour management matters are appropriately addressed in this modern era given the realities of the schoolroom and the school setting nowadays. They work hand in hand, with both designed to lift the quality of teaching that graduate teachers receive for their efforts at university which they are then able to take into the schooling sector.

In relation to the next point the member raised regarding the costs of the testing, in the second reading debate I did respond to his question about the costings. The department is funding the development and trialling of the tests. This is early days. There is still a lot of work yet to be done by the Queensland College of Teachers. Indeed, this legislation is carrying the legislative remit or head of power for them to formerly undertake the work that is required over the next few years.

The quantification of what the costs might be and what different matters contribute to the costs of the tests are yet to be addressed by the Queensland College of Teachers. The government will work closely with the college over the next six to nine months in getting a clearer idea about what exactly is involved in administering the tests and also the cost implications. As I indicated in my response earlier in the second reading debate, because the costs will be reflected in a regulation that will come back to this House there will be a regulatory assessment process that will have to be gone through in relation to those costs and fees that will involve open community consultation and certainly consultation with the relevant stakeholders.

On the third point the member raised in relation to resitting the test, the legislation permits any person who sits the test and does not pass the test to sit another test. They, of course, would not resit that test; they are able to sit another test. They are also able to seek feedback, of course, from the QCT in relation to how they went in the test they did sit but which they did not pass. Then they are able to make their choice, taking guidance from the Queensland College of Teachers, about whether they actually need to do some supplementary training or education to address whatever particular deficiency may have shown up in that first test.

The short point is they are able to resit another test. They do have the opportunity to pass the test. I think that is a fair thing. The objective is for graduates to succeed at a high standard. We know they are passionate about education, that is why they take it up. We want them to succeed so that they can then succeed in the classroom for the then success of students who get the benefit of their excellent education and teaching.

Dr FLEGG: The response from the minister, for which I thank him, does, however, raise some concerns. I understood him to say--he will correct me if I misunderstood because I would be very concerned if it is what he said--that teachers graduating registering for primary school would not be required to undergo the science test. One of the key recommendations was that primary school teachers feel ill-equipped from their training to teach science in primary school. Primary school science is very important. The minister will correct me if I am wrong, but if that is the correct interpretation of what he said then I am certainly very concerned for the future of primary school teaching of science if we are unable to test the teachers.

The response in relation to what fees are likely to be charged is really an inadequate response. These students are already at university; they are already studying teaching in the seven Queensland education faculties. They will have to pay fees to sit an exam after they graduate from their course. They are already on track for that. But at this point in time the minister is unable to even give a ballpark figure of whether they will be paying $25 or $250. Particularly for students who could be struggling quite a bit financially this is an extra cost they will have to pay on top of the things that happen up to graduation. Given that this bill will put in place things that will start the ball inevitably rolling, they have a right to know that.

Another issue causes me some concern. Certainly I accept that we should allow teachers who fail a subject to resit it. However, no time limit is given between when they fail and when they must resit, so there is no implication that further work, effort or study is required. Also, there does not appear to be any limit on the number of resits. The only thing that might be a limiting factor is the fees that they would have to pay to keep resitting. At this stage we cannot even enlighten them about what those fees could be. It is a concern to me that there will be either no time limit or any limit on the number of times failed teachers could continue to resit. Those three things from the last response cause me a little bit of alarm.

Mr WILSON: I would be distressed if the shadow spokesman was alarmed in any way. I will clarify the first point. The advice I gave in relation to the legal interpretation about ‘and’ and ‘or’ et cetera is correct. The bill has been drafted to create the flexibility for the test to be designed to match the destination of the intended graduate. In the case of science, it may be that teachers going into the secondary sector will not be required to teach science. Science is not bolted on to literacy and numeracy; you do not have to satisfy the science requirements if you are going into secondary teaching.
Dr Flegg: But primary teachers will have to do science?

Mr WILSON: Correct. I would expect literacy and numeracy, together with science, would apply in the primary sector. Of course, for the reasons I have just explained, that is not so in the secondary sector.

The second point relates to cost. Frankly, it would not be responsible for me to speculate about the costs of the tests at this juncture. With others they have engaged for this purpose, the Queensland College of Teachers is in the early days of developing what is involved in the testing, including the administrative arrangements and an assessment of what the costs will be. At some point that will crystalise and I am advised that there will be public consultation under the regulatory assessment process. We will be able to address that at that time. I think that is the responsible way to deal with it, when we actually have a clearer indication of what the costs will be. I do not think it would be responsible for anyone to speculate that, therefore, they will be enormous or of any particular dimension. It is appropriate for us to wait for advice from the Queensland College of Teachers, which will be given at an appropriate time, on what the estimated costs may be. At that time I will be very happy to talk to the stakeholders about that.

The third point relates to the opportunity for a graduate to sit a second or subsequent test. The regulations have the capacity to reflect what QCT might advise us is an appropriate period or number of occasions on which a graduate may sit a further test. We will take advice from the Queensland College of Teachers on that. I underline that the objective is for graduate teachers to display the content knowledge and the teaching skill that match the tests that have been designed to reflect that. Therefore, if they pass it is because they have actually acquired, by whatever appropriate means, the content knowledge and the teaching skill that has been deemed by the Queensland College of Teachers to be appropriate and to be measured by the sitting of these preregistration tests. However, it is the case that the regulations are able to reflect the period over which they could sit a second or subsequent test and how many occasions that might be in that period. We will take advice from the Queensland College of Teachers on that.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 11 and 12, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 13--

Dr FLEGG (5.05 pm): Clause 13 relates to the institutions in which teachers can spend time to maintain their currency. In the briefing and subsequently I took a little bit of time to get my head around this issue. I take this opportunity to thank the minister’s staff for the briefing that we had. They were very helpful.
Mr Wilson: I have found them so, as well.

Dr FLEGG: Sometimes we forget to say ‘thank you’, but I did appreciate the nice, frank briefing. It was a very cooperative briefing. In general, most of my concerns around this clause were satisfied. Basically it refers to someone working out of school, in early childhood, in one of the senior TAFE colleges and the like. That is as expected. I am a little concerned about the small group that includes education advisers in relation to curriculum matters. I would have thought that with people in that sort of work, one year in five spent in the classroom probably would be good for them and would not be an onerous expectation.

Taking that a little bit further, in the provisions under clause 13, does the minister know how many extra teachers would be registered who otherwise would not have been able to be registered? Excuse me if this sounds a bit cynical, but the suggestion was made that, in allowing people to be re-registered and considered to have the equivalent of classroom time when in fact they have not worked in a classroom for five years, the government may be trying to boost the number of teachers that it reports annually. Is the government putting on the books staff who are not classroom teachers and who have not been classroom teachers over the proceeding five years? I understood from somewhere that there are about 20 such people in each education area, so a couple of hundred people do not work in the classroom but would be listed on the books as classroom teachers. Could the minister comment on that? Will this result in a boosting of the number of teachers that the department reports annually, despite the fact that those teachers are five years or more out of the classroom?

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for the question. He can set aside any concern about adding to numbers. He might notice that in the briefing notes this issue was identified as an area of tidying up miscellaneous and anomalous circumstances. It has hardly been identified as a major area of new forward thrust in government policy to add to the numbers of teachers registered. To be frank, I am advised that it is responsive to discussions that have taken place between the department and the Queensland College of Teachers about some of the clouded areas that have emerged over the last five years in the operation of the existing legislation. That is what has prompted this particular amendment.

I am advised, for example, that the new provisions will require that the educational leadership being provided is both consistent and substantial. Mind you, we are dealing with renewal of registration. We are not dealing with someone who has never been registered before and we are not dealing with a provisionally registered person. It is someone who already has full registration and who needs to be renewing that registration before the expiry of that five-year period. I am advised that a person will, therefore, need to demonstrate that they have been engaged on a regular basis in providing expert curriculum and learning advice to, and mentoring for, those delivering an educational program. It is not intended that the experience of a person who is in a role that involves leadership aspects but does not have a direct link to classroom practice will be recognised. This would include a teacher who has undertaken a largely administrative or policy role such as a secondment to central office rather than one directly related to classroom practice. The bill also does not recognise the experience of a person who undertakes or engages in occasional or incidental educational leadership roles or tasks, for example, the delivery of a one-off or occasional seminar about professional development.

In relation to those formerly recognised as education advisers, they should not of course lose touch with the classroom. I acknowledge that in many cases advisers may serve only three years or less in such a role. However, in some specialised areas teachers can remain in advisory positions for longer, for example, the advisory visiting teachers in the various disability areas. In other cases, an adviser may take maternity leave directly following their term as an advisor and can only refer to their time as an adviser when identifying their recency of practice. It should be noted that teacher registrations are generally a mandatory requirement for such advisory teacher roles. Failure to recognise the role for the purpose of renewal is seen as implying a lower status for such roles when in reality we should hope to attract some of our best teachers to those advisory roles.

On the advice given to me I want to assure the shadow spokesperson that these amendments are of a somewhat technical and miscellaneous nature. They were prompted by the discussions that the department has had over recent times with the Queensland College of Teachers and acting on the basis of those discussions to try to address some of the improvements that are believed by the Queensland College of Teachers and the department to be appropriate to finetune the legislation that has been operating for about five years or so since we set up the QCT.

Dr FLEGG: I did take some comfort in those comments that were in the notes, because I think it is very important. My concern was around the integrity of the figures that we publish every year as a reliable guide. As an example, in the health department there are people who are qualified nurses and doctors but when they fill administration roles they can be counted as medical staff and professional staff. You can get a false impression of the resources that are available to treat patients. I am concerned that when we talk about teachers in the education department we are actually talking about somebody who is in a classroom teaching students. Thank you for that answer.

Mr WILSON: Can I add that I have the highest regard for the Queensland College of Teachers and the advice that it gives to us as a government. It is independent of the government. It has a wider spectrum of stakeholder representation on it, enabling it to provide the soundest advice to government. We would not be acting in this way unless we understood from the Queensland College of Teachers that this was an appropriate step on balance to deal with a reality that it has experienced over the years in administering this important legislation about teacher registration which, at the end of the day, is designed to ensure that we have quality teachers going into our classrooms across the three school sectors.
Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (5.15 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a third time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a third time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (5.15 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.LegAssembly: Crim. History Screen. Leg. A’ment Bill; Dis. Serv. (Crim. History) A’ment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill resumed from 9 February (see p. 54), on motion of Mr Wilson, and Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill resumed from 23 February (see p. 411), on motion of Mr Wilson--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bills be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SHINE (Toowoomba North--ALP) (5.16 pm): I am very pleased to be able to make a few comments in relation to this bill. It is a very large bill in size in terms of the number of pages--533 pages. It is a significant bill, besides that point. Nevertheless, as I see it, there are two main objectives to the bill. The first is to create a far more efficient system by reducing duplication with respect to the issue of blue cards, yellow cards and so on and, secondly, to bring about a consistency of approach in criminal history screening by the amalgamation of various categories of workers providing services to children. As I understand it, these are the two main thrusts of those 533 pages. I would have thought that those objectives are, on anyone’s understanding, desirable and laudable.

Looking at them more closely, the first being the reduction of duplication, specifically, this will apply to, first of all, police officers and registered teachers. In their case, police officers and registered teachers will be able to apply for an exemption from holding a blue card when providing child related services outside their professional duties. I take it that that means, for example, a teacher or a police officer being involved in looking after children apart from when they are performing police duties or teaching duties. It might be volunteering in a sporting role, scouts, girl guides or something of that nature. As I understand it from the reading of the bill, they would be able to apply for an exemption in relation to those sorts of activities. Also, blue card holders can apply for exemption from holding a yellow card. It makes a great deal of sense to me for them to be able to do that. Also, registered health practitioners, including not just doctors but also nurses and midwives, will be automatically exempt from requiring a blue or yellow card when they are providing services to children as well as adults with a disability as part of their professional duties.

The only query I have is why that automatic exemption applies to health practitioners but it does not apply to blue card holders seeking an exemption from holding a yellow card and it does not apply to police officers or registered teachers in the instance that I gave before. The minister might be kind enough to explain that. It may be because registered health practitioners are performing part of their professional duties, whereas police officers and teachers in the instance that I gave are not engaged in their professional duties but are doing something else. That may be the simple explanation.

The second point that I mentioned as being a laudable objective was consistency. We see here the amalgamation in the blue card screening of all persons providing services to children with a disability, all employees and volunteers of state government entities who are engaged in child related matters, health students undertaking placements that involve service delivery to children whether those activities are provided in the public or the private sphere, and all employees and volunteers engaged by local governments undertaking child related roles.

The only other aspect that I want to mention relates to the matters raised in the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s Legislation Alert No. 2 of this year. The comments in that document remind us of what the law of Queensland is, particularly in relation to section 4(2) of the Legislative Standards Act--that is, in the legislation that we deal with in this place, we have to have sufficient regard to the rights and liberties of individuals, particularly a person’s right to employment. It relates to disclosure of information, including personal information, to various entities that might be considering employing a person.

The Legislation Alert refers to the provision of a person’s criminal history and the provision of information concerning convictions, and very few people would have any problem with that. However, it also refers to the fact that there is provision for the exchange of information regarding charges, expired convictions and ‘information’ from interstate police. As well as that, it refers to ‘investigative information’ about certain alleged offences that did not result in a charge being laid, let alone a conviction being recorded.

The Legislation Alert also refers to the state’s legislative history that is relevant to this point and mentions that piece of legislation that was passed in the dying years of the conservative regime in the eighties--that piece of enlightened legislation called the Criminal Law (Rehabilitation of Offenders) Act. The danger is, and the point the committee raises is, that there is a continual watering down of the protections that were provided for in the Criminal Law (Rehabilitation of Offenders) Act. I certainly have a real concern about that and I think I will continue to have that concern.

The general rule that was recognised in the Criminal Law (Rehabilitation of Offenders) Act was that, after the expiration of a rehabilitation period--of five or 10 years depending on the type of offence--there was not a need to disclose past criminal convictions. In fact, there was a prohibition against people disclosing the criminal convictions. Officials considering a person’s fitness for a profession or other purpose had to disregard the conviction. There were, however, some provisions made for matters to apply where the person involved had in fact reoffended--in other words, they gave away the benefit of that act. Of course, those matters were dealing with convictions and we have come a long way since then in the sense that we now include mere charges and mere investigative information which is not even known to the applicant for the job.

I have a concern about these matters and I ask the minister to comment on those concerns in her summing-up. I congratulate the minister for the considerable amount of work that has been undertaken in the 533-page piece of legislation that we have before the House today. The protection of children is the paramount aim of the minister and the government, and I hope the parliament will see that achieved tonight. I commend the minister and the government for its efforts in this regard.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (5.26 pm): I rise to contribute to the cognate debate on the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill and the shadow minister’s Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill. It is a tragic day when we must devote nearly 550 pages of legislation to amending the systems designed to protect our children and our most vulnerable members of society. It is a sad indictment on the world we live in that these are the steps we must take to ensure certain individuals are prohibited from interacting with our children, our sick and our disabled. I sorely wish there was another way--a way that did not impinge or intrude so abruptly and completely on the rights and liberties of so many true, upstanding citizens, a way that did not overrule their rights to privacy, a way that did not create potential limitations over their employment opportunities.

Whilst I would hope a better resourced police force or corrective services or child protection services would negate the need for blue cards, yellow cards and teacher or police registration, I know it would not. So a form of criminal history screening has necessarily become an inevitable burden on law-abiding Queenslanders. The challenge now is to make that system as robust and foolproof as possible, whilst maintaining a level of simplicity that ensures the more than 500,000 history checks that are processed are done so expeditiously and with sensitivity.

I am pleased to say that both bills we are debating today achieve that. The Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to do so through reducing the duplication of such screening processes and by increasing the consistency across the screening regimes. The Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill seeks to address the protection needs of people with disabilities by ensuring they are not placed in the care of an employed carer with a violent criminal history.

If I spend a moment considering the first of these bills--the government’s screening bill--I acknowledge the efforts to reduce undue bureaucracy and red tape. It does this by the following: by allowing registered teachers and police officers to apply for an exemption from holding a blue card when providing child regulated services which are outside of their professional duties; by recognising the blue card and corresponding criminal history check of new applicants for teacher registration; by allowing exemptions for blue card holders requiring yellow cards; by automatically exempting registered health practitioners from requiring blue or yellow cards when providing services to children and adults with disabilities as part of their professional duties; by extending the renewal period for blue and yellow cards from two years to three years; by aligning the exclusionary framework of the blue card, yellow card and registration systems as much as possible; by increasing the ability within the blue and yellow card systems to access certain criminal information; and by amalgamating certain screenings into the blue card system.

As I said, each of these steps are commendable. I honestly hope that this will reduce the number of checks undertaken by the touted 100,000 in the first three years. I know that my former colleagues and many across the child protection sector--particularly those in the central screening unit--will let out a collective acclamation of joy. I know that many will rejoice at the potential improvements in processing times this will deliver. I appreciate this will also reduce costs on the various government agencies and certainly in the case of paid employees requiring a blue card.
Debate, on motion of Mr Powell, adjourned.
Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (5.30 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House:
Urges the Premier as the incoming national President of the Australian Labor Party to oppose any move to cancel or postpone the annual state conference of the Queensland Labor Party.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is interesting to note that this morning those opposite thought this was a humorous suggestion for about one minute.
Mr Fraser interjected.

Mr LANGBROEK: Why don’t you go back to your seat? Then they spent the next hour trying to get it ruled out of order because they did not want to hear this sort of debate. Very obviously the Premier is now saying that it is stupid and it is a waste of time. We are not wasting the time of the members of this House when we call on the Labor Party to listen to its local members who deserve to have a convention.

We could have moved that this House support the right of Labor Party branch members to have their say and call on the federal Labor executive to ensure the 2010 Queensland annual conference of the Labor Party proceeds. We made an invitation to all members of the caucus, to their electorate officers and to unions so that they could be represented here today to see if they are going to stand up for the Labor Party constituency. Let us have a look at the history. On 7 June last year the Premier addressed the 2009 state conference of the Queensland Labor Party at the Brisbane Convention and Exhibition Centre.

I note that when the honourable member for Gladstone suggested a similar motion--that the federal government should pass on interest rate reductions a couple of years ago--that was not objected to by the Labor Party on the grounds that it may offend the standing orders, and I thank you for your ruling this morning, Mr Speaker.

The Premier at the convention told the delegates they should support asset sales. She said, ‘Confronted with the challenges of the global recession, we offered the electorate a Labor solution.’ The mind boggles! This is a Premier so out of touch that she presents her campaign to cut from the government the jobs of thousands of rail workers, labourers and admin workers as an idea Labor should support. She appeared before an audience who had campaigned on her behalf, who did not know that when they handed out those how to-vote cards and when they stood on those booths they were selling a gross fabrication.
Government members interjected.

Mr LANGBROEK: They do not like to hear it, do they? The Premier who spruiked ‘jobs not cuts’ was out with her razor telling the party faithful to line up and cop it. So the Premier spent her last conference weekend friendless, begging for support from delegates for her previously unannounced plan to sell QR, Forestry Plantations Queensland, Queensland Motorways and the Port of Brisbane, or else asking them not to turn up for the vote. Standing at the lectern, she claimed she had a mandate for what she was doing. ‘It is a mandate with a message,’ she said. ‘We have to hear that message.’

The Premier was just 78 days out from the election, but in 78 days her popularity among the Labor faithful had crashed. There among the delegates the Premier had big problems. Like all Queenslanders, they felt--and they were--deceived, cheated and conned. It is no wonder that this Premier is running fast away from any danger that she might have to front another Labor convention any time soon. She is running as fast as her feet will take her from any forum within which Labor members might get the chance to tell the Premier what they think of her mandate.

Premier Bligh is not the only one running from the storm clouds gathering over the convention centre. She is running like a startled rabbit, but two months ago something loomed up behind her and then shot past like a bullet out of a gun. What was it? It was Prime Minister Rudd. It was Kevin Rudd, who takes the blind support of the Labor rank and file for granted. It was Kevin Rudd, whose incompetent, bureaucratic and lately deadly administration is floundering. It is Kevin Rudd under pressure from Tony Abbott and just six months or so from an election. Those opposite laughed this morning but they are not laughing now.

Today in Queensland the Premier is a lightning rod for the complaints of Queenslanders whose jobs are on the state government chopping block along with the government agencies that provide them. The Premier is a lightning rod, but the Prime Minister’s ETS has him hooked up to a high-voltage transformer of white-hot anger from across Australia. Neither want to have to explain their odorous policies or face the music from rank and file workers who have had enough of being guiled by the Prime Minister and duped by the Premier.

In this country there is a strong democratic tradition. Throughout history our political parties have valued and respected Australia’s democratic beliefs. Even today, with union bosses stacking the vote to carry Premier Bligh through the 2009 ALP conference and frogmarching ministers in and out of cabinet, the Premier’s party pays lip-service to electoral fair play on its website. This is what it says on the website: ‘Party members are the core of the Labor Party. Party members and local branches play a central role in innovative policy development.’ I say this to Labor members opposite: they may play a central role, but when it comes to power in the ALP some are more central than others.

Remember the recent findings of the Queensland Council of Unions’ poll. Just one in 10 Queenslanders supports privatisation; 59 per cent say that asset sales make them less likely to vote Labor; 66 per cent will not forget; 80 per cent think the government underestimated opposition to asset sales; 70 per cent do not agree with the share float of Queensland Rail; and 74 per cent think Premier Bligh misled the public and kept her plans secret. Premier Bligh is the incoming National President of the Australian Labor Party. The Premier gets her turn at the wheel for 12 months beginning in July, and she takes control right at the time ALP members would expect to attend their 2010 State Conference. Unfortunately for them, the Premier and other Labor figures from Queensland lobbied party bosses, and the weekend before last they agreed to cancel all state conferences in this federal election year. This is an affront not just to angry unionists demanding a special convention to roll Premier Bligh on the asset sales and to Queensland ALP members who want their say unfettered by this unfair gag. It is an affront to all Queenslanders who expect parties to honour their constitutions and to behave in an open and democratic fashion.

The image of the Prime Minister turning tail and running away from the smelly policies of the Labor Party in Queensland is a disgrace to the principles on which his party was founded. The image of the Premier barricaded in her president’s office while hardworking Labor campaigners protest outside is another disgrace. It is a double disgrace since the Premier sits here in this chamber pretending to be accountable but turning a deaf ear to her own members and supporters.

On this side of the chamber we are proud that our leaders have shown none of these cowardly tendencies. When Bob Quinn, a former parliamentary leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland, proposed dramatic reforms to internal rules governing preselection and representation within his organisation, he fronted the Liberal Party convention. At the time it was speculated that the proposals would not please the then Prime Minister, John Howard. Did Prime Minister Howard run away and hide? No, he did not. He attended and fronted that meeting, and it was the democratic view of party members that prevailed.

Similarly, shortly after Mr Howard proposed sweeping new gun laws in the wake of the Port Arthur massacre a National Party convention was due in Queensland, and again there was speculation about the likely reaction of party members. Was that National Party convention cancelled? It was not. What is more, the Liberal Prime Minister attended the Nationals conference and fronted rank and file members. That is the democratic tradition which we represent and honour in this House and across the state of Queensland. The Premier cannot follow this course and pretend to Queenslanders that she is a serious parliamentary representative. Do not climb up on the public stage and then dive for cover.

In closing, here are some of the Premier’s words from the 2009 ALP conference. ‘I have made some tough calls recently--calls I never imagined I’d be confronted with--but if there are choices to be made, I will make them.’ Premier, it is not tough to hide the government’s true intentions from Queenslanders at a time when they expect and are entitled to demand complete honesty. It is not tough to duck for cover or bow to the craven weaknesses of the Prime Minister, even if it is at some small risk to his political hide. Premier, the tough call is to give ALP members their right to have their say on the dangerous meanderings of this Labor government and that of Mr Rudd.

In her speech the Premier singled out some of the true believers: the people who have stood up to be counted and have backed the ALP in the truly tough times--women like Billie Pelling, who worked to establish the Gordonvale women’s branch of the ALP in 1963. The Premier should think about her salute to Billie Pelling and remember her obligations to members who expect their say at their annual conference. I say to the Premier: it is her call. She needs to toughen up and stand by those who have stood by her.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (5.39 pm): I rise to second the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition and honourable member for Surfers Paradise. ‘You can count on me,’ the Premier said, hand on heart, as she forced an early election upon the decent folk of Queensland. ‘You can count on me,’ said a Premier so desperate to become Queensland’s first elected female Premier that she sold out the people of this great state.

This debate is about honesty and truthfulness--two words used very loosely by members opposite. Just like the words ‘open’ and ‘transparent’, they fall from Labor members’ lips with insincere frequency and alacrity. So long had the Premier been tutored by the greatest spin doctor of them all--Beattie--she had forgotten what they meant. Fanfare, spin and a stunt a day kept voters at bay for a whole decade. But just as they were cottoning on to this vaudeville act of Beattie and Bligh, Beattie up and left before the tricks he and Bligh played on Queenslanders were revealed, before he could be blamed--
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I do not want to interrupt the creative flow of the honourable member, but you will refer to the Premier by the correct title. That way, we will maintain dignity in the debate.

Mrs STUCKEY: The former Premier left before the tricks the current Premier and Mr Beattie played on Queenslanders were revealed, before he could be blamed for plunging Queensland into a black hole of debt. The new Premier simply picked up where he left off. But rather than jump into shark tanks and other flashy stunts designed to draw the media, she preferred to don a hard hat--a hard hat here, a hard hat there, a hard hat everywhere, even when they were not warranted for safety purposes. Tony Fitzgerald’s ferocious public attack on the Bligh government’s 12 years of secrecy, cronyism and corruption in July last year, stating that Labor considered accountability to be ‘collateral damage’ in its fight to retain power, was so much of a close call for the Bligh government that the Premier was forced to hastily react to the accusations by issuing discussion papers and new legislation.

Again in August last year the Premier was telling Queenslanders they could count on her--this time to clean up the mess created by pay-per-view politics involving Labor linked lobbyists. ‘I know that tackling these issues means taking on some pretty powerful players,’ she said. Now that was close to the truth, but she did not mention these were players she played with often--players who knew the game rules and knew that if they did not pay then they did not get a say. It was Labor’s way or no highway, no railway, no resort. On 21 January this year the Premier said with regard to the sale of assets--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I do not shy away from any form of debate on this issue either in the Labor Party or outside of it.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: She should have added ‘unless I can control the outcome’, as was the case at last year’s Labor state conference when, curiously, there were voting members absent for a crucial vote on asset sales.
XML.Hansard-Body: People are not stupid. They are working out for themselves that they were tricked by this government at the last election, and they do not like it! No-one likes to be made a fool of, even less so when they place trust in someone or something such as the Premier and the Labor Party. They do not like losing the fuel subsidy. They do not like vehicle registration hikes. They do not like paying crippling costs for their electricity or their water. They do not like filling in sustainability declaration forms. They do not like being denied access to discounted solar hot-water systems. Most of all, they do not like having Queensland’s assets sold off, and particularly at bargain basement prices.

Amidst all this unrest Mike Kaiser popped into the spotlight again, hand-picked by the Premier after the fall of Morris Iemma in New South Wales. Kaiser, a self-confessed rorter from the Shepherdson inquiry, was given a plum job and a plum salary to assist the Queensland Premier. But before long Kaiser got a whiff that the Premier’s popularity was tumbling, so he jumped ship to work for the NBN project under circumstances that have raised questions of integrity. No wonder the Premier is worried about her job. Even Kaiser has deserted her!

In May 2008 then Premier Morris Iemma overturned 117 years of ALP history on sanctity of conference by introducing legislation into New South Wales for the partial privatisation of the state’s power industry. For his arrogance he fell on his own factional sword. By announcing legislation to allow asset sales of state owned entities before taking it to a state conference, the Premier was considered by some to be in breach of her own party policy. Perhaps the Premier has a case of the nervous Nellies. After all, look what happened to Iemma. She started talking about herself in the third person--a sure sign of delusional behaviour! So self-absorbed, she is no longer able to connect with the world around her. Failure to oppose moves to cancel or postpone the ALP state conference would highlight these incompetencies further and deny rank-and-file members their right to vote.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (5.44 pm): The government opposes this motion. The government opposes the pathetic waste of time that the LNP proposes to put into this parliament for the sorts of debates that one might expect to be conducted at the university Liberal versus Labor club. What we see here are members of an opposition so bereft of ideas, so bereft of an agenda and so bereft of any ability to put forward an alternative of their own that they seek to occupy the time of this parliament in a debate about the internal mechanisms of the Australian Labor Party. Well, let me say this: so impotent are they in their confected rage here that they are reaching out in a pathetic attempt to talk to the rank and file of the Australian Labor Party.

Let us understand this position. This Labor Party put this motion to a conference properly constituted and it passed through that conference. Each and every one of those delegates at that conference knew exactly what they were doing. Those of us who have been to a Labor Party conference would know that. In fact, that is all of us on this side plus at least the Leader of the Opposition, who tried to go to the last conference with the sort of success that he has had here tonight in his call to arms as one looks up at the packed public gallery. He sent out his call to arms to unionists from around the state to come and hear his contribution, to recognise that he stood as the new torchbearer for the rights of working people. I invite honourable members to cast their eyes above to see the empty gallery, because what the people of Queensland know--what every unionist knows, what every member of the Australian Labor Party knows--is that this is confected rage. This is the greatest act of deceit attempted to be perpetrated on the people of Queensland.

What we have here is a Leader of the Opposition who at his core believes in privatisation, who has voted for privatisation in this parliament, who has given impassioned speeches in favour of privatisation in this parliament, who has come into this parliament and moved amendments to the effect that public education should be provided by private corporations. And now he comes in here and asks us to believe that the confected rage that he puts forward, in a ham-fisted acting attempt, is what he actually believes! Well, none of us believes that and the people of Queensland will not believe it.

Following this debate is a bit like following Dickie Knee and Patsy Biscoe. We have the Dickie Knee of Queensland politics. If you spun him around and put a hat on it, you would not be able to tell the difference, because someone else is playing the tune. This is merely a puppet. This is merely a puppet charading in the parliament, pretending to the leader. The only difference is that someone had the good idea to stick a broomstick in the back of Dickie Knee to give him a backbone. The reality is that this is a puppeteered effort of an individual who came into this parliament and is now today a shrivelled soul--a shrivelled kernel of his former self.

We did not want him at the last conference and we do not want him at the next conference, because the Australian Labor Party will always draw on its strength--its capacity for strength and courage, its capacity to be the agents of change, its capacity to make the tough decisions for working people right around the state--and we do not need the likes of the Leader of the Opposition with his deceit, his duplicity and his spineless leadership that will not stand for anything. All through our history, through the travails and the troubles, through the times at which we have been the agents of change for this nation and this state, we have drawn upon what resides within us and we do not need--thank you very much--the woeful contribution offered by the Leader of the Opposition.

What this parliament deserves at times like this, in the one hour that is provided by the government to the opposition, is for it to put forward policy ideas. What a pathetic waste of this parliament’s time! Those opposite were carping at the start of the week that they wanted a greater opportunity to debate. They wanted a lot more time to say nothing. They wanted more speeches from ‘Lord Monckton of Warrego’--20 minutes where they do not put forward an idea. What have they done with their one hour here tonight? They come in here with the sort of UQ Labor-Liberal club agenda. This might be fascinating to the student members of the Liberal club who are occupying the Leader of the Opposition’s office and writing this tripe for him, but the reality is this: the time has come for the Leader of the Opposition to stand up and put forward a policy agenda.
Mr Langbroek: Because you say so!

Mr FRASER: No, because the people of Queensland expect an opposition to put forward an idea, to put forward a policy proposition and to not come in here and waste this parliament’s time. This government will stand on the strength and the history of the ALP as being the agent of change, of having the courage to come in here and put forward an idea. What the members opposite should do at 5.30 pm on the Wednesday of the next sitting week is come in here and tell us about their plans for job creation and service delivery and concern themselves less with those on this side.

Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (5.49 pm): This debate marks new depths in the pathetic and parlous nature of the Liberal National Party and its concern for the people of Queensland. To think that the LNP would take its time to debate a motion--a time that could be dedicated to debating any pressing issue facing the people of Queensland--about the ALP internal processes is a disgrace. This is the LNP’s opportunity to put forward policy, or hold the government to account, yet it uses it to debate the internal workings of the ALP. I guarantee that not one of my constituents will ask me where I stand on the ALP national executive’s decision on the state conference. When I am at the Meadowbrook IGA, not one person will pull me up in the aisle and ask me what is happening with that special state conference.

In 2010, the workers of Queensland and Australia have a very important choice. Prime Minister Kevin Rudd has delivered a fair and balanced industrial relations system that protects vulnerable workers from the exploitation that is at the heart of Work Choices. At the same time, Tony Abbott has come to the Australian people offering up the Work Choices policies that were rejected by the Australian electorate in 2007. The union movement of Queensland will be firmly focused on promoting the rights of workers regardless of political persuasion. Just as the union movement will do, the ALP across Australia will ensure that every effort in 2010 is spent defending the Fair Work Act and making sure that Tony Abbott does not get his hands on the rights of workers.

Let me talk about the LNP’s duplicitous and shameless attempt to appeal to the Queensland union movement’s right to be involved politically on behalf of its members. It was the LNP that tried to bring laws to this place requiring unions to spend union dues to go through expensive referenda so that they could have any say in the ALP. It was the LNP that tried to crush Queensland’s union movement through Santo Santoro’s Workplace Relations Act 1997 while at the same time stripping away from Queensland workers penalty rates and other award conditions. It was the LNP that wanted to prevent unions campaigning against people who promised to strip away the work rights of union members. Generally, that is because it is the LNP that is attacking the workers whom the union movement is defending. It was the LNP that described those who are elected by union members in this state as union thugs, union bosses and union mates. These are the same people who try to sell to Queenslanders that tired old line that unions are third-party interference, yet want to come to this chamber and defend the right of unions to represent their members politically. There was nothing clearer to show what the LNP members thought of unions when they sat here and voted for Work Choices. They simply do not understand what workers face when they try to protect not only their rights but also their dignity and their self-respect at work.

The most duplicitous member is the member for Southern Downs, with his performance on the issue of asset sales. He has descended to personal insults to those people who have been elected to represent Queensland workers’ industrial interests. He has come into this place and called union leaders pansies, jellyfish and spineless. He and his minions, such as the member for Buderim, have been secretly trying to court union leaders, asking for joint media conferences and statements with vague and unintelligible overtures that they would reverse the decision. They have been making secret phone calls to try to court our union leaders of Queensland, but they have been rejected.

As always, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is talking behind his hand. He is making secret advances while at the same time deliberately misleading workers by saying that the rail unions have supported privatisation. Unfortunately, his secret advances for an affair have been rejected. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition did not even say that he would leave his current commitment--that profound ideological commitment to crush unions, destroy public sector jobs and sell state assets. In the short-shrift response they have given to the LNP’s cheap and insincere advances, Queensland’s union leaders have shown that they can see through its cheap political opportunism. That is why the Leader of the Opposition’s letter to unions asking them to come to the debate tonight has been the own goal that it is--just like this entire debate. Unfortunately, own goals have been the story of this Leader of the Opposition’s leadership. Maybe he should realise that only half his enemies are in front of him.

Mr GIBSON (Gympie--LNP) (5.54 pm): Not since the 1950s, with Thomas Dunstan, has a member for Gympie risen in this chamber to speak in the interests of the rank and file of the Labor Party. It is as if we have entered a parallel universe. Under this Bligh government we have found a Labor Party that Thomas Dunstan and others would not recognise--a Labor Party that has sold out its core values, a Labor Party that would not know what the Labor movement was about. This is what we are seeing here.

We heard the most unpopular member of this parliament--and no doubt the state’s worst Treasurer--put forward the proposition that this motion is a waste of the parliament’s time. May I put forward to the member for Mount Coot-tha perhaps some other moments in this parliament’s recent history were a far greater waste of time. What springs to mind at first is the minute’s silence for a drug trafficker. If ever 60 seconds in this parliament was wasted, it was that motion. It was an insult to those in our community who have to deal with the issue. But another waste of the time of this parliament perpetrated on the people of Queensland by this government--and a waste of taxpayers’ dollars--was the recalling of parliament for Gordon Nuttall. That was a time that was clearly wasted. That was a time when we saw this Labor government show its true colours. So to have the member for Mount Coot-tha--the most unpopular member of this parliament, the state’s worst Treasurer--come in here and lecture us about a waste of time is indeed something that takes the cake.
Mr Hinchliffe: Did Tommy Dunstan go on like this?
Mr GIBSON: Tommy Dunstan stood for the workers of Queensland and now we on this side of the House find ourselves standing up for the workers in Queensland.

As has quite rightly been pointed out, this motion comes down to those core elements of integrity and honesty. Whilst I will not profess for a minute to understand the machinations within the Labor Party--I do not think a crack addict could understand the machinations of the Labor Party--I note with great interest the argument put forward that it is an election year and, therefore, the ALP should not be having a state conference. I thought to myself, ‘Surely, that has been done before?’ A little bit of research has shown me that in July 2007--an election year--there was a state conference. Perhaps in 2004 the ALP scrapped it? That would have been one that it would have been concerned about. No, the ALP held a state conference. What about in 2001? There was an election in that year that the ALP wanted to win. So should it have held a state conference? The ALP held a state conference. What about in the election year of 1998? Surely that was a year that the ALP suspended the state conference.
An opposition member interjected.

Mr GIBSON: There has. We have to go back beyond 1993. So the ALP has form. I understand that. In fact, there was a while there when the ALP did not hold any conferences. That must make us wonder what it is about the Australian Labor Party and its view on democracy. Surely, the ALP’s state conferences are for the same purpose that most people would think a political party has a state conference, and that is to check the views of their members--look at the attitudes to ensure that they are reflected in its policies. State conferences would be an opportunity to do that. But what do we find from this government? It is running from the idea that it might have its policies representing its own members’ views, running from the idea that perhaps its policies represent the views of Queenslanders.

Clearly it does not. We have seen from recent polls that this government is so out of touch with the views of Queensland, so arrogant and so dishonest, that its members would not know what ordinary Queenslanders wanted if they fell over it. They find themselves in a position where they are disconnected from the views of ordinary Queenslanders. The arrogant attitude they display shows that they do not deserve government.

Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading)
(6.00 pm): Groucho Marx could have had the LNP in mind when he said, ‘I’ve got principles and if you don’t like them I’ve got others.’ Where are the LNP’s principles? The answer is that they have none. This motion is all about LNP opportunism. They do not care about workers. We can see the crowd that you have drawn today. What would you do if you were in government? We know what you would do. I will give you a few examples in just a minute.
Mr SPEAKER: The honourable minister will talk through the chair, thank you.
Mr LAWLOR: What about the sheer hypocrisy of the Leader of the Opposition sending an email out today addressed to--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Dear Labor Caucus Members, and union members
Re: Urgent special motion to save Labor’s State Conference.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Leader of the Opposition had better not go into the theatre. He would close the Phantom of the Opera in one night. Have a look at the crowd. The workers’ friend? You have got to be joking. This comes from the leader of a party that confiscated millions of dollars of electrical workers’ superannuation in the 1980s. This is the leader of a party who now says he is the workers’ friend. What gets worse about the hypocrisy is that the email states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And will the Premier give Labor MPs a conscience vote?
XML.Hansard-Body: This is from a leader who two weeks ago would not give his own members a conscience vote on altruistic surrogacy. Now he is asking for a conscience vote on this ridiculous motion. I used to say back in the 1980s that I lost all interest in satire when Joh Bjelke-Petersen made Terry Lewis Queensland’s Father of the Year. However, any flickering interest I had in satire has well and truly been doused by the Leader of the Opposition tonight masquerading as the workers’ friend, saving the Labor Party and the union. What an absolute outrageous joke. I will just quote from a few things in relation to democracy.
Mr Gibson interjected.

Mr LAWLOR: I am not as versed in the history of the LNP as those opposite are. The LNP state executive has been trying to silence critics, the Leader of the Opposition being one of them, of course, and there are many of them. For instance, Gary Hardgrave has been given a show-cause notice as to why he should not be expelled. Why? The notice relates to comments he made about the state opposition being hopeless. He made the comments not as an LNP member but as a radio announcer. For telling the truth the member for Burnett was dropped from the high office of deputy whip because he dared to vote for a spill. In my opinion those opposite came to the right decision about the member for the grassy knoll. I think the right result was achieved. Everyone knows that he was 16 before he learnt to wave goodbye. The LNP has sought to silence other critics, such as Mal Brough.
A government member: Poor old Mal.

Mr LAWLOR: Poor old Mal, that is right. He was not wanted by the LNP because he dared to criticise the way the party was formed. He has also criticised--and is correct--the way it has been operated since. Even Michael Johnson is now being investigated, not that I have much sympathy for him.
Mr Johnson: He’s done nothing wrong.
Mr LAWLOR: You might be right there. Quoting from Joe Hockey--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... as a government, sold Telstra...governments shouldn’t be in the business of owning business.
XML.Hansard-Body: Quoting from John-Paul Langbroek--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: our belief that the government does not have to be involved in activities that can be best performed by private enterprise.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Leader of the Opposition has also been quoted as saying the asset sales are inevitable. Directing his comments at ETU members, Tim Nicholls has been quoted as saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: One has to ask: why not sell the poles and wires as well? Why not sell the generators as well? Most informed commentators know that this is the best solution to provide adequate power efficiently and with little risk to government.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr SPRINGBORG (Southern Downs--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition)
(6.05 pm): Contempt, arrogance and deceit. That is what we have heard from the other side of this House tonight. It was absolutely personified by the Treasurer, the most unpopular member of parliament, a member of parliament who could not even get a primary vote above body temperature. This is a guy who could not get a primary vote above 38 per cent. This is the most unpopular, useless Treasurer that the people of Queensland have ever seen. We have seen the contempt of this person here tonight. He has said to the people’s parliament that they have no right to be heard. I have news for the Treasurer and member for Mount Coot-tha: the reason that we are debating this issue tonight is because those opposite are too scared to debate it at a Labor Party convention.

This government, this Treasurer, is now bereft of any democratic principles whatsoever. They are scared of their own membership. What would those people who stood by that tree 100-odd years ago in the member for Gregory’s electorate and actually established the Labor Party think about this mob of charlatans and frauds and those people who have walked away from the principles of the Labor Party? Would those people, the hard workers of that area who actually set up this party, have walked away from a philosophical or ideological argument? No, they would not have done, because this is a party that was forged in a cauldron of adversity and austerity at the time. We may not necessarily agree with it ideologically, but you could certainly respect it. No longer can you respect it.

The reason that we are having this debate here tonight is because we have a Premier who by virtue of her position will be the incoming president of the Labor Party of Australia and she is not prepared to stand up for the fundamental, democratic rights of Labor Party members and what they are saying. As we have seen again tonight, this government does not understand the level of palpable anger that exists in the community. This level of palpable anger is accompanied by arrogance and deceit from this government. The anger actually exists because those members of the Labor Party are upset that they have been let down by this government. That is why the polls are so bad. That is why their members are upset. That is why some members of the union movement, the ones who are not two-faced--and there is only a handful of them--are out there demanding another conference. But there is only a handful. The majority of the unions behind the scenes are doing a nudge, nudge, wink, wink exercise.

Last year the unions went to the Labor Party conference. Some of them decided they would vote for privatisation, others decided they would vote against it and others decided they would not vote at all; they would go and hide under a couch somewhere. That is exactly what they did. But it was all contrived. There has been one union though that has shown at least some semblance of ticker and that has been the ETU. They have booted out a whole range of Labor members who they believe no longer subscribe to their principles. Those members are now running around homeless. The member for Barron River has found a new home today. The Australian Services Union has adopted him. The member for Cook is still running around looking for a refuge. He says he cannot find one but that it is not really a priority.

One really has to ask the question: what is the Labor Party scared of? What is the Premier scared of? Why won’t they listen to their members? Why won’t they let their members be heard? It is no accident. It is their own doing that there has been an enormous dive in the popularity of and support for this government within the community. Why is that? It is because they have deceived the people of Queensland. They have treated those people with contempt and those people want a chance to have their say.

The rank-and-file Labor members want to have their say, too. It is absolutely unprecedented that, in an election year, when the state faces such important issues, we have a Labor Premier who so arrogantly dismisses the rank-and-file concerns of Labor Party members in Queensland. Is it any wonder that her own branches have passed motions of no confidence? Is it any wonder that her own branches want her expelled from the Labor Party? There is a chance for the Premier to redeem herself. Finally she can open her ears and understand that she has, in her own hands, the chance to have this conference by virtue of her position as the incoming president of the Labor Party and not run away.
Mr SPEAKER: I call the member for Yeerongpilly.
Mr Dempsey: Be nice, Simon.
Mr FINN: I will, Jack.
Mr Johnson: What union do you belong to?
Mr FINN: The miners union.
Mr Johnson: You look like a miner!
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Member for Yeerongpilly, resume your seat. I will wait for the House to come to order.
Mr Johnson: You wouldn’t know what a pit was.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I ask the honourable member for Gregory to come to order.

Mr FINN (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (6.10 pm): Tonight with this motion the LNP plumbs new depths in its own laziness, new depths in partisan pettiness and new depths in disregard for the proper business of this House. The time for this debate is set aside on the Notice Paper to enable the opposition to interrogate the actions of government, to debate the policy framework of the government and to showcase itself as the alternative government. It gets to do that in here, in the House, on the record and accountable to the people of Queensland. But what do we see tonight? We see cheap partisan political point scoring. How is it the business of this House to debate a decision of the Australian Labor Party national executive regarding the scheduling of internal party forums? How is it the best use of Her Majesty’s opposition’s time to have this debate and how does this debate showcase an alternative government? The fact is that it does not.

The LNP is saying, ‘What you get from us is what you have come to expect from us: a deep and enduring focus on the internal divisions of politics.’ This showcases the one thing the LNP has mastered over the years, which is petty division. There are a couple of aspects to this debate I will comment on. The first is the Leader of the Opposition calling for a government conscience vote on this motion. What a joke! In the Australian democracy, the role of the conscience vote is well understood by everyone except those opposite. A conscience vote is determined by the matter before the House, dealing primarily with issues of a moral, ethical or religious nature. Last week we saw an example of matters like this in the debate on the surrogacy bill. That debate required members to consider their core values and evaluate issues of gravity affecting the rights of children. That debate had strong lobbying by religious and civil rights organisations. What did we see from the opposition in the surrogacy debate? We saw a party lockup and the denial of a conscience vote for its own side. The matter before the House today--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. The member will resume his seat and I will wait for the House to come to order.

Mr FINN: The matter before the House tonight is not a matter for a conscience vote. It is a petty partisan stunt. However, I say to the Leader of the Opposition that if that is what he believes then he should give his members of parliament a conscience vote on this motion. He should tell them there will be no repercussions for not supporting the motion. He should tell them they will not be sacked as committee chairs and they will not be sacked as deputy whips. He should tell them there will be no repercussions. He should say this: ‘If you think this is the best use of our time, then support the motion.’
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Stop the clock. The House will come to order.

Mr FINN: He should tell his members, ‘If you think this is the best use of the time allocated to you, to raise issues of ALP conferences, then support the motion.’ He should also tell them this: ‘If you think we should be debating education issues rather than ALP conferences, you can vote against it. If you think a better use of our time would be to debate health or the economy rather than ALP conferences, then vote against it. If you think we should be presenting our own policy framework as an alternative government, rather than debating ALP conferences, then vote against it.’ But he will not do that.

The national executive of the Labor Party is considering a resolution requiring state branches to seek national executive support prior to holding conferences. This is about ensuring the party is focused on delivering the best outcome for working families during a critical election year. State conferences require significant resource allocation in their organisation and administration. They take several months of work--arranging travel, accommodation for delegates, lead-up committee work, publication preparation and so on. However, let there be no mistake that the Australian Labor Party’s national organisation is focused on one aim: ensuring we do not return to the antiworker policies of the Liberal and National parties, and we make no apologies for that. There is nothing sinister or secret about it. In fact, the only sinister aspect is the threat of a Tony Abbott government and the return to individual worker contracts. The ABC has reported Tony Abbott as saying he would relax unfair dismissal laws and reintroduce statutory non-union contracts if he won the election. He said, ‘That is what we had under the Howard government and that is what we need to have again.’ The Labor Party will remain focused on never returning to the LNP’s Work Choices world and we will not shy away from it. We will do whatever we can to protect working families.

Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (6.16 pm): I rise to support the motion that was moved by the Leader of the Opposition and seconded by the member for Currumbin. The member for Currumbin defined tonight’s debate when she said that this is a debate about honesty and integrity. It is not so much a debate about a policy decision. It is not a debate about the sell-off of Queensland’s assets, per se. It is a debate about the honesty and integrity of the Premier. It is a debate about the honesty and the integrity of the Labor government.

It was instructive to watch the government members who had to respond to the proposition that the Premier take a small step to partially redress the anger that has been caused by her lack of honesty and her lack of integrity. What was the response of those Labor members? We have seen an outpouring of insult and invective like this parliament has seldom seen before. If one listened to the members on the other side of the House, one would think that this debate was about the LNP. Attacking the LNP does not cure the problem. Attacking the LNP does not hide the dishonesty and the lack of integrity that was involved in this decision which has angered Queenslanders across-the-board, not so much for the decision itself but for the sneaky way in which it was made. It has not just angered Queenslanders across-the-board; it has also angered the core supporters of the Labor Party, the Premier and the government that made it because it was cloaked in dishonesty and lacked any integrity. It was done without any of the normal processes that should be part of our democratic processes.

The motion before the House tonight gives the Premier and the government a small chance to redress some of that anger. They have singularly refused to provide an explanation as to why they are not prepared to do that. Members have used this opportunity to insult anyone who suggests they should do that. Members such as the member for Brisbane Central typify the hypocrisy of Labor members of this government. The member for Brisbane Central is the classic union parasite, who comes into this House on the back of workers, who makes a career of having her hand in workers’ pockets and then, when she gets into this place, completely abandons the principles that she espoused to get here.

If those members believed those principles that they espoused to get here they would be voting with us tonight. They would be voting to give those people whom they represent an opportunity to have a say, an opportunity to express an opinion, an opportunity to let the Premier and the government know what they think about the decision that was made with so much dishonesty and such a lack of integrity.

That is only the first step. The motion before the House tonight asks that the Premier give the Labor Party rank and file members the opportunity to express an opinion about the decision that was made with so much dishonesty. If the Premier wants to restore the confidence in her government she should give the people of Queensland the opportunity to have a say--to have the say they should have had. If the Premier wants to restore that confidence, she needs to give the people of Queensland the opportunity that she denied them at the election. She went to an election without telling them of the plan. She went to the election without telling them that $15 billion of their assets were to be sold off. It is no wonder that the decision made so soon after the election has caused the anger that it has. That decision is never going to be considered properly by the people of Queensland simply because of the sneaky and underhanded way in which the decision was made. The decision itself is not the subject of this debate. It is a debate about honesty and integrity. It is clear from the government’s response tonight that it has no interest in addressing that dishonesty, it has no interest in redressing that lack of integrity. If it did it would, like us, be supporting the motion that was moved by the Leader of the Opposition as a first step in that process.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (6.21 pm): I understand a number of people on this side of the House have referred in this debate to whether or not this is a useful use of the parliament’s time. I am actually intrigued by the fascination being shown by those opposite for the machinations of the Australian Labor Party. I am very happy to feed their fascination. Nothing gives me more pleasure than talking about that great Australian political institution, the Australian Labor Party.

The Australian Labor Party is the oldest political party on the Australian political landscape. We are one of the most cohesive political forces in the political history of this country. That is because we run a well oiled, disciplined, united team that has a sense of purpose.
Opposition members interjected.

Ms BLIGH: They do not like it. I can understand why those opposite would be so fascinated, because such an entity is unknown to them. Their care and concern for the members of the Australian Labor Party is touching and I thank them for it, and I am happy to reveal a few things to them tonight.

Firstly, let me tell them about the national executive of the Australian Labor Party. This is a body elected by the party and is authorised to act in the best interests of the party. It is driven and motivated by a desire to put the party in the best position to campaign, develop policy and to put those policies to the Australian electorate.
Mr Schwarten: What is that word again? Policy?

Ms BLIGH: Yes, policy. Let me give them a second revelation about the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party is a parliamentary party. That means it is a party formed to compete at elections and a party that wants to win those elections. What is the national executive?
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The House will come to order.

Ms BLIGH: The motion, as I understand it, that is before the national executive at its next meeting, a motion that is yet to be resolved or considered but which is before the national executive, is a motion that recognises that 2010--another revelation--is a federal election year. The motion acknowledges that in a federal election year the party will be on a campaign footing--no apologies, we are a political party and we are on a campaign footing in a federal election year. Do members opposite know why? Because we want to defeat Tony Abbott. Defeating Tony Abbott is the best thing that we can do for the working families of this country. Defeating Tony Abbott means putting an end to the denial of climate change. It means putting an end once and for all--we would have thought it happened in 2007, but no--to Work Choices, but it is creeping out of the coffin again. We will put an end to Work Choices completely. Tony Abbott was the architect of Work Choices, and the national executive of the Australian Labor Party will be putting all of its national resources, all of its effort, all of the time of the party available this year into defeating Tony Abbott.

I understand that the leadership of John Howard, particularly on the issue of gun control, was raised here this evening. It is a particularly apt example because John Howard did not go to that election promising gun control. John Howard faced circumstances that demanded that he act and he acted. He acted and withstood--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. The House will come to order.
Mr Seeney: An outrageous comparison--absolutely outrageous!
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member for Callide! The House will come to order.

Ms BLIGH: He acted as he should have in a moment of supreme leadership against a revolt within his own party led by people like the member for Callide. He knew what the right thing to do was and he had the courage to do it. Do honourable members know what he did? He was not deterred by the critics. He acted to do the right thing when the circumstances demanded it. I acted to do the right thing when the circumstances demanded it. We set a course. We will go the distance--
Mr Seeney: You knew. You knew before the election. You knew before the election. You lied.
Mr SPEAKER: Stop the clock. You will withdraw that comment immediately. It is unparliamentary.
Mr SEENEY: I withdraw.

Ms BLIGH: Like John Howard, we set a course when the circumstances demanded it. We have the courage to go the distance. We will not be deterred by critics. We will campaign to win the federal election.

XML.Hansard-Body: Sitting suspended from 6.33 pm to 7.30 pm.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill
