XML.LegAssembly: Crim. History Screen. Leg. A’ment Bill; Dis. Serv. (Crim. History) A’ment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill resumed from p. 491, on motion of Ms Struthers, and the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill resumed from p. 491, on motion of Mr Cripps--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bills be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (7.30 pm): As I was saying, all of these elements are worth while, but I cannot help feeling what could have happened if only the government had taken the process one step further. This amendment bill only amends the three separate criminal history screening processes. It does not revolutionise them. It does not deliver a single streamlined approach to ensuring individuals with inappropriate criminal histories are prevented from working with our most vulnerable. There was an opportunity here to produce one system that had in-built flexibility to ensure the various sectors--be they child care, child protection, education, disability, health or policing--were all appropriately accommodated.

This amendment still relies on extensive cross government, cross agency communication. No matter how much a government can claim to operate within a whole-of-government approach, when you are dealing across layers of bureaucracy, when you are dealing with multiple criminal recordings, gaps will occur, mistakes will be made. Sure, this bill will reduce the likelihood of such to some extent but it could have achieved more.

Whilst I support the government’s bill, I am also disappointed it did not take the opportunity to strengthen the protection to our most vulnerable. It is clearly about the applicant--the individual requiring the criminal history check--and the government agencies that must undertake them. As commendable as this is, it is not about the children we are trying to protect or the adults with disabilities who need certainty and safety in their care. This is why I also support the shadow minister’s bill.

The Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill would raise the bar with regards to criminal history screening for nonfamilial disability carers. It would implement an automatic disqualification from employment in such a role for someone with a criminal conviction or charge for a violent offence in the last seven years. Quite simply, people who have violent histories should not and will not be placed in a position of responsibility over vulnerable people.

The shadow minister has previously enunciated a range of cases that could have been prevented had this piece of legislation already been in place. In short, it is a necessary improvement to the protective system as it pertains to the care of adults with disabilities. As I said earlier, it is tragic that we must implement such a cumbersome and restrictive system on what is by far a predominantly law-abiding citizenry. It is my hope that both of the bills when passed will streamline and strengthen that system to make it less cumbersome and more effective in protecting the most vulnerable in our society. I commend the bills to the House.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (7.33 pm): I rise tonight to make a contribution to the cognate bills--the government’s Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 and the opposition’s Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill 2009, which was introduced by my colleague Andrew Cripps, the shadow minister for disability services and multicultural affairs. The purpose of this legislation is to reduce duplication and increase the consistency across the criminal history screening system, including education, disability services and child safety. I will be supporting the proposed amendments by the LNP which also seek to safeguard the wellbeing of disabled people who are placed in the care of an employed carer and to ensure that people with a violent criminal history are precluded from becoming a carer of a person with a disability.

Almost 18 months ago, my colleague Rosemary Menkens raised in parliament the issue of a carer with a non-conviction criminal history assaulting a person with a disability who was in his care. The Labor government took no action, and subsequently a private member’s bill was introduced into the parliament in October 2009 by the member for Hinchinbrook. The Bligh government has now introduced a mirror of the LNP bill which we believe is significantly overdue. The government’s bill, like the LNP’s bill, seeks to provide protection for people with disabilities, ensuring that they are not placed in the care of an employed carer with a violent criminal history.

Of particular interest to me are the amendments to the Nursing Act 1992, which provides the following exemptions in relation to the nursing profession whereby registered health practitioners, including nurses and midwives, will be automatically exempt from acquiring either card when they are providing services to children and adults with a disability as part of their professional duties. A person with a disability is in a position of vulnerability and must be able to trust their wellbeing to an employed carer. Both the LNP’s and the government’s bills seek to ensure that we are putting safeguards into legislation which seek to protect some of the most vulnerable members of our community. I commend the bills to the House.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (7.35 pm): As has been said, this is a cognate debate on the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill and the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill. We support both bills. The opposition’s bill, as previous speakers from the opposition benches have said, was initiated by the member for Hinchinbrook. His actions were precipitated by a carer with a non-conviction criminal history assaulting a person with a disability who was in his care. The government’s lack of action led to the member’s response.

As has been said, the government has introduced this bill with its stated aim as being streamlining bureaucracy rather than protecting the vulnerable. The government claims that this is to reduce duplication and increase consistency across criminal history screening systems and make legislative amendments regarding short-term approvals for restrictive practices.

All I can say is ‘What’s past is prologue,’ which is a quote from The Tempest . The three medical related acts affected by this bill are the Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act 1999, and I would also say that it does embrace the health practitioners act 2009, and I will explain why; the Nursing Act 2002; and the Coroners Act. Obviously the changes relating to the Coroners Act lie primarily in the area of law and justice so comments relating to that area need to be made in reference to largely non-medical issues. I will leave that to other speakers.

Registered medical practitioners have an automatic exemption from requiring a blue or yellow card when providing services to children or adults with a disability. I join with the member for Toowoomba North and his concerns for giving an automatic exemption to health professionals, and I will explain why. My concerns are specifically in reference to the amendment to the Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act 1999 and I will refer my comments only to changes to this act and changes to relevant acts associated with it. I will leave it to other speakers to review those acts that are affected and that are in areas of their own personal interest or expertise.

The critical issue that applies to medical practitioners is the change to section 384A(4) of the act, which relates to what must be recorded and the disciplinary matter, immediate suspension et cetera. The change to section 384A(5) will be--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Subsection (6) applies if the children’s commissioner--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) requests further information about the disciplinary action, immediate suspension or section 311 action...
XML.Hansard-Body: A section 311 action, for those who may not know, is that section of the act under which the board--that being the Medical Board of Queensland--may take action on the basis of foreign law. In simple terms, this applies to a foreign registrant, who could be a naturalised citizen or other, where, one, the registrant’s registration, licence or certification under a foreign law relating to the registrant’s profession is suspended or cancelled for a reason relating to a matter for which disciplinary action could be taken under this act; or, two, conditions are imposed on the registrant’s registration, licence or certification under a foreign law relating to the registrant’s profession for a reason relating to a matter for which disciplinary action could be taken under this act.

Before becoming too overtly technical, this Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act is quite different to the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Act 2009 in the following ways. The Commonwealth template legislation is not necessarily inclusive of these issues in their totality, but it could be argued that now there is a progression to the authority of the national board and, where applicable, their state or regional designate boards.

This then implies that reference to the sections in the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Act 2009--those sections being 135, 140, 144, 148, 150 and 151 of the Commonwealth template legislation--will have to apply either by default or by subordinate legislation. Sections 5 and 6 of the amendment to this bill in part mimic or closely replicate the exact words of the Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act 1999 but enable the capacity of the children’s commissioner to have written notice of all types of potential offences that I have previously detailed--that is, disciplinary action, immediate suspension, section 311 actions and all other issues.

Before moving to those issues, I put it to the health minister, the Attorney-General, the Premier and the Solicitor-General that I see a weakness that becomes immediately apparent. I suspect it is a gap, but I think it is more than a technical one and I believe it may be utilised by an astute but potentially dangerous offender--in this case, a medical professional--who may seek to use the transition from state to federal responsibility as an issue of denial of authority effectively, because there are no retrospective clauses or even possibly a choice not to be inclusive of a specific series of amendments to the new health practitioners act--that is, the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Act 2009.

This act is really an agreement between health ministers. I am quite happy to stand corrected, but I would be concerned even if the High Court eventually upheld the right of the Commonwealth law to be applied. In that time delay an offender might be able to continue offending or escape justice in the most extreme case, or in the most minor case deter appropriate judicial authority from promptly dealing with that situation. In this situation, the children’s commissioner might be delayed in being correctly and promptly informed to prevent the offence on the vulnerable individual.

The critical reason is that the Commonwealth has no legislative authority currently in this area of health. I must ask that these matters be carefully considered and no superficial decision be made, as we have seen in the past how very determined offenders have wreaked such havoc on our systems by evading boards which fail miserably to protect the public interest when the demands of government for urgently available professional medical staff were placed ahead of proper due diligence on the alleged offenders. I say this because googling certain people discovered medical offenders and then immediately raised concerns when the board’s more extended due diligence allegedly found no improper behaviour orders against the practitioners.

The next issue I would like to raise in the amendment to the Health Practitioners (Professional Standards) Act 1999 is raised in sections 7 and 8 of the same clause--clause 217. I would merely like to highlight that the draft changes seek to protect the identity of the child. Secondly, the board gives the children’s commissioner information about disciplinary action, suspension or whether it is set aside on appeal--this is a very important change--and, one, that the act, action or suspension has been set aside and, two, the reasons given by the entity that set aside the action or suspension and the reasons for setting it aside.

Interestingly, in the Legislation Alert there were quite a few issues raised, but this one obviously was not raised. I think it should have been, but possibly it was overlooked because of the detail. It does raise issues of denial of natural justice and restriction of rights and liberties. It is for that very reason that I have to endorse and praise the actions of the member for Hinchinbrook, whose approach in his private member’s bill was to clearly annunciate that the benefit of the doubt must rest in favour of the vulnerable. If the law cannot or will not protect these people, then change it so it can.

As I say, I support both bills and would ask that they both be supported in a bipartisan approach. I have raised issues that I believe will upset some of those who considered that the Commonwealth template--that is, the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Act--was not really included in it and in fact is not discussed. But, in fact, I believe it is drawn into it. It is not through fear that the law will not apply. It is the potential for delay where harm may occur.

State health ministers might be fooling themselves if they believe new boards will be utterly compliant with their wishes. Whilst the minister retains the authority to overrule boards, it is not specified when and where those reserve powers may be used. I raised this issue in my speech in this House on 28 October 2009. Interestingly, in the changes New South Wales has opted out and has opted to control its own complaints handling, investigation and review mechanisms. Some felt that this would enable some people to escape to New South Wales and avoid detection. Equally, it may beef up its due diligence and identify and report those people to the children’s commissioner, as is the case with this bill. It may follow, then, that all investigation of medical practitioners might eventually drift towards New South Wales. We could have avoided the cost here, but I doubt we will. I think that it will only amplify the cost. As it is a user or service entity pays system, I think it may well do so.

This then leads to the very difficult issue of mandatory reporting and all that would seem to stem from it by the act that has come about. This criminal screening act seems to raise issues where it may well apply. Just as was raised when the new bill last year--that is, the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law Act 2009--was proclaimed, opposition members spoke clearly about the consequences and the varied types of consequences when you have mandatory reporting. I think what was said, in summary, was that all sorts of people who never thought they would be drawn into this now will be. Many will refuse to report. I guess we are potentially going to see the consequences of it.

In an interjection to my speech, the minister said that doctors should not be treated any differently. Unfortunately, with this type of act that follows, and which I believe links in, I believe the potential problems that we raised will come about. I think we are going to have to wait and see. There is a lovely saying that parents teach their children in childhood the consequences of their actions. Indeed, it is the wise and prudent who always think things through. There is that wonderful quote from Romeo and Juliet that said, ‘A plague on both your houses,’ which is what happens when you institute laws that come back to bite you.

In simple terms what I have been trying to say is that this bill relies on comparable screening standards and timing of the behaviour of relevant boards. In this case I am discussing the Medical Board. I believe the assumption is flawed. I say this because currently in Health there is a transition to both a national board and a review mechanism. In New South Wales that mechanism is slightly different. A new health practitioner has come about to implement this. I see institutional weaknesses that may lead to potential gaps that do not appear to have been raised and certainly have not raised alarms where I think they should have. I believe there is clear evidence on past experience and that it has necessitated us to move to a national board of registration and certainly a review of these health acts. Furthermore, health may be more complex for a system that is seeking to simplify procedures and that may have been believed. That was why I endorsed the comments of the former Attorney-General and member for Toowoomba North.

I have discussed with the shadow minister what I have raised, and closely reviewed the acts and all the relevant literature associated with them. My recommendation is that medical practitioners be excluded from this process until the issue is clarified. It is not exclusion so as to treat them as higher bodies but represents a more powerful approach to dealing with a group with clearly a greater power and open access to vulnerable people. I will be writing to the health minister with my concerns. We support the intent of the bill. I personally see no other major issues in my more superficial overview of the other areas.

Hon. PG REEVES (Mansfield--ALP) (Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport) (7.48 pm): It gives me great pleasure to rise to speak in support of the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill. The Bligh government is committed to providing children with a safe and loving home environment and protecting them from harm or neglect. To help make sure our children are safe, it is necessary to undertake criminal history checks on people working with children. In Queensland there are multiple screening regimes in place including the blue card system. This bill will reduce the duplication of criminal history checks. At the same time it will maintain the stringent controls that protect our children. It will do this by linking existing screening systems to avoid multiple criminal history checks being undertaken. The number of screenings will be reduced by around 100,000 in the first three years of implementation. This system will be simpler to understand. If you work with children you need a blue card unless you qualify for an exemption

Child safety officers will also now be screened under the blue card system rather than the department’s screening system. The bill also has some practical benefits for both sides of my portfolio--Sport and Child Safety. For sporting clubs, it will get volunteers on the ground sooner--and we can only hope that we will get more sports coaches, managers and the like. For example, if police officers or teachers want to work at their local sporting club, a criminal history check may not need to be conducted as it has already been done for them to undertake their professional duties.

This is also the case for people who would like to become foster or kinship carers. Carers may be able to provide a safe and loving home for our children sooner because screening will not be duplicated. However, we will maintain the checks and balances that mean that our carers go through an extensive screening and training process before being approved.

Aside from criminal history screening, the assessment and approval process involves a household safety study, a health and wellbeing questionnaire and medical checks, if required. We have one of the most stringent child protection systems in the country, and the commission has reported that 98 per cent of children in care in Queensland feel safe. Tonight when we pass this legislation, hopefully it will increase the number of potential foster and kinship carers and also increase the number of volunteers at local sporting clubs. I commend the bill to the House.

Ms JOHNSTONE (Townsville--ALP) (7.50 pm): I am pleased to rise tonight to participate in this cognate debate. The Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill allows a number of changes that will provide protection to two groups needing special protection in Queensland--children and people with a disability. The amendments will also provide a number of benefits to our community. The obvious intention of changes to criminal history screening is to maintain rigorous protections for these vulnerable groups.

In addition to these fundamental protections, the proposed changes also mean that registered teachers and police officers will be able to apply for exemptions from holding a blue card as they have been screened to undertake their professional duties. This will save them the cost of a blue card application. Exemptions will be provided at no cost to teachers or police officers. Exemptions will last as long as the person remains a registered teacher or police officer or while their blue card remains current.

Blue card holders will be able to apply for an exemption from holding a yellow card. Exemptions will be provided at no cost to the blue card holders. I currently hold both a blue and yellow card. This is because an organisation I was employed by did work with both children and people with a disability. Consequently, I was required to obtain both cards as a condition of my employment. This was a duplication of administrative tasks for both my employer and those administering the requirements of the Commission for Children and Young People and Child Guardian and the Disability Services Act.

The exemption notice process will enable individuals to transition easily between systems and begin working or volunteering immediately on the basis of their previous criminal history check. It will also increase the pool of people readily available to be volunteers or to work with children with a disability. The exemption notice process will simplify and streamline administrative processes for organisations and individuals, and this is important because we all know the importance of having our dollars at the front line instead of in the back-of-house area in administration. These amendments will actually allow that important front-line work to continue. As has been said by the previous speaker, the number of screenings is anticipated to be reduced by about 100,000 in the first three years of implementation.

It is important to remember that this bill reduces duplication while maintaining scrutiny, protection and safeguards for our children. Student teachers must obtain a blue card to undertake their teaching practicum, and this is provided free of charge. They will now obtain a saving when applying for their teacher registration by paying an administration fee which is half the cost of the regular criminal history check fee.

The blue card renewal period will be extended from two to three years, with a reduction in the per annum costs, and the yellow card renewal period will also increase to three years. I feel comfortable with this extension of time given that the children’s commission has systems in place which allow for daily updates from the Queensland Police Service on changes to an individual’s police information. This means that if a person does not comply with the conditions of holding a blue card and notifies the commission of any changes to their personal police information, the commission will still receive this information daily and be in a position to maintain the protection of our young people and people with disabilities. In conclusion, the system is simpler to understand: if you work with children you need a blue card unless you qualify for an exemption. I commend the government bill to the House.

Mr CRANDON (Coomera--LNP) (7.54 pm): I rise to add to the cognate debate on the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill introduced by the member for Hinchinbrook and the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. I intend to focus my comments on the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill. The proposed amendments seek to ensure the wellbeing of people with disabilities placed in the care of an employed carer.

Under this bill, a violent criminal history would preclude employment or necessitate consideration by the chief executive. A history including convictions would disqualify a person from employment as a carer while a history of violent charges without conviction, such as repeated charges of domestic violence, would be assessed by the chief executive. I remind the House that a right to request review of a decision made by the chief executive is included. As the member for Hinchinbrook has stated, the current legislation does not preclude the employment of someone with a violent criminal history from being a carer for a person with a disability, and that is a risk that is not worth taking.

In consideration of the aspects of this bill, I took the time to speak with a Coomera constituent who, in my view, is abundantly experienced with regard to the issue of caring for those who suffer a disability. My constituent has an associate degree in social science with regard to disability. In addition, and perhaps more importantly, this person has provided care for two now-adult children, both of who suffer quite serious disabilities. For the past 28 or so years this person has been the principal carer of these children and chose to study in this area to both help her to better care for her children and allow her to work within the industry and care for others as a paid carer. As I said, this individual is abundantly experienced to comment on the bill before us. Among other things, my constituent was adamant that the need to protect those suffering a disability from the risk of harm at the hands of carers is paramount. Indeed, the view expressed was best summed up by this statement--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is so important to protect the marginalised in our community at the outset. It is not good enough that we run the risk of putting these people in harm’s way when we have the capacity to avert that risk.
XML.Hansard-Body: Currently, that certainly is not the case. Some people with disabilities have anger issues themselves. So, as my constituent said, if in those circumstances the carer has a predisposition to violence then one feeds off the other. Even the most balanced person would be challenged at times by a disabled person with anger issues. It follows that a carer with known anger issues should not be a carer. It is recognised that not everyone with a predisposition to aggression would have a history that is on the record, but where there is a record then that record should be used to protect those vulnerable people.

I want to make one final comment--a suggestion, if you like. I put it to the government that there is an anomaly in the system that puts bona fide disability workers at a disadvantage. My understanding is that if a worker leaves employment then they lose the right to retain their blue card. Once a new sponsoring employer is found, a reapplication for a blue card can proceed. Once the application has been receipted, the employee can commence employment. I am told that that is where the problem occurs. It can take some weeks for the process to arrive at the receipting point. I put it to the government that this, too, could be streamlined. Where a worker has accreditation in the industry, retention of the blue card would help employment prospects. If deemed necessary, employers could have access to a central database that confirms the current qualifications of the prospective employee. It has been made clear that we support the government bill, and I call on those opposite to see the sense of the private member’s bill and to support it through the House also.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms van Litsenburg): Order! Before I call the member for Currumbin, I want to acknowledge in the public gallery guests of the member for Waterford from the Sunnybank RSL.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (7.59 pm): May I add my welcome. The Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill 2009 was introduced into the House by the shadow minister for disability services and multicultural affairs, the honourable member for Hinchinbrook, on 7 October 2009. The honourable Minister for Community Services and Housing introduced the government’s Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill on 9 February 2009, the first sitting day of this year.

In rising to speak in this cognate debate of the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill and the private member’s bill from the LNP, the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill, it would be remiss of me not to mention that the government’s bill is yet another example of Labor playing catch-up to the opposition. Mind you, if that means we get better laws to protect vulnerable Queenslanders then we are happy to have prompted the creation of this bill. Frequently in this place we witness Labor exposed by the LNP for its laziness as it scrambles to rejig and improve upon our policy and bills with legislation of its own. As honourable members have heard, the LNP will be supporting the government’s bill, along with our own, albeit with some reservations.

Positive aspects aside, to bring this bill forward on the Notice Paper with less than 24 hours warning and then squeezing in a briefing before parliament sat yesterday morning is something of a slap in the face to those affected by the legislation, not to mention the non-government members of parliament. However, I would like to thank the staff from the various departments for attending the rushed briefing and for answering questions to the best of their capabilities.

The Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill, which runs to some 500-plus pages, makes changes to some 17 acts and others which are found in schedule 3. I turn first to the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill 2009 and congratulate the shadow minister on bringing this bill before us. We on this side of the House respect and understand the need for people with disabilities to maintain as much independence as they possibly can, with or without carers. People with disabilities are among the most vulnerable and isolated members of our community, which is why the position of a carer is one that should exemplify absolute trust. The proposed amendments seek to help protect people with a disability from being put in the care of someone who has a history of violence or abuse and be free from maltreatment or cruelty. As the shadow minister so clearly opined in his second reading speech--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There should be no question marks over the safety of the relationship between a carer and a person receiving that care.
XML.Hansard-Body: Therefore, people with a background of violence and abusive behaviour should be disqualified from providing care to a vulnerable person, such as a person with a disability. Disabilities can be permanent or temporary and affect the young and the old. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that about one in five Australians is affected by some form of disability. Notably, the Australian population is changing, with older age groups making up an increasing proportion of the population. Maturing baby boomers have been signalled as a major financial challenge for the federal government, which is no doubt behind federal Labor’s decision to raise the working age to 67. Older populations and increasing life expectancies will create more people with disabilities and an associated increased demand for carers to look after them. Many unpaid family carers will simply become too worn out to adequately manage the care of their loved ones without assistance.

The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare in its 2009 report found that the number of people with the highest level of disability is projected to increase from 1.2 million to 2.3 million within the next two decades. It would follow that the number of carers will also need to rise to accommodate this doubling in the number of people with special needs. Disabilities also occur in varying degrees. Many people with disabilities require intensive ongoing care and support from others because they cannot meet their own basic daily needs. For that reason a carer is required to help those people to survive on a daily basis and maintain their dignity and their respect.

In the main, carers are people with noble intentions who give much of themselves to improve the lives of people with disabilities. However, there are exceptions, and this bill would prohibit someone convicted of a violent offence from being engaged in a paid position as a carer for a person with a disability. People with a history of committing violent offences would be referred to the chief executive of the Department of Communities for consideration as to their suitability to be a carer.

Organisations such as Teenage Adventure Camps--Queensland, TAC-Q, are a prime example of the wonderful and exceptional people in our community who offer their time and services to care for and support people with disabilities. TAC-Q is a charity that runs an annual camp in Currumbin for teenagers suffering from life-threatening illnesses. The generosity of all involved in this adventure filled week--from theme park operators to people offering Harley rides, the Rocks Resort and the kind, big hearted volunteers--is to be commended. Tales are recounted at the farewell dinner on the last Sunday night of the camp and there is not a dry eye in the place--lots of laughter, happy moments, challenges overcome and, above all, love. Camps and carers provide these teenagers with the experience of living with their peers, establishing friendships and the realisation that they are not alone with their misfortunes. Teenagers are challenged, inspired and motivated to participate in a range of unforgettable activities and leave with a new-found confidence and outlook on life. Of course, that is made possible only through the dedication of the volunteer careers who devote themselves to this worthy cause.

Initiatives such as the LNP’s carer’s charter were designed to ensure that the value of carers is recognised in our legislation. Unfortunately, this charter of rights has not been transformed into legislation by the current government. Undoubtedly, the majority of carers perform their duties with great dedication and compassion. Unfortunately, there is a minority who violate the implicit terms of this relationship and it is those people who prey on the vulnerabilities of people with disabilities. That is why it is so necessary for the state government to provide the necessary protection and to support this bill.

History reveals that the Queensland government has failed to protect the vulnerabilities of people with disabilities in recent years. The Bribie Island Care Independent Living Association facility is one prime example, where a federal parliamentary committee in 2004 was told that residents were forced to have cold showers, have chillies put into their mouths, were deprived of sleep and food, were hit with broom handles, had head lice infestations treated with flyspray and were tied to chairs and toilet seats. The Adult Guardian in Queensland also investigated the Bribie Island facility. Their findings tell of a staff culture within the facility where disabled people were blamed for their behaviour and unfair punishment was doled out. Despite the fact that both of these findings occurred in 2004, it is only quite recently that several former carers at that facility have been brought to justice and I understand that others are still awaiting trial. In addition to those instances, police were called to investigate claims that people with disabilities were being abused and neglected by staff at a community support service at several day-care and accommodation facilities in South-East Queensland.

When looking at the latest statistics provided by the Department of Communities we see that, while infrequent, abuse by carers is a real issue in the community. The report shows that there were 27 complaints of alleged official misconduct by departmental workers servicing people with disabilities in Queensland. Of those matters, seven related to assault, six related to criminal misconduct, 12 were for inappropriate behaviour and two related to mismanagement. These figures relate to government service providers alone. Figures that will include non-government service providers would push these sad statistics even higher.

Additional findings from a report conducted by the National People with Disabilities and Carer Council titled Shut out: the experience of people with disabilities and their families in Australia , a national disabilities strategy consultation report, show us that one of the main areas of concern voiced among people with disabilities, their carers, family members and service providers was the abuse of children with disabilities in institutional settings, including respite services. This bill adds a much-needed layer of protection for all people with disabilities who require paid care.

I move now to the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill which, as I mentioned before, makes amendments to some 17 acts and several others in schedule 3. The explanatory notes inform us that the policy objectives are to effectively reduce duplication and increase consistency across criminal history screening systems. Currently in Queensland there are multiple criminal history screening regimes in place. These include the blue card system, which requires a person in child regulated employment to undergo a criminal history screening, and the yellow card system, which requires all persons engaged at service outlets of funded non-government disability service providers to undergo criminal history screening.

The provisions of this bill will allow for police officers and registered teachers to apply for an exemption from holding a blue card when they are providing child regulated services that fall outside their professional duties. Blue card holders will be able to apply for exemptions from holding a yellow card and registered health practitioners, including nurses and midwives, will be automatically exempt from requiring either of these cards whilst providing services to children and also when providing services to adults with a disability as part of their professional duties. Different legislative systems of the blue card, yellow card and teacher registration will be retained but will need to be aligned in order to examine the same types of police information. The only way to achieve that is through amended legislation.

Yellow cards will now attract the new fee of some $70. Departmental staff told us that the money is to be allocated to reimburse the NGOs which will have to apply and purchase cards for staff. As this is earmarked for the 2010-11 budget, concerns have been raised that this could place added stress on already stretched NGOs to come up with the money for their staff should there be an interim period between when provisions in the bill are enacted and the budget allocation becomes available. Perhaps the minister could address this in the reply or in consideration. Volunteers will remain exempt from paying a fee under both systems.

The minister boasts that Queensland’s blue card system is regarded as one of the most effective and accountable screening systems in Australia, yet this government refuses to make it even better. It voted down the opposition’s 2008 amendment that would have added photo ID to new and renewed cards stating it was too costly. While cost effectiveness is an important consideration, one cannot place too high a price on the personal safety of society’s most vulnerable group: children.

As the new processes go through the installation phases, various computer systems will have to be linked together. Yesterday’s briefing informed us that duplications will be removed or erased in this manner. A number of agencies are involved here. There is Police, Education, Disabilities, Child Safety, Health and Communities, if not more. This Bligh government has a shocking track record of successfully linking computer systems. Deadlines have not been met in the past and many millions of dollars have been wasted. The task of interfacing existing systems with other agencies is guaranteed to be difficult and I am keen to know what time lines the minister is working towards. Will it be this year or next or the one after?

I would also like to know how long before the streamlining and linkage to other agencies is complete and what guarantee can be given that information will be correctly processed. How many unfortunate glitches that see vulnerable children and adults fall through the cracks will there be, such as we saw in the transition of the ICMS child safety system?

At yesterday’s briefing the member for Gladstone asked whether people wishing to enter into surrogacy arrangements would have any criminal screening. The reply to this was no, they would not. COAG currently has an agreement with regard to children for a greater sharing of information between states. Living on the border of New South Wales and Queensland, I can attest to the benefits for those of us living in this region to have more cross-border friendly laws. This legislation also makes changes to restrictive practices which are required at times to manage testing behaviours. As a result of the 2006 Carter report, Challenging behaviour and disability: A targeted response , legislation was brought in to introduce a scheme on 1 July 2008 that was aimed at reducing restrictive practices. There is currently a period of three months for short-term approvals to be able to be given. To date these could only be extended in exceptional circumstances. This legislation will extend the maximum period for short-term approvals for a further three months. Apparently it has been difficult for some disability service providers to have enough time to prepare a proper assessment for the adult and to develop the positive behaviour support plan that is a central part of this scheme. The shadow minister has already outlined his concerns with this amendment and I look forward to hearing the minister’s reply.

The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s report No.2 of 2010 found that a large number of clauses may affect the rights and liberties of individuals and, in particular, employment related rights and information privacy. The government does not see any significant costs with this legislation. However, as I have said, the past record with computer systems, especially when attempting to link agencies, has been very poor. In short, the legislation has significant merit. It aims to reduce duplication and increase consistency across criminal history screening systems. However, it does not offer the level of protection to people with disabilities that the LNP’s bill does.

I would like to place on record my enormous respect and gratitude to all of those who have chosen to care for another, whether in a paid or an unpaid capacity. We should all spend a day, or three, walking in their shoes.

Ms DAVIS (Aspley--LNP) (8.14 pm): I rise to speak in the cognate debate on the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill 2009 and the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. The overwhelming majority of employees and volunteers in the sector which we are speaking about tonight provide exemplary service to the community. The vast majority of these people are both professional and caring and perform their roles with diligence and humility. These individuals and their service provider employees ensure that those in the community who need their assistance are on the whole very well provided for. They face many challenges and difficult circumstances in their day-to-day roles and are often constrained by limited resources but nevertheless do a marvellous job. That is why it is so important to protect these sectors and their clients with appropriate systems, checks and balances, regulations and, today, legislation to ensure the continued intrinsic goodwill of the word ‘carer’ and to guard their clients from harm.

My first comments are in respect to the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill. Whilst I am supportive of the thrust of this piece of legislation proposed by the government, it could be seen as being more about the reduction of duplication and about increasing consistency across the entire criminal history screening process rather than an intent to protect those who are vulnerable. The main objective of the bill is to reduce duplication by providing exemptions relating to police officers, teachers, current blue card holders and registered health care practitioners when they are providing services to children as well as adults with a disability as part of their professional duties. It also aims to increase consistency in criminal history screening by amalgamating into the blue card system screening of all persons providing services to children with a disability, all employees and volunteers of state government entities who are engaged in child related roles, health students undertaking placements that involve service delivery of children within private or public facilities and all employees and volunteers of local governments undertaking child related roles.

The system seems to be unnecessarily complex at present. For example, the teacher screening procedures do not exempt teachers from requiring a blue card and individuals with a blue card are still subject to the teacher screening process if they are applying to become a teacher. A further example of this complicated web is an individual providing services to a child with disabilities in a non-funded organisation that is not screened under the yellow card system but under the blue card system. As such, there are duplications, inconsistencies and unnecessary costs that are experienced by both organisations and individuals. It is these costs that I am concerned about.

Whilst I welcome the move to improve criminal history screening, I have concerns relating to the costs in the government’s bill where employees may be required to pay to obtain and maintain their own cards in order to secure or maintain employment in the sector. On commencement of the blue card system in 2001 the cost of a blue card was $40. Today it is $61.75. Under this bill it jumps again to $70. The fee to replace a card is now $10.30. A yellow card, the cost of which was previously borne by the government, will now hit the applicant for the same cost of a blue card, increasing to $70.

I see from the minister’s second reading speech in relation to costs that the Bligh government will be assisting the funded non-government disability services sector in relation to the changes. I understand that there was mention of increased recurrent funding for community organisations at a briefing yesterday morning, but I still hold reservations, as do many organisations in the sector.
In relation to this I would like to quote from National Disability Services, the peak representative body for more than 600 non-government disability services throughout Australia--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The disability sector already has an array of financial and administrative imposts associated with compliance that are beyond those experienced in any other state. The additional burden the proposed changes represent is likely to compromise viability for some services and is considered unreasonable.

Overall, it is the view of our members that the proposed changes represent administrative efficiencies for government but represent an increase in administrative, monitoring and financial impost for non government disability service providers. There is also concern that these changes will disadvantage low income (predominantly female) workers, and specifically disadvantage people with disability (or families) who manage their own funding, or live in Indigenous communities where the labour market is tight.
XML.Hansard-Body: We need to ensure that the government’s proposals do not compromise the great work and viability of service providers and individuals. We need to be enabling these organisations, not imposing more paperwork as they manage their workforce of carers.

I acknowledge that this bill is not specifically targeted at the disability sector. It also seeks to reduce duplication and increase consistency across the criminal history screening system, including Education, Disability Services and Child Safety. The legislation will affect health professionals, police involved in child regulated duties and volunteers.

I would like to briefly touch on short-term approvals in relation to restrictive practices. Amendments were made to the Disability Services Act in 2008 to regulate their use and mandate positive behaviour support following the report by Justice Carter. Under current arrangements, a short-term approval provides up to three months of the development of a behaviour management plan for an individual who exhibits challenging behaviour. The amendment extends this period to six months. According to the explanatory notes, this extension is warranted as service providers are having difficulty with completing these requirements in the current three-month period. We are a little concerned by this extension and I sympathise with service providers who face the challenges of developing the plans in light of the scarce resources that they have at their disposal. I note that the government has not allocated funds to service providers to implement the Carter recommendations and I wonder whether appropriate investment might have solved this issue.

The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee noted that a large number of clauses may affect the rights and liberties of individuals and, in particular, rights to employment and information privacy. However, in my opinion those potential breaches are justified for the safety of children and those with a disability from risk of harm.

I would now like to make some comments on the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill, which I do support. Only 18 months ago, the then shadow minister for social inclusion and member for Burdekin, Rosemary Menkens, raised the issue of a carer with a non-conviction criminal history assaulting a person with a disability who was in his care. Due to government inaction to address the matter of inadequate criminal history screening for carers at that time, this private member’s bill was introduced in October 2009 by the shadow minister for disability services and member for Hinchinbrook, Andrew Cripps. The foremost principle in disability services should be the interests of the person with the disability and the environment in which he or she lives. One of the key planks of government policy on disability services should be the identification, prevention and early intervention in situations where those with a disability are endangered, and that is what this legislation seeks to do by protecting those most vulnerable people in our society through ensuring that those who care for them in a non-familial capacity do not have histories of violent behaviour.

All forms of violence are abhorrent to this community, including physical, sexual and emotional violence, and to have a carer with a history of such behaviour jeopardises the health and wellbeing of those for which they purport to care. The objectives of this bill include an automatic disqualification from employment in a carer’s role for someone with a criminal conviction or charge for a violent offence in the past years. Those charges can cover examples such as domestic violence charges that are not followed through the court processes. A history of charges without conviction would be at the discretion of the chief executive. It is important to note that the bill does not preclude individuals with criminal histories from being employed in the sector, only from working in the role of a carer of a person with a disability.

It is a shame that the government is not prepared to support the bill that seeks to afford vulnerable people much more protection than does its contribution. We make no bones about the fact that our bill is much more stringent than the one proposed by the government because we want to ensure that this community is as secure as it can be from those who seek to damage the marvellous record of our carers and place them in jeopardy. Australia has almost 2.6 million carers and nearly 500,000 of those are primary carers. Carers provide care and support to family members and friends with a disability, mental illness, chronic conditions, terminal illness or those who are frail aged. It is appropriate that legal safeguards are employed and strengthened to protect the rights of those with a disability and also to protect those carers who do the right thing in providing exemplary care to their clients. People with disabilities are valued members of our community and should be respected and cared for in a nonthreatening and violence-free environment. I commend the bills to the House.

Mr O’BRIEN (Cook--ALP) (8.24 pm): It is a great pleasure to rise in support of the bill that is currently before the House. I congratulate the minister for her initiative in improving the safety and lives of the children and the most vulnerable in the state of Queensland. The legislation before the House will reduce, particularly for registered teachers and police, the red tape surrounding criminal screening for people working with children and people with disabilities. This will save time, money and resources. I think it is a very important initiative.

The bill will reduce the duplication of criminal history checks undertaken in Queensland for people seeking to work or volunteer with children and increase the consistency of criminal history screening processes to enable exemptions to operate across the systems. In any employment screening, it is important to keep focus on the context environment in which a person may pose a risk. Accordingly, separate specialist screening systems are being maintained, but they are being effectively linked to reduce duplication. The bill will improve the cohesion of the blue card, teacher registration and yellow card systems to allow for exemptions to operate across systems, while also improving essential safeguards for children and people with a disability. The amendments will simplify and streamline processes for community members seeking to work or volunteer with children and will ensure that no gaps are created when people move from one system to another. The bill is evidence that the government is continually finding new ways to improve service delivery by simplifying and streamlining processes.

This evening I particularly want to talk about some of the aspects of the changes that are reportedly going to affect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander applicants. It is important to remember that the bill will not significantly alter the requirements for the blue card. The focus is on reducing duplication. Of the total number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander applicants to provide foster or kinship care or be employed as licensed care providers, 88.94 per cent resulted in the issue of a positive notice, only 1.4 per cent of applicants resulted in a negative notice and 9.17 per cent of applications were withdrawn because additional information was not received. Therefore, it is an important focus of the bill that those people are not going to be adversely affected, as some people have alleged. That is simply not the case, because most of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander applicants are blue card applicants.

The children’s commission is very active in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in my electorate. It distributes a range of information to advise on who requires a blue card, makes available resources to help applicants meet the identification requirements and advises people that, in most cases, a criminal history does not prevent a person from applying for a blue card. I wanted to put that on the record to allay the fears that have been raised. I commend the bill that is before the House.

Ms O’NEILL (Kallangur--ALP) (8.27 pm): I am proud to rise to take part in this cognate debate. Specifically I want to refer to the benefits for teachers. Currently registered teachers do not require a blue card when undertaking their professional duties. However, teachers often work with children outside of the domain of their professional duties by volunteering in local sporting clubs or community organisations. To do this they currently need to obtain a blue card. It is estimated that there may be 31,500 teachers who currently hold blue cards. Under the amendments, registered teachers will be able to apply for an exemption and immediately commence work or volunteer with children in child regulated services in the blue card context outside of their professional duties, for example, to volunteer at a local sporting club.

The Commissioner for Children and Young People and Child Guardian will verify the person’s status as a registered teacher with the Queensland College of Teachers and a duplicate criminal history check will not be undertaken unless the person has a criminal history that requires further consideration to operate unconditionally across the variety of service environments in which a blue card can be used. For example, a teacher with conditions attached to their registration may further require assessment in the blue card context to ensure safeguards for children are maintained. Once a registered teacher obtains an exemption notice, they do not need to apply for renewal. The exemption notice remains current for the duration of their teacher registration unless cancelled earlier. Given that the screening of teachers in the teacher registration process is broadly comparable to that undertaken in the blue card system, including registered teachers, the exemption notice regime is an efficient way to reduce the duplication of criminal history screening.

In addition, student teachers must obtain a blue card to undertake their teaching practicum and this is provided free of charge. They will now obtain a saving when applying for their teacher registration by paying an administration fee that is half the cost of the regular criminal history fee. A duplicate criminal history check will not be undertaken unless further assessment is required about a person’s a suitability to teach. I support the bill.

Mrs SCOTT (Woodridge--ALP) (8.29 pm): I am pleased to speak on the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill tonight. The blue card system has three critical elements. The first is a requirement for regulated organisations to implement risk management strategies to mitigate risks of harm to children. The commissioner works in partnership with organisations to achieve improved safeguards for children. In 2008-09 the commission engaged with over 266,000 people to educate stakeholders about the blue card system.

The second element is a requirement for regulated organisations to ensure that individuals providing services to children undergo a blue card check, which prevents high-risk individuals from providing services to children. Since its inception, over 3,500 high-risk individuals have been prevented from providing services to children. Of these, almost 1,900 people have been excluded from holding a blue card and almost 1,500 people have withdrawn their application after being challenged on their criminal history. This number of withdrawals is indicative of the strong deterrent effect of the blue card check. It is very likely that a significant number of other high-risk individuals are deterred from applying altogether because of the reputation of the system in identifying and challenging them.

The third element is that of monitoring the criminal histories of over 478,000 blue card holders and the levels of compliance by regulated organisations with risk management and blue card requirements. Since its inception, nearly 350 people have had their blue card suspended as a result of a change in their criminal history. A strong indicator of the effectiveness of the blue card system is the community’s acceptance and support, which is reflected in the 2008-09 client satisfaction survey conducted by the Office of Economic and Statistical Research. The majority of respondents--77 per cent, in fact--in the survey believed that the blue card system is an effective initiative which assists in creating safe and supportive environments for children and young people in Queensland.

The effectiveness of the blue card system will be further strengthened by increasing the commission’s access to certain information relating to a person’s police information and by broadening the exclusionary framework to automatically disqualify persons who are subject to sexual offender orders under the Dangerous Prisoners (Sexual Offenders) Act 2003. A sexual offender order is made when a person has been convicted of a serious sexual offence and when a court is satisfied to a high degree of probability that the person is a serious danger to the community in the absence of such an order being made. A person subject to a sexual offender order will be banned from being able to apply for a blue card.

The system will also be strengthened by the introduction of the new mandatory validation process, which will require an individual’s blue card or exemption notice to be validated by an employer. This will enable the commission to be advised of up-to-date employer details. It is important for the commission to have up-to-date employer details so that all relevant employers can be informed of changes to the status of a person’s blue card or exemption notice. This additional safeguard will significantly strengthen the effectiveness of the blue card system.

The commission’s access to criminal history information will be increased by amendments enabling certain information to be requested from the Mental Health Court, the Mental Health Review Tribunal and the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions. It makes sense, therefore, to reduce duplication by amalgamating the screening for people who work in regulated child related environments under the blue card system and exempting those already screened under another comparative system. This presents a simplified child related employment-screening system which is robust and consistent.

The success of the blue card system has ensured that those who work with our children are of a high character. Parents can be confident that their children are in safe hands when they join a sporting club, nippers, little athletics, scouts, girl guides, church youth groups or whatever the group may be, and our service providers such as police, teachers and health workers have all undergone criminal history checks. This legislation will cut out unnecessary duplication. It will also ensure that those who work with people with disabilities and all state and local government workers whose positions include working with children and young people will come under the system.

The period covered will also increase from two to three years. These measures will increase the efficiency of the blue card system and streamline the application process. I thank the commissioner as well as the office of the Commissioner for Children and Young People and Child Guardian for their efforts, the minister, the Hon. Karen Struthers, and all involved in the preparation of this bill. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr DEMPSEY (Bundaberg--LNP) (8.35 pm): It is indeed a great privilege to be able to speak in favour of the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment 2009 before the House. As all members of parliament representing the different political parties and different areas know, we are here to serve and help our constituents. How we help the most vulnerable people in our society is a reflection on this parliament, on each member and on the community they serve. It is great to see any bill before the House that assists those most vulnerable people in the community. In saying that, we have to make sure that the bills are drafted in such a way as to reduce the administrative burden on society. I would like to thank the minister for easing the burden in relation to how the different acts are administered.

The protection of vulnerable groups within our community should always be at the forefront of the minds of members of this parliament. This bill provides protection for people who remain amongst the most vulnerable in our society. Our disabled citizens rely on carers to varying degrees. Some just need help occasionally with odds and ends, while others need intensive care to perform what able-bodied people would consider the simplest of tasks. Whatever their situation, disabled people in our society deserve to be treated with love and respect. Those who require intensive care should feel safe with their carer at all times. A carer is placed in a position of trust as they look after someone who is completely reliant on them to perform essential daily tasks. It is one of the most honourable roles someone can take on--one that cannot be done lightly and one where we must maintain standards so the disabled in our community receive the best care possible.

Carers truly are people whom we should all admire and thank whenever possible, because their hard work and valuable contribution to our communities is immense. While the majority of carers are giving of their time, skills and assistance for the right reasons, a very small minority are not. A carer who abuses this trust in any way is among the most despicable of human characters in our society. It is, therefore, appropriate and necessary to prevent people with violent criminal histories from becoming carers. The last thing our society needs is to have people with a history of unleashing violent assaults in a position of trust with a person who is unable to defend themselves. Unfortunately, these situations do happen and disabled people do become victims of abuse from their carer. One struggles to comprehend what it would be like to be assaulted with no possibility of defending yourself or escaping that attack. One struggles to comprehend placing your complete trust in someone to look after you, only to be stabbed in the back by a cowardly assault. It is not just the physical act that is appalling; it is the ongoing trauma that the victim experiences. Reliving the horror of such an attack would be horrible enough on its own, but imagine being disabled and experiencing such a cowardly attack.

Having your trust broken and being in such a vulnerable position would truly be terrifying. The fear that you could be assaulted again in the future and knowing that you are unable to do anything about it would be overwhelming. It would be hard to trust a carer again, yet they are not able to go about their lives without a carer helping them. These types of events impact on how they interact with their carers and also with the rest of society. Our disabled citizens deserve to be protected like other vulnerable people in our community.

Another vulnerable group in our society is children, and this parliament has taken steps in the past to protect them. The requirement of holding a blue card before working with children and being put in a position of trust with them is a simple measure that works. There is a perception amongst the community that it works, and sometimes the perception becomes reality.

Our disabled citizens deserve similar measures to protect them. This bill will do that by creating a system of carer prohibition notices, which will prevent people with criminal histories of violence from caring for the disabled. This legislation is very important because it helps protect those who are most vulnerable in our community. Protecting the disabled from people with a history of violent assaults is a simple step we can take as a parliament to make our most vulnerable citizens feel safe.

Before closing, I have to report that I do have some concerns with the bill, particularly in relation to the issuing of blue cards. As I said before, there is a perception that the blue cards have been good, and that reputation needs to be protected. For the point I wish to make, I will use the Bundaberg Steam Tramway Preservation Society as an example. It runs a small locomotive in one of the beautiful parks in Bundaberg. The volunteers were issued with blue cards, but they have been told, and I quote, ‘We have encouraged the society to consider as part of their general occasional risk management strategy what policies and procedures they have in place to minimise risks of harm to children.’ The Commissioner for Children and Young People and Child Guardian sent a letter saying that the volunteers no longer need blue cards because their primary focus is not children. But those who have been to Bundaberg know that hundreds of thousands of people use this train every year, and it is predominantly for the children.

The workers were all issued with blue cards, but this is one example of a small group--with approximately 200 volunteers--which will no longer get the blue cards. They will need to have, according to the words I just quoted, risk management policies and procedures in place, but they had an assurance that they would be covered by the blue card for their insurance and for other purposes. To maintain that high level, they will now need to have criminal history checks done, which could cost up to $60 or $70 each. So organisations which have 200 volunteers who used to have blue cards will now have a huge financial burden on them because they will now need to get criminal history checks done. That is a cost for this one small group of $70 times 200. I would like that issue to be clarified later.

There are also other clubs which could be affected, like the Rotary clubs, the Lions clubs, the Apex clubs. Community and sporting organisations that do not have a majority of young children--it might be 60-40--will now need to have criminal history checks done. I hope the financial bean counters have actually worked out what the cost will be to the community of Queensland.

The benefits of the blue card have been immense, and I would hate to see that reputation being put aside because of any financial restraints. Without further ado, I will conclude by saying that I support the bill and thank the minister and the shadow minister for the hard work they have done.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (8.44 pm): I rise to speak to the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 and the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill 2009. I thank the minister for the briefing that her staff provided. I note that the sheer size of the bill was enough to frighten anybody in terms of being able to understand all of the implications of the legislative amendments. The minister’s staff, however, assured us that the bulk of the bill related to getting consistent amendments to a series of pieces of legislation, and that is what caused the amount of changes.

The reason for this legislation is to reduce the duplication for screening and also to set up notifications between jurisdictions. I applaud that. I do have a question though: that is, will there be regular audits to protect against system failure? The bigger the system and the bigger the connection between departments and between elements in a department, the greater the risk of failure of the system and the greater the risk that people who should not be getting approved could be approved. I will be interested to hear the minister comment on what audit provisions there will be to ensure there is not a breakdown in this interjurisdictional connection. Any reduction in red tape is certainly important, but it is in such a vulnerable area, an area of intrinsic importance, so it is vital that there is no breakdown.

I think it was the member for Currumbin who commented in relation to my question about criminal history checks on surrogate applicants. I again raise the concern that I think there will be a significant portion of the community who start the surrogacy process who will have no criminal history screening, and I believe we could be making a mistake in leaving what will be a very vulnerable group of young children without any protection. In saying that, I am not casting aspersions on surrogate parents. It is just that we have quite significant protections for children in care, for children in preschools and for children who are assisted by volunteers in schools and preschools, but in this area where a little baby will be going into a home there is no protection.

The minister’s staff gave us a concise document that outlined the proposed significant amendments, I thank the minister for that. I value that because it made it simpler to understand the thrust of the bill. The bill will reduce duplication by allowing registered teachers and police officers to be able to apply for an exemption from holding a blue card when providing child regulated services. One would hope that that group of community members would be able to be trusted, although I do believe that at all levels there has to be a degree of screening to ensure that everybody who has a contact of trust with young people should be in that position of trust.

I am not going to speak to all of the elements, but the bill states that blue card holders will be able to apply for an exemption from holding a yellow card. A yellow card is required for a person working with an adult with a disability. I think that is an eminently logical exemption, and I believe that will not only streamline the process but also reduce cost, given that this legislation introduces a fee for a yellow card which previously did not exist.

The other issue I want to raise relates to the cost implication. Other members have talked about the increasing cost. When the blue card was first introduced, the cost for applying--which did not apply to everybody--was $40. It has increased over time to be $65, and now under this legislation it is $70, which is almost double.

I have talked to volunteers in my electorate--people who are very generous in spirit. They do not have a problem with the process, but many of these people are retirees and $70 is a significant amount of money for them to find when they are offering themselves on a volunteer basis to benefit others. One of the groups in my electorate sit with young people who have problems with literacy and they read with them. These people now need a blue card. They are retirees, and one group lives in a retirement village. $70 for them is a lot. Given that under the federal government regulations the nursing home can take 80 per cent of their pension, they do not have a lot left over. I believe we have to keep a very close check on the cost of these cards. It is more acceptable perhaps for people who are earning an income, but for people who are not earning an income these additional charges will add to the issues that they must consider before they offer themselves on a volunteer basis. The same will apply to a yellow card.

Having said that, I in no way want to undermine the importance of people who work with our children and people who work with individuals with disabilities--that those people are appropriate people; that their motives are pure; that their motives are good; and that they do not have any underlying agenda. I will always support legislation in this chamber that will give protection to people in our community who are vulnerable, both our young people and people with disabilities--both physical and mental disabilities. However, I do ask the minister to respond to the question of whether there will be an audit process on a regular basis to ensure that a breakdown does not occur and that there will be a tight reign placed on the cost of these cards. As I said, many people who apply for them are volunteering, and it is a cost that they should not have to bear.

Mr GIBSON (Gympie--LNP) (8.51 pm): I rise tonight to make a contribution to the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill and the LNP’s Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill. At the outset, I would like to place on the record my admiration and tribute to the overwhelming majority of the organisations, the professionals who are involved--both the paid and the volunteers who assist--and the directors of the various organisations that help, because it is the efforts of all in these sectors that need to be recognised. What the bill does today I believe is important, but it is also important to recognise the work that is done in somewhat difficult circumstances. From time to time it is not easy work, but it can be some of the most rewarding work that people can engage in.

We have to recognise that there are vulnerable groups in our community, and those who are disabled fall into that category of some of the most vulnerable. I would go on to say that disabled children are the most vulnerable in that category. That is why we in this parliament and the government of the day have the responsibility of ensuring that we have the best system for those vulnerable members of our community involving the best checks and balances possible for all those who work in this area.

I would like to acknowledge the great work of the LNP shadow minister. It is something that needs to be recognised, particularly when in opposition we do not have the resources of the department to draw upon. Putting forward a bill that is genuinely looking at addressing a need is something that needs to be recognised. I would also like to recognise the minister and her departmental staff. As has been indicated, the bill before the House is incredibly comprehensive. I acknowledge that that takes time. You cannot just take an idea and make it into a bill. You have to ensure that it covers all of those areas, and I believe we see that with this bill.

It is important that we recognise the bipartisan nature of the two bills that are before the House tonight. As has been pointed out on many occasions, what is often reported is the adversarial nature of this parliament. What is not covered in the depth that it should be is the bipartisan spirit that occurs when a problem is identified and is moved forward.

While many have spoken about many of the details of this bill, I believe it is important to go back to the time line that really drove this bill and that brings us here to debate it tonight. Eighteen months ago in this House a question was posed to the minister by the member for Burdekin regarding a man with disabilities being placed in the care of an individual with a violent criminal history. It is tragic that in this case the man was assaulted by his carer and suffered trauma, and his family endured great distress. That is understandable, because families who rely upon carers and the support that they provide are placing their trust in another individual.
