When that trust is breached, it comes back onto themselves and they feel guilt and concern about ‘what if’ and ‘where could we go’.

As indicated, the LNP identified that shortcoming. About four months ago we saw the introduction into this House of the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill. That was a genuine attempt to address a concern. I note that the government’s bill was introduced two weeks ago. I am of the view that the government intended to do its homework properly. The bill before the House, as I indicated, shows a very comprehensive approach to that. It is unfortunate, though--and I do not mean this as a slur on anyone involved--that 18 months had to pass, because during that period of time there was ongoing concern. It is very unfortunate that we have to have these bills and subsequent laws before the House at all. We would like to think that those in whom we place our trust in our society would not breach it. However, it is an unfortunate fact that a very small minority do breach that trust. When they do so, they unfortunately besmirch the good reputation of others who work in these sectors. We must protect the most vulnerable. If that impacts on less than one per cent of people who act in a heinous manner, then I support it because I believe it is important that we move forward.

During my time at university I had a great opportunity to work as a carer for nine months. In those days the circumstances were somewhat different. It is not as it is now, where carers work on a much smaller basis. We had large institutions that were involved in care. In my job I was able to work the night shift at one of those institutions that cared for disabled children. Not all of those children had language skills. Not all of those children were able to function in what we would consider simple, ordinary tasks. The role of the carer is one that I am very conscious of. I applied for the job simply from an advertisement. At that time, there was no history check and no experience was required. I was given the opportunity to care each night for the children in that institution--and for a uni student it was an ideal situation.

It comes back to the fact that, and I wish to stress this, the majority--I believe greater than 99 per cent--of those who work in these industries--those who give of their time, whether it be paid or those who give of a greater sacrifice in terms of their time without any form of recompense because they do so with a desire to assist--are good people and should be trusted. But, as has been pointed out, when that trust is breached, we find ourselves responding in the manner in which we are tonight--a manner which will ensure that those most vulnerable in our community will be protected. There has been much said about the detail of the bill, and it is not my intention to repeat what has already been said. Anything that can cut duplication should be welcomed. Anything that involves a reduction in red tape should be welcomed.

Of course there are costs that are associated with that, and I would encourage the government, as I know our shadow minister did in drafting his bill, to look at the most cost-effective ways that we can bring about these arrangements so that the costs do not rest on the already-stretched budgets of those organisations that are doing a fantastic job and getting more bang for the buck than we see in many other areas. We do not want to put an additional cost burden on to them unnecessarily, but we do need to ensure that as we legislate to protect the most vulnerable in our society we do so in a measured way and in a way that will result in the outcomes that we seek. I am not that optimistic to say that as a result of tonight we will never see an incident where an individual will not face abuse or some form of torment from a carer. I would like to think that tonight will be the end of it. Unfortunately, I am a pragmatist and I realise that that will not be the case. But tonight we send a clear message out from this House to the people of Queensland and to those who do a fantastic job that we are supporting them and we are protecting the most vulnerable, and for that I commend both bills to the House.

Mr PITT (Mulgrave--ALP) (9.00 pm): In making a contribution to this cognate debate tonight, I want to put on the record my support for the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. This place is more than a forum for debate and assessment of policy ideas. Through the legislative process we must always try to bring some common sense and practicality to the final implementation of these policies. We must also not forget the enormous administrative impact that our words and decisions in parliament have on the public servants who diligently implement these initiatives and, of course, the impact on the end user. Our decisions have flow-on effects right across the community--in schools, child care, sports associations, clubs, disabled and age-care facilities, and the list goes on.

Since 2001 the blue card system has significantly assisted service providers to go about their business in the human services sector, our justice system and non-government organisations--all the while protecting our most vulnerable Queenslanders. Through the effective administration of blue card related functions, the Commission for Children and Young People and Child Guardian plays a critical role in providing safeguards for children and young people in regulated service environments. In 2008-09, the commission monitored over 466,000 blue card holders and applicants, providing advice and acting to minimise potential at-risk situations in over 600 cases. During this period the commission processed more than a quarter of a million blue card applications and embarked on an awareness-raising campaign about the application process and cardholder obligations to a similar number.

The blue card concept has worked well in this state. However, we must make every effort to continue to not only improve the integrity and consistency of the screening system but also ensure that it is a pragmatic system that is based on reality. While the system must continue to reflect the high expectations that our community has for the screening of individuals who work with children, we should always aim to streamline the process, reduce costs--both to government and to users--and avoid duplication wherever possible. The provisions of the government’s bill achieve this by providing exemptions for professionals who operate in a regulated service environment who may also work with children in another capacity--for example, registered teachers and police officers involved with junior sport or youth groups. Under the current regime, this would necessitate an application for a blue card. The changes proposed under this bill mean these people need only apply for an exemption--at no cost.

Comprehensive criminal history checks have already been undertaken on these individuals in the first instance. They have already satisfied strict requirements. In addition, existing blue card holders will be able to apply for an exemption from holding a yellow card and registered health practitioners, including nurses and midwives, will be automatically exempt from requiring a blue card or yellow card when they are providing services to children as well as adults with a disability in the discharge of their professional duties.

The proposed legislation would also have a positive impact on the hip pocket of individuals in paid employment. The renewal period would be extended from two years to three years for new applications for blue cards and yellow cards--those who work for organisations that are funded by government to work with disabled Queenslanders. For paid employees who hold a blue card, this would mean a reduction in the annual rate from $30.93 per year to $23.33 per year. These same fees would apply to holders of yellow cards in paid employment in order to meet the proposed new criteria. These workers will, under the government’s proposal, be required to hold a blue card like anyone else who works with children. The need to hold a yellow card for existing blue card holders who want to work with adults with a disability would be removed. Under the new arrangements for both systems, volunteers would remain exempt from paying a fee.

With regard to the exclusionary frameworks, the amendments would see a stronger alignment of the blue card, yellow card and teacher registration systems. Individuals convicted of certain serious sexual offences are effectively banned from working in child related employment or government provided or funded disability services. Persons excluded are those subject to reporting obligations under the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004; those on orders under the Child Protection (Offender Prohibition Order) Act 2008; those on orders under the Dangerous Prisoners (Sexual Offenders) Act 2003; or those who have been convicted of a disqualifying offence and received an imprisonment order for the offence. People subject to any of these orders are banned from applying for either a blue or yellow card.

Aligning these frameworks means that the blue and yellow card systems will exclude people with the same types of police information and improve safeguards for children, as well as adults with a disability. These changes are an important element in making sure that the exemption notice system does not allow for loopholes in one system that would allow entry into another. These changes are to be commended for improving criminal history screening safeguards and, consequently, the safety of our children. The Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill will not significantly alter requirements for the blue card. It will, however, pave the way for a substantial reduction of red tape. I congratulate the minister and her department for their work on the bill. If passed, this bill will be a win for common sense.

Hon. MM KEECH (Albert--ALP) (9.05 pm): In rising to support the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill, I congratulate the minister on presenting the bill to this House. The bill reduces duplication of screening for people seeking to work or volunteer services to children in two ways. Firstly, it effectively links existing screening systems to avoid multiple criminal history checks being undertaken. Currently, police officers and registered teachers are only exempt from holding a blue card when providing child regulated services as part of their professional duties. Now they may also apply for an exemption when providing child regulated services which fall outside their professional duties--for example, when a police officer volunteers at a local sporting club.

The commission will confirm the person is entitled to an exemption and an exemption will be automatically granted unless the person has a criminal history that requires further consideration to operate unconditionally across the variety of service environments in which a blue card can be used. As well, registered health practitioners will now not be required to hold a blue card or a yellow card when undertaking their professional duties in child regulated contexts. For example, school based nurses will not require a blue card and GPs providing services to adults with a disability in regulated environments will not require a yellow card. An applicant for teacher registration will be able to rely on their blue card and a duplicate criminal history check will not be undertaken unless further assessment is required about a person’s suitability to teach. For example, an applicant for teacher registration who obtained a blue card to undertake their student placement will generally not need to undergo another criminal history check and blue card holders may apply for an exemption from holding a yellow card--for example, when a blue card holder works with adults with a disability.

The bill also reduces duplication by, secondly, amalgamating screening for certain people who work in regulated child related environments. The following individuals will now be screened under the blue card system--namely, all individuals providing services to children with disabilities will now be required to obtain a blue card rather than be screened under the yellow card system; all employees and volunteers of state government entities engaged in child related roles will be required to obtain a blue card rather than be screened by the individual departments; all health students undertaking placement that involves service delivery to children within private or public facilities will require a blue card; and all employees and volunteers of local governments undertaking child related duties will now also require a blue card.

The amendments are anticipated to reduce the number of criminal history checks undertaken in the first three years alone of implementation by approximately 100,000. That is a tremendous reduction in duplication of services. In concluding, I want to thank all the people, especially those in Albert, in paid employment or volunteers who support and encourage children, whether it be in schools, junior sports or disability services. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr CRIPPS (Hinchinbrook--LNP) (9.09 pm), in reply: From the outset I would like to thank all members for their contributions to the debate on the bill that I introduced, the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill, which was debated in cognate with the government bill, the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill. I do not intend to take up a deal of the time of the House in reply to the debate on the LNP’s bill, save to do three things: firstly, to respond to the concerns of the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee; secondly, to reiterate the principles, values and objectives contained in the bill put forward by the LNP; and, thirdly, to respond to the contribution of the Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs to this bill.

With respect to the report of the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee on the bill that I introduced, I thank the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee for its constructive and reasonable comments in respect of the Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill. The committee raised the issue of whether the bill has sufficient regard to the rights and liberties of individuals. The committee drew the attention of members to clause 4 of the bill, which, it is suggested, may affect the rights and liberties of individuals engaged or seeking to be engaged as a disability support carer. Although I acknowledge that point of view--and it was a view that was raised, I think, by the member for Toowoomba North in respect of the government’s bill--I would argue that priority consideration has to be given to the rights of vulnerable people with disabilities who must trust in their carers implicitly. A breach of this trust has devastating effects on the person with a disability, often extending beyond physical wellbeing to social interaction and emotional development. It is a choice to work in the field of disability support services. It is not a choice to have a disability. The role of the government is to protect the most vulnerable people in our society. In this case, people with disabilities need more legislative protection and enshrinement of liberties and rights than do carers with criminal histories.

In addition, I would point out that similar, although not identical, concerns are raised in respect of the government’s bill, the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill, by the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee. The explanatory notes accompanying the bill seek to justify concerns in respect of a potential breach of privacy rights by arguing that the risk of such a breach is necessary to effectively protect the best interests and safety of children as well as persons with a disability and to ensure that adequate safeguards have been put in place where appropriate. I think it is important, as part of this summing-up process, that I reiterate some of the important principles that are being pursued by the LNP opposition by introducing this bill.

The LNP feels that there needs to be legislative effort to try to enhance the confidence not only that people with disabilities can have but also that families and the wider community can have in the integrity of the important relationship between a carer and the people for whom they care. The bill that I introduced in October last year is designed to help protect people with a disability from being put in the care of someone who has a history of violence or abuse. The bill will allow people with disabilities to have confidence in their carer and it will also allow disability service providers to employ carers with confidence. I regret the advice from the Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs that the Bligh government will not support the LNP in attempting to achieve this important goal.

The overwhelming majority of carers in our community are exemplary people who give so much of themselves to improve the lives of people with disabilities. As I said when I introduced this bill, the contribution of carers is very often of a value well in excess of the remuneration they receive. They are essential service providers. They do their work with sincerity and, unfortunately, sometimes they provide the only genuine connection between their clients and the outside world. Indeed, in many cases carers enhance the quality of life of their clients.

However, as I said when I made a contribution to the debate on the government’s bill, tragically there will be the odd occasion when the trust between a person with a disability and a carer is breached. This is an unfortunate reality that we have to face up to. Let me share with honourable members two distressing examples of when these breaches of trust occur.
Debate, on motion of Mr Cripps, adjourned.
Hon. KL STRUTHERS (Algester--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (9.14 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House do now adjourn.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr CRANDON (Coomera--LNP) (9.14 pm): Recent reports put community safety volunteer associations receiving $2.6 million in grants. Of that amount, the Volunteer Marine Rescue Association--or VMR--was reported to receive nearly $600,000. That sounds like a large sum, but let me break it down. That means that $22,542 was available for each of the 25 Volunteer Marine Rescue groups to manage their boat replacement program. I have the honour of hosting a Volunteer Marine Rescue group in my electorate. In fact, the Jacobs Well Volunteer Marine Rescue is the only Queensland Ambulance Service first responder on the water for personal injury cases in Queensland. That group’s patch encompasses all waterways from the north arm of the Coomera River to the northern point of Macleay Island in the north and 50 nautical miles out to sea. The Jacobs Well VMR has a total of four vessels.

In the past two years, the vessel replacement program at Jacobs Well cost $473,000. That program included the replacement of two vessels, new engines for those two vessels, the refit of one vessel that was due to be replaced--but because of a lack of funds a refit was done--and a replacement engine on an additional vessel. Vessels are replaced every 10 years and engines are replaced every two years. The suggestion that a contribution of $22,542 can appropriately accommodate the vessel replacement program beggars belief.

I turn to the ongoing costs. The running costs of engines is $60 to $70 per hour per vessel. The primary rescue vessel holds 500 litres of unleaded petrol and uses it in just six hours. Last year total fuel expenses at the Jacobs Well VMR were approximately $43,000. The total operational cost of the Jacobs Well VMR is approximately $250,000 per financial year. The average cost for each volunteer in their first year in this vital service is $1,100 out of their own back pocket.

What about the important work that these volunteers do? Over the past two years, activations at the Jacobs Well VMR were 40 medicals, of which 16 were Queensland Ambulance Service activations. There were 620 vessel assistance activations, of which 29 were Queensland Police Service activations. The total patrols or training amounted to 1,068 activations. The Jacobs Well VMR fielded 6,425 radio and telephone communications over that period. They put in many hours of ongoing training.

This group is made up 100 per cent of volunteers--people putting their own time and their own money into a cause that saves peoples’ lives and their property. Today, the very important and relevant point was made to me that if those vessel assistance activations did not occur in a timely fashion by these volunteers then in many cases they would soon become medical activations. I make these points and call on this government to fund more adequately the Volunteer Marine Rescue Association to ensure that it remains a viable essential service.

Hon. D BOYLE (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (9.17 pm): On Thursday, 18 February this year, one of the great community leaders of Cairns, Mr Arthur Strike OAM passed away, aged 92. Arthur Strike received the Medal of the Order of Australia in the 1991 Queen’s Birthday honours in the General Division for service to local government and to the community, particularly through the Noah’s Ark toy library.

Arthur was born 92 years ago, on 10 November 1917, in Richmond. As a young man he joined the Labor Party and remained a staunch member for close on 70 years. He served the community with tremendous effort and with great heart for all of those years. Right up until the last days of his life, even when his movement was physically limited, he was still organising things on behalf of those in the community for whom he felt a soft spot. These people were particularly those who suffered from disabilities, or difficulties, or barriers in life. He had a particularly soft spot for children with disabilities and for very many years spent hours beyond count working for children with disabilities. In particular, Arthur set up the Noah’s Ark toy library and was recognised for that service, although it was a small part of the huge work that he did on behalf of those children. That has been recognised, I am pleased to say, in a lasting way by ARC Disability Services in Cairns naming a building after Arthur Strike.

Arthur also cared tremendously about children, particularly on the sports field. He became a coach in cricket and rugby and spent very many years doing his best to encourage children to participate in sport and to play every game fairly. He developed a passion for speedway racing and decided that the facilities in Cairns definitely needed a boost and that he would become their patron. He raised countless thousands of dollars for them. The speedway in Cairns is, in fact, proudly called the Arthur Strike Park Raceway.

Arthur served on the Cairns City Council as an alderman and as a deputy mayor over a period of 21 years. His contribution to Cairns cannot be measured. He was an absolutely amazing fundraiser for very many causes. He had such a humble manner that one could not turn him down. Heaven knows how many hundreds of thousands of dollars he raised.

He will be sorely missed by his son, Brian, by Gayle and by members of the family, but others of us gathered to celebrate a life truly well lived, with a huge contribution made to the people of Cairns and the region. I hope indeed that he is in heaven with his beloved wife, Julia.

Mr STEVENS (Mermaid Beach--LNP)
(9.21 pm): I rise tonight to express how absolutely ecstatic I am about the return of the Australian Surf Life Saving Championships to its natural home of Kurrawa on our fabulous Gold Coast next month. I congratulate Surf Life Saving Queensland on making this happen, and I wish them every success for an outstanding and thoroughly entertaining event.

The Gold Coast has the necessary infrastructure to present such a world-class event and we do it well. We have beautiful beaches, perfect weather and fantastic facilities. We have all levels of accommodation available to the 10,000 participants, supporters and visitors--from backpacker facilities right up to five-star hotels that can fulfil all accommodation needs. Around $15 million will be generated for Queensland through the staging of this event. It is a classic example of spending a small amount of money to generate a large amount for the Queensland economy.

In 1996 I was the mayor of the Gold Coast when the inaugural Australian Surf Life Saving Championships was captured for a 10-year contract at Kurrawa through the Gold Coast City Council promising $200,000 each year for 10 years. That was a commitment and I was proud to be part of it. With the super success of the Australian Surf Life Saving Championships on the Gold Coast in the past, it should never have left, but because of the failure of this state Labor government and Queensland Events to negotiate a positive outcome with Surf Life Saving Australia it slipped out of their hands and ventured across to Western Australia, where all reports said it failed miserably.

This is just another example of the inept and incompetent Bligh government that does not seem to be able to deliver a successful event, despite the fact that it has the best natural attributes of any state in Australia. It seems that everything it lays its hands on just disappears, such as the Indy carnival, the Queensland Winter Racing Carnival and possibly even the Magic Millions carnival. The victims of these constant failures are the people of Queensland.

We have not seen any sign of our New South Wales based ex-Qantas boss Geoff Dixon anywhere near Queensland since he was appointed the chairman of Queensland Events. He has not come up with one new suggestion since he was appointed to the role. Do the Premier and the Minister for Tourism believe there are no suitable Queensland tourism entrepreneurs who could run Queensland Events more efficiently and effectively than our current New South Wales phantom?

The Gold Coast is the natural home of iconic sporting events, with its ready-made infrastructure available for immediate use. When an event such as the Australian Surf Life Saving Championships fits so well with the locality and services it can provide, it should never again be lost to Queensland or the Gold Coast.

Hon. DM WELLS (Murrumba--ALP) (9.23 pm): I table a paper by parliamentary intern Sam Hussey-Smith, who has since graduated to become a member of the Hansard staff and who is perhaps making history today by sitting in the Hansard gallery auditing a speech about the work that he did while he was an intern.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Report into Aboriginal Customary Law and the Murri Courts--Research Paper prepared for the 2009 Queensland Parliamentary Internship Program by Sam Hussey-Smith.
XML.Hansard-Body: The report is titled Report into Aboriginal Customary Law and the Murri Courts . In the preparation of this document, Sam had discussions with local Aboriginal elder Uncle Peter Bind and with judicial and administrative officers of the Murri Court system and observed the Murri Court in action.

The Murri Courts throughout Queensland deal with pleas of guilty to offences that can be heard by a magistrate. Indigenous elders are involved in the process, the objective being to incorporate customary law in the sentences to reduce recidivism and the overrepresentation of Murri people in the criminal justice system. Sam concludes that the scope for additional incorporation of customary law concepts in the criminal law is limited. Customary law processes like community endorsed punishments, the involvement of elders and the shaming of offenders should be strengthened, but the application of traditional punishments further than is presently practised he thinks is not practical. However, he suggests that there is scope for expansion by giving the Murri Courts a civil jurisdiction. Sam Hussey-Smith writes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Disputes between individuals are common in customary law settings, and discrete Aboriginal dispute resolution mechanisms have existed to deal with them for thousands of years. When resolving disputes between individuals in traditional Indigenous communities, the focus was not on restitution for the wronged person, but on engaging all parties in a consensus-based process designed to restore community harmony as quickly as possible.

The Murri Court structure is flexible enough for it to deal with a number of legal issues and disputes, and not just the sentencing of offenders. Inter-clan disputes, which are a particular problem in larger urban areas with overlapping tribal land claims, could be resolved through the Murri Courts. Individual, inter- or intra-family disputes could also be heard in the Murri Courts, incorporating the traditional authority of elders and the opinions and concerns of affected community members. Widening the jurisdiction of the Murri Courts to include civil claims and other matters could also reduce the negative perceptions of the justice system held by many Aborigines, as they come to see the Australian legal system as a means for peace, order and social cohesiveness, rather than simply as a mechanism for punishment. A more open and culturally appropriate courtroom setting could also encourage Aboriginal people to resolve disputes through the conventional legal system.
XML.Hansard-Body: I commend my intern’s paper to honourable members.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP)
(9.27 pm): I rise this evening to address two key transport issues in my electorate. Members would note my keen interest in road safety around schools, so it would come as no surprise that I speak about this tonight.

The issue of road safety has been prevalent around Meridan State College. I point out that the road networks that surround the school are indeed council roads and not state roads, but I fundamentally believe that if a state government plonks a school in the middle of a residential subdivision then the state bears a certain level of responsibility to ensure that the children of that school can arrive at and depart safely from school.

Meridan State College has sustained substantial growth in the past two years and the department has failed to properly plan for this growth in terms of car parking, drop-off zones and the general flow of local vehicle and pedestrian traffic. It came to a point where a local parent organised a community rally for the governmental council to act and install a safe passageway for children to cross a busy road. The application by developer AV Jennings has been held up in council bureaucracy for many years. They have been desperately wanting to help, but this bureaucracy held them back.

Late last year I contacted the developer, AV Jennings, in an attempt to intervene and improve the situation as I believed there was still potential for an agreement to be forged. I am happy to inform the House that the developer, AV Jennings, is now funding two crossing supervisors to allow students to safely travel to school. These supervisors will enable students to safely walk along the footpath on Parklands Boulevard, which crosses to the other side of the road at the Ivadale Boulevard roundabout. The developer, AV Jennings, should be commended for its act of goodwill and community spirit. Members would think that a state that plonks a school in the middle of a residential subdivision would install a pedestrian crossing and pay for the traffic supervisors, but we have to rely on a third-party independent developer in this situation to pay for traffic supervisors so that the children who attend the school can cross the road safely to school.

A similar issue regularly occurs at Kawana Waters State College. Nicklin Way, which is the main arterial road connecting motorists from Caloundra to Maroochydore, borders the college and students are crossing this road at will in the morning and afternoon as there is no safe passage to the other side. There are no traffic lights or a pedestrian crossing at which to cross. The P&C have raised these concerns with the CoastConnect project team as the project was being revised and consultation sought, but no response has been given by this government. In the latest revised concept plan published by the department of transport, the intersection of Thunderbird Drive and Nicklin Way has been designated as a possibility for future traffic lights. Action needs to be taken now. We cannot sit around and wait for a child to be hurt trying to get to school. Action needs to be taken now.

Mrs SULLIVAN (Pumicestone--ALP) (9.29 pm): The only real threat to Bribie Island is the LNP and its current plan to build a massive desalination plant there. It is the LNP’s only proposed new source of water for the whole of South-East Queensland. There is no evidence to suggest the LNP is basing this proposal on any scientific or environmental studies. Its decision is motivated purely by politics; this is a Labor-held seat. Even the independent Queensland Water Commission states quite clearly that the best site for a desalination plant is Marcoola and the Bligh Labor government strongly supports that site for that reason. The commission identified Lytton as the next best site and then the expansion of the existing Tugun plant, which the government also supports.

I have tabled in parliament a petition with over 1,000 signatures protesting against a desalination plant on Bribie Island. I have always said that I am against any move to place one there, particularly since there are better sites. When I talk to residents, they believe a desalination plant on Bribie Island will destroy their quality of life and they do not want it. They acknowledge they are surrounded by the protected Moreton Bay Marine Park and they are concerned about the impact that hundreds of heavy vehicles would have on our roads and bridge. Those who genuinely care about the environment recognize Bribie Island as a flora and fauna reserve and worry that a desalination plant would threaten the underground aquifers.

For as long as I can remember--my husband Jon and I have lived on Bribie Island for 26 years--the Liberals and Nationals have wanted to turn Bribie Island into an industrial estate. They have suggested everything from a coal loading facility to a wood chipping plant, a satellite city with a population of 300,000 located at the fragile northern tip, John Howard’s nuclear power station and now the LNP’s massive desalination plant. I am not the only one warning locals about attending any meetings against desalination if there is any LNP involvement. It is the height of hypocrisy for anyone in the LNP to be involved, because it is LNP policy to build a desalination plant there if ever they were to win government in this state. A three-times failed LNP candidate, a newcomer to the Island, has said that we should not have a desalination plant on Bribie. I quote from a leaked email from this failed LNP candidate, which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We’ll tell any new Government that we won’t tolerate desalination here.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Yet it is his party that wants to foist it on us.
XML.Hansard-Body: Senior members of the LNP have stated publicly that they want a desalination plant on Bribie Island. On 612 ABC Radio the member for Maroochydore, whose electorate covers Marcoola, has said the desalination plant proposal for Marcoola is disastrous for the future. The member for Noosa has said it was not a project that locals wanted. The LNP water plan can be viewed at www.climateproof.com.au and copies are available from the Pumicestone electorate office.

Let us contrast the LNP with Anna Bligh’s Labor government. We have spent billions on securing water for South-East Queensland and whilst the Traveston Dam will not proceed, the desalination plants at Marcoola and Lytton will. Those who say there are other ways of providing enough water have never been able to explain how an adequate supply can be provided to our growing population. Suggesting harvesting stormwater will not provide all our needs. It has some profound difficulties and those challenges are glossed over by those opponents of desalination. Perhaps in 20 years the technology will allow some--

Ms DAVIS (Aspley--LNP) (9.33 pm): The 2010 Guide Dogs Queensland’s annual Pawknock appeal runs from 21 February to 6th March. Around 4,000 volunteers will hit the streets or email their friends to donate, and I encourage all Queenslanders, if at all possible, to contribute to this vital fundraising campaign. Guide Dogs Queensland’s head office, breeding and training centre is located in Bald Hills in the Aspley electorate. On many occasions I have had the pleasure of visiting the facility to get a better understanding of what the organisation provides for the vision impaired. Since 1960, Guide Dogs Queensland has been helping to equip, empower, and educate vision-impaired Queenslanders of all ages, regions and circumstances through the offering of a broad range of orientation and mobility services. Of course, as the name suggests, Guide Dogs Queensland is mainly known for its star attraction, the guide dogs, but the services of our canine friends are just one piece of the suite of services provided by the organisation. Endeavouring to provide a total service to the vision-impaired community, Guide Dogs Queensland also provides white cane training, electronic travel aids training, community and professional education workshops, mobility services for children and psycho-social services.

The organisation is ably led by its CEO, Ms Chris Laine, and its services are delivered both on and off site through the community and through specifically adapted residential services where clients receive education and training while living in purpose-built accommodation at Bald Hills. Last year when I toured the facility, I was put through my paces by Basshir Ebrahim as he tried to instruct me in the use of the white cane. Everyone should be encouraged to experience the difficulties faced by those with a disability and I am so glad that I was able to ‘walk in the moccasins’ of a vision-impaired person, if only for a brief moment. It was a true test of my abilities as I discovered that the smallest of things can be a big issue when you are vision impaired.

With regional offices all over Queensland, thousands of people seek Guide Dogs Queensland’s support, training and resources to assist them remain active at work and play every day. That is why this organisation deserves our support. I am sure we have all seen guide dogs diligently assisting their owners when navigating our streets, shopping centres, and transport services. I am sure members would agree that those dogs provide a marvellous service to their owners. Not only do they provide them with the sight that they lack, but they can also be a valuable companion or addition to a family.

Finally, I want to congratulate Guide Dogs Queensland on its achievement of turning 50 this year. The golden anniversary will be marked on International Guide Dogs Day, 28 April, and later in the year with an open day and concert. I wish the organisation every success in planning for this momentous occasion.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: The Learning Link Bridge, Auntie Linda Link
XML.Hansard-Body: Mrs SCOTT (Woodridge--ALP) (Woodridge--ALP) (9.36 pm): The recent completion and opening of the long-awaited pedestrian overpass bridge between the Mabel Park State School and Mabel Park State High School offered a unique opportunity to commemorate and remember in perpetuity the life of a much-loved Indigenous education counsellor, Aunty Linda Link, in naming the bridge The Learning Link. The pedestrian bridge was a government commitment made by the Hon. Paul Lucas in the wake of the sad death of a student outside Redcliffe State High School. The first pedestrian overpass was named Caitlin’s Crossing. The Mabel Park schools straddle busy Paradise Road in Slacks Creek, which is also the dividing line between Evan Moorhead’s Waterford and my Woodridge electorates. The site has seen students injured on the busy roadway and, while our government has responded over the years by installing two sets of traffic lights, none the less at times students will take risks and the results can be disastrous. Therefore, this community now has the ultimate safety feature, a bridge that is designed for disability access, enclosed for traffic safety and, with the removal of the traffic lights, which will allow for more free-flowing traffic.

This bridge, now named the Learning Link, is a fitting tribute to Aunty Linda who, for more than 20 years, nurtured and inspired possibly thousands of students, both Indigenous and non-Indigenous, at Mabel Park and Woodridge State High Schools and Kingston College, as well as many other schools. She commenced her work as a teacher aide at Mabel Park State High School in 1984. Although her own education had ended abruptly in year 4 because of family circumstances, in 1996 she completed a degree through James Cook University, at which time she was granted a permanent position as an Indigenous education counsellor. She and her husband Roy raised seven children.

Whether it was her own children or grandchildren or her students at school, Aunty Linda always believed that education was the key to a bright future for her people. Her children are testament to those strong beliefs. For example, her eldest son Johnathan is a long-serving officer of the Royal Flying Doctor Service based in Cairns and her youngest daughter, Selina, is near to completing a law degree. A rollcall of her students would include teachers, lawyers, social workers, accountants, physiotherapists, chefs, sporting high-achievers, secretaries, tradesmen and myriad others.

Sadly, Linda passed away in 2003 and tributes include a memorial garden at Mabel Park State High School, the Linda Link Indigenous Centre at Kingston College and, now, our bridge which will be a constant reminder of a treasured life and will be the link between the two campuses to ensure students cross safely. The opening on Friday, 12th February was attended by many of Aunty Linda’s family, who came from as far away as Cairns and New South Wales, along with many local Indigenous elders and community members. It was a wonderful gathering to pay tribute to a remarkable lady. A number of Linda’s family members spoke of this rare individual who dedicated so much of her life to her much-loved students and family. I was privileged to cut the ribbon with Johnathan, her eldest son. You will live on in the hearts of many, Aunty Linda, and never be forgotten.

Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (9.39 pm): I rise tonight to table a non-conforming petition signed by 880 residents of the community of Monto calling for an urgent upgrade to the main road link to their closest regional centre of Bundaberg. The petition states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We the undersigned citizens petition the Governments State and Federal for an upgrade of the Mount Perry-Gin Gin road in particular the Oaky creek to Yarrol road turnoff section and to remedy the lack of communication between the Burnett Highway and Mt Perry.
XML.Hansard-Body: This petition has been motivated by a terrible head-on accident on the road that claimed the lives of two men. One of the accident victims was Lionel Cavanagh, a schoolteacher who had served the Monto community for 30 years and whom I knew well. Lionel Cavanagh was a very well respected schoolteacher through his initiatives with the school’s cattle club, which gave the high school students the opportunity to show cattle at all the regional shows and at the Brisbane exhibition. He was an outstanding member of the Monto community and was involved in an extensive range of community activities.

His death in the tragic head-on accident on a crest on the unsealed section of the Monto-Mount Perry Road has inspired the community of Monto to instigate a campaign to have the road upgraded to a much safer sealed standard. The sealing of this road is long overdue. It is the primary link to the regional centre of Bundaberg for all Monto residents and it is an appalling failure of regional planning that it remains in such a dangerous unsealed state when every other such road linking smaller towns to nearby regional centres has long since been upgraded to a sealed standard.

Local residents have to travel this road for all the same reasons that residents of smaller towns throughout Queensland have to travel to their regional centre. In recent years the changes in the health system, for example, have increased the need for people in Monto to travel to Bundaberg. As the health services available locally have declined, as they have in all small communities, more and more people are referred to Bundaberg for treatment. This often requires multiple trips across a road that is clearly substandard and has seen many minor accidents and near misses before the tragic accident that recently took two lives.

In tabling this petition in the parliament tonight, I want to strongly support the campaign that 200 people of Monto instigated at a recent public meeting in their town hall under the slogan of ‘Monto to Mount Perry--No more fatalities’. I call on the Minister for Main Roads to address this critical issue. Why this road has remained unsealed for so long is now irrelevant and there is no place for finger pointing and blame shifting. The road needs to be brought up to a standard more appropriate for a major regional road before there are more tragic accidents claiming more lives. I table the petition.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Non-conforming petition relating to an upgrade of the Mount Perry-Gin Gin Road, in particular the Oaky Creek to Yarrol Road turnoff section and to remedy the lack of communication between Burnett Highway and Mount Perry
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms FARMER (Bulimba--ALP) (9.41 pm): I was very excited to hear the Minister for Child Safety and Minister Sport today announce a suite of new funding programs to encourage participation in sport and recreation. I am an extremely enthusiastic supporter of the government’s initiatives to promote a healthy and active lifestyle, and there is no doubt that these new funding programs will go a long way towards contributing to that outcome. I congratulate the minister on his thoughtful analysis of the way sport and recreation clubs operate, using this as the basis for putting together the new programs. He is a most enthusiastic supporter of sport and recreation and obviously loves his portfolio.

There is already a lot going on in the Bulimba electorate that encourages a healthy and active lifestyle. There are 35 sporting clubs active in the local community, and it is a pleasure to drive throughout our suburbs on a Saturday or a Sunday--or any night of the week, for that matter--and see children and adults being active in a variety of different ways in our local facilities. We know that none of these activities would be happening without the dedication and commitment of volunteers, and there are no more visible examples of the long-time contribution of our local volunteers than in our four very active swimming clubs.

Last Saturday I had the pleasure of attending as both a mum and an MP a three-way swim meet which was organised by the Cannon Hill Dolphins with the Morningside Flyers and the Norman Park Swim Club. I particularly acknowledge Amanda Shipway for her excellent coordination of this event. It was a truly enjoyable afternoon and a fine example of clubs getting together to make sure kids see sport as not just competition but also an opportunity to be part of a team and to enjoy being active. The kids all did us proud.

These three clubs, along with the Bulimba Darts Swimming Club, comprise a fair cross-section of the children of the Bulimba electorate. They have been going for a number of years and all of them boast volunteers who have seen them through generations of local children. They can tell much of the history of their clubs and have so much to contribute.

In the Cannon Hill Dolphins, which has been running for 30 years, there is Sandra Spinaze, who has had six children and now three grandchildren swim for the club; Michelle and Peter Hurketts, who have been with the club for the past 12 years; and also the Forgan family and Paul Norman. In the Morningside Flyers, which has been running for nearly 45 years, there are life members George and Delma Nicholson, Ernie and Lyn Blumel, John and Julie Beale, Michael Mann and Jason and Lisa Spencer. I was very sorry to hear today from Jason that he is stepping down as president after nine years with the club. The Bulimba Darts Swimming Club has long-time volunteers John and Sharni Lovell and the Hoskings family. The Norman Park Swim Club, which has so many enthusiastic volunteers, headed up by David Orchid, has been running for more than 45 years.
I thank all of these clubs for the life they give to our local community and the wonderful volunteers who have for so long made them the vibrant organisations that they are.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 9.44 pm.

Attwood, Bates, Bleijie, Bligh, Boyle, Choi, Crandon, Cripps, Croft, Cunningham, Darling, Davis, Dempsey, Dick, Dickson, Douglas, Dowling, Elmes, Emerson, Farmer, Finn, Flegg, Foley, Fraser, Gibson, Grace, Hinchliffe, Hobbs, Hoolihan, Hopper, Horan, Jarratt, Johnson, Johnstone, Jones, Keech, Kiernan, Kilburn, Knuth, Langbroek, Lawlor, Lucas, McArdle, McLindon, Male, Malone, Messenger, Mickel, Miller, Moorhead, Mulherin, Nicholls, Nolan, O’Brien, O’Neill, Palaszczuk, Pitt, Powell, Pratt, Reeves, Rickuss, Roberts, Robertson, Robinson, Ryan, Schwarten, Scott, Seeney, Shine, Simpson, Smith, Sorensen, Spence, Springborg, Stevens, Stone, Struthers, Stuckey, Sullivan, van Litsenburg, Wallace, Watt, Wellington, Wells, Wendt, Wettenhall, Wilson
